journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Long bone fracture belongs to one of the most common injuries encountered in clinical routine trauma surgery. Automated identification, pose and size estimation, and contour extraction of diaphyseal bone fragments can greatly improve the usability of a computer-assisted, fluoroscopy-based navigation system for long bone fracture reduction. In this paper, a two-step solution is proposed. In the first step, the pose and size of a diaphyseal fragment are estimated through a three-dimensional (3D) morphable object-based fitting process using a parametric cylinder model. This fitting process is optimally solved by a hybrid optimization technique coupling a random sample consensus (RANSAC) paradigm and an iterative closest point (ICP) matching procedure. Monte Carlo simulation was used to determine the parameters for the RANSAC paradigm. The results of the fragment detection step are then fed to the second step, where a region information based active contour model is used to extract the fragment contours. We designed and conducted experiments to quantify the accuracy and robustness of the proposed approach. Our experimental results conducted on images of a plastic bone as well as on those of patients demonstrate a promising accuracy and robustness of the proposed approach. © 2007 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on detecting and segmenting bone fragments, which doesn't relate to predicting or evaluating how things look after plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn't fit this review.

title: A haptics-assisted cranio-maxillofacial surgery planning system for restoring skeletal anatomy in complex trauma cases
author: Olsson P.; Nysjö F.; Hirsch J.-M.; Carlbom I.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Cranio-maxillofacial (CMF) surgery to restore normal skeletal anatomy in patients with serious trauma to the face can be both complex and time-consuming. But it is generally accepted that careful pre-operative planning leads to a better outcome with a higher degree of function and reduced morbidity in addition to reduced time in the operating room. However, today's surgery planning systems are primitive, relying mostly on the user's ability to plan complex tasks with a two-dimensional graphical interface. Methods: A system for planning the restoration of skeletal anatomy in facial trauma patients using a virtual model derived from patient-specific CT data. The system combines stereo visualization with six degrees-of-freedom, high-fidelity haptic feedback that enables analysis, planning, and preoperative testing of alternative solutions for restoring bone fragments to their proper positions. The stereo display provides accurate visual spatial perception, and the haptics system provides intuitive haptic feedback when bone fragments are in contact as well as six degrees-of-freedom attraction forces for precise bone fragment alignment. Results: A senior surgeon without prior experience of the system received 45 min of system training. Following the training session, he completed a virtual reconstruction in 22 min of a complex mandibular fracture with an adequately reduced result. Conclusion: Preliminary testing with one surgeon indicates that our surgery planning system, which combines stereo visualization with sophisticated haptics, has the potential to become a powerful tool for CMF surgery planning. With little training, it allows a surgeon to complete a complex plan in a short amount of time.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a haptics-based surgical planning tool for cranio-maxillofacial trauma but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results.

title: A method for material parameter determination for the human mandible based on simulation and experiment
author: Clason C.; Hinz A.M.; Schieferstein H.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: In cranio-maxillofacial surgery planning and implant design, it is important to know the elastic response of the mandible to load forces as they occur, e.g., in biting. The goal of the present study is to provide a method for a quantitative determination of material parameters for the human jaw bone, whose values can, e.g., be used to devise a prototype plastic model for the mandible. Non-destructive load experiments are performed on a cadaveric mandible using a specially designed test bed. The identical physiological situation is simulated in a computer program. The underlying mathematical model is based on a two component, linear elastic material law. The numerical realization of the model, difficult due to the complex geometry and morphology of the mandible, is via the finite element (FE) method. Combining the validated simulation with the results of the tests, an inverse problem for the determination of Young's modulus and the Poisson ratio of both cortical and cancellous bone can then be solved. © 2004 Taylor & Francis Ltd.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical analysis of the mandible with simulations and experiments but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Phase-unwrapping algorithm for images with high noise content based on a local histogram
author: Meneses J.; Gharbi T.; Humbert P.
abstract: We present a robust algorithm of phase unwrapping that was designed for use on phase images with high noise content. We proceed with the algorithm by first identifying regions with continuous phase values placed between fringe boundaries in an image and then phase shifting the regions with respect to one another by multiples of 2π to unwrap the phase. Image pixels are segmented between interfringe and fringe boundary areas by use of a local histogram of a wrapped phase. The algorithm has been used successfully to unwrap phase images generated in a three-dimensional shape measurement for noninvasive quantification of human skin structure in dermatology, cosmetology, and plastic surgery. © 2005 Optical Society of America.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a method for image processing that doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Three-dimensional facial model reconstruction and plastic surgery simulation
author: Lee T.-Y.; Sun Y.-N.; Lin Y.-C.; Lin L.; Lee C.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: Facial model reconstruction and surgical simulation are essential to plastic surgery in today's medicine. Both can help surgeons to design appropriate repair plans and procedures prior to actual surgery. In this paper, we exploit a metamorphosis technique in our new design. First, using metamorphosis and vision techniques, we can establish three-dimensional facial models from a given photo. Second, we design several morphing operators, including augmentation, cutting, and lacerating. Experiments show that the proposed algorithms can successfully create acceptable facial models and generate realistically visual effects of surgical simulation.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on 3D facial modeling and surgical simulation without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Optimizing light collection from thin scintillators used in a beta-ray camera for surgical use
author: Levin C.S.; MacDonald L.R.; Tornai M.P.; Hoffman E.J.; Park J.
abstract: We are developing a 1-2 cm2 area camera for imaging the distribution of beta-emitting radiopharmaceuticals at the surface of tissue exposed during surgery. The front end consists of a very thin continuous or segmented scintillator sensitive to betas (positrons or electrons) of a few hundred keV, yet insensitive to gamma rays. The light from the scintillator is piped through clear fibers to the photon detector (PD). This approach requires that a sufficient number of scintillation photons be transported from the scintillator, through the fibers to the PD. The scintillator, reflector, surface treatments, geometry, fiber light guides, and optical couplings must be optimized. We report here on efforts made to optimize the light collection from < 3 mm thick plastic and CaF2(Eu) scintillators into clear fibers using experimental measurements and computer simulations. We measured that with a 1.25 cm diameter, 0.5 mm thick optimized CaF2(Eu) disk coupled to a 5 cm long bundle of clear optical fibers, on average, ∼250 photoelectrons are produced at a PMT photocathode for a 204Tl beta flood source (Emax = 763 keV). This corresponds to a sufficient number of photoelectrons for ∼ 1 mm resolution imaging capabilities for the proposed camera. © 1996 IEEE.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on improving light collection in a beta-ray camera for surgical imaging without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: An integrated environment for plastic surgery support: Building virtual patients, simulating interventions, and supporting intraoperative decisions
author: Porro I.; Schenone A.; Fato M.; Raposio E.; Molinari E.; Beltrame F.
abstract: In the last decade a number of environments for Computer Supported Plastic Surgery have been presented. Nevertheless, an overall approach for training and intraoperative support is still missing or has not been widely exploited yet. We developed a fully integrated system which allows surgical simulation, planning, and support for computer-guided plastic surgery procedures starting from image acquisition to final intraoperative assistance. The system also provides the user with a radiological workstation able to analyse patient medical images and case studies, with advanced bidimensional and three dimensional image processing functionalities. We intend to demonstrate that such a platform can be built at an affordable cost. The radiological workstation is capable of supporting radiologists and surgeons in real patient case studies and the simulation workstation may be adopted by plastic surgeons in teaching and training of complex surgical planning. Moreover, results of simulation can be used in the operating room with a relatively high benefit in terms of improved accuracy, reduction of surgical risks, and decrease in training costs. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on surgical simulation and support tools during surgery instead of predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Optimization of rib surgery parameters for the correction of scoliotic deformities using approximation models
author: Carrier J.; Aubin C.-É.; Trochu F.; Labelle H.
abstract: Background. As opposed to thoracoplasty (a cosmetic surgical intervention used to reduce the rib hump associated with scoliosis), experimental scoliosis has been produced or reversed on animals by rib shortening or lengthening. In a prior work (J. Orthop. Res., 20, pp. 1121-1128), a finite element modeling (FEM) of rib surgeries was developed to study the biomechanics of their correction mechanisms. Our aims in the present study were to investigate the influence of the rib surgery parameters and to identify optimal configurations. Hence, a specific objective of this study was to develop a method to find surgical parameters maximizing the correction by addressing the issue of high computational cost associated with FEM. Method of Approach. Different configurations of rib shortening or lengthening were simulated using a FEM of the complete torso adapted to the geometry of six patients. Each configuration was assessed using objective functions that represent different correction objectives. Their value was evaluated using the rib surgery simulation for sample locations in the design space specified by an experimental design. Dual kriging (interpolation technique) was used to fit the data from the computer experiment. The resulting approximation model was used to locate parameters minimizing the objective function. Results. The overall coverage of the design space and the use of an approximation model ensured that the optimization algorithm had not found a local minimum but a global optimal correction. The interventions generally produced slight immediate modifications with final geometry presenting between 95-120% of the initial deformation in about 50% of the tested cases. But in optimal cases, important loads (500-2000 N mm) were generated on vertebral endplates in the apical region, which could potentially produce the long-term correction of vertebral wedging by modulating growth. Optimal parameters varied among patients and for different correction objectives. Conclusions. Approximation models make it possible to study and find optimal rib surgery parameters while reducing computational cost. Copyright © 2005 by ASME.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical details of rib surgery for scoliosis without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Rapid prototyping for orthopaedic surgery
author: Potamianos P.; Amis A.A.; Forester A.J.; McGurk M.; Bircher M.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: The revision of an orthopaedic procedure can present surgeons with the challenge of a complex reconstructive process. Orthopaedic surgery can also face considerable challenges in cases presenting extensive primary injuries with multiple bone fragmentation, as well as in cases presenting bone deformities. Radiographs are used routinely for orthopaedic surgical planning, yet they provide inadequate information on the precise three-dimensional extent of bone defects. Three-dimensional reconstructions from X-ray computed tomography offer superior visualization but are not portable for consultation or readily available in the operating theatre for guidance during a procedure. A physical model manufactured from X-ray computed tomography data can offer surgeons a clear understanding of complex anatomical detail, by providing an intuitive physical relationship between patient and model. Rapid prototyping was used for the construction of an anatomical model in a case presenting with a complex shoulder injury. The model provided a definitive interpretation of joint pathology and enabled a full assessment of the degree of injury. ©IMechE1998.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on quick modeling for bone surgery but doesn't cover automatic predictions or looks at cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn't match the review topic.

title: Mechanical simulation of composite hip stems
author: Kaddick C.; Stur S.; Hipp E.
abstract: Calculation of new orthopedic implants prior to manufacturing of prototypes can be economic in the case of complex production processes. The use of composite materials for highly loaded hip stems is one application of the Finite-Element Method. Due to the anisotropic behaviour of composite structures, special routines had to be programmed for element alignment and failure analysis. Stability of carbon fibre-reinforced epoxy hip stems could be confirmed by experimental results. The risk of neck fracture was found to be one of the critical features in the design process.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on mechanical simulation and design of hip implants, not covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: The planning of orthopaedic reconstructive surgery using computer-aided simulation and design
author: Murphy S.B.; Kijewski P.K.; Millis M.B.; Hall J.E.; Simon S.R.; Chandler H.P.
abstract: Three-dimensional reconstructions from computed tomographic (CT) images are currently being used clinically in a wide variety of orthopaedic surgical applications. The computer may be used to select the optimum standard artificial joint replacement or to design a custom artificial joint replacement for a particular patient. Where large bony defects exist, the computer may be used to design bone allografts for joint reconstruction and to manufacture models of the bones for use in planning the surgery. In cases where osteotomies are performed to improve the mechanics of the joint, each proposed osteotomy may be simulated on the computer to identify the surgical plan that will optimally normalize the diseased joint. © 1988.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on computer-aided planning for orthopedic surgery and doesn't cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: In vivo experimental testing and model identification of human scalp skin
author: Gambarotta L.; Massabò R.; Morbiducci R.; Raposio E.; Santi P.
abstract: A comprehensive experimental/numerical procedure is formulated and validated for the in vivo characterization of the mechanical properties of human skin and the simulation of reconstructive surgery. The procedure uses in vivo experimental tests on undermined skin flaps, which can be performed during surgery, a numerical model formulated within the framework of nonlinear finite strain elasticity and a nonlinear parameter identification technique for the calibration of the model from indirect measurements. The procedure is applied to characterize the scalp skin tested in Raposio and Nordström (Skin Res. Technol. 4 (1998) 94). The skin is treated as a time independent, isotropic and hyperelastic membrane and the problem is solved through a finite element discretization. The study highlights that the model parameters can be determined with good accuracy using displacement measurements of a few points in the domain. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on modeling scalp skin properties instead of predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Mass transport disturbances in the distal graft/artery junction of a peripheral bypass graft
author: Devereux P.D.; O'Callaghan S.M.; Walsh M.T.; McGloughlin T.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: Intimal hyperplasia (IH) development is a primary cause of failure of reconstructive bypass surgery. While the exact mechanism by which IH initiates and proliferates has yet to be fully elucidated, it is clear that the abnormal haemodynamics present in the downstream graft/artery junction are intrinsic in its development. Mass transport disturbances owing to abnormal haemodynamics have been associated with atherogenesis and it is for this reason that an investigation into transport of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), a known promoter of the intimal hyperplastic response, at the downstream graft/artery junction was carried out. A steady flow analysis in a three-dimensional, idealized, downstream graft/artery junction was carried out using commercial computational fluid dynamics software. It was found that there is a two-and-half fold increase in the transport of PDGF to the artery wall at the bed of the junction when compared with an idealized, healthy artery. The presence of secondary flows in the downstream arterial section also leads to large disturbances in mass transport. It was concluded that PDGF transport in the downstream graft/artery junction tends to be highly disturbed and that there may be a role of this disturbance in the initiation and subsequent development of distal anastornotic intimal hyperplasia. © IMechE 2005.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on blood flow and transport issues in vascular grafts, which isn’t connected to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: A predictive study of the mechanical behaviour of coronary stents by computer modelling
author: Migliavacca F.; Petrini L.; Montanari V.; Quagliana I.; Auricchio F.; Dubini G.
abstract: Intravascular stents are small tube-like structures expanded into stenotic arteries to restore blood flow perfusion to the downstream tissues. The stent expansion is an important factor to define the effectiveness of the surgical procedure: it depends on the stent geometry and includes large displacements and deformations, geometric and material non-linearity. Numerical analyses seem appropriate to study such a complex behaviour after a free stent expansion. In this study the finite element method (FEM) was applied to a new generation coronary stent. Results from computations were compared with those from a laboratory experiment in terms of radial expansion and elastic recoil. By means of a scanning electronic microscopy the area of plastic deformation were also detected and compared with those obtained in the numerical simulation. Matching between the different measurements was quite satisfactory even if some discrepancies were present due to the absence of the balloon in the numerical model. © 2004 IPEM. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract centers on mechanical modeling of coronary stents and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t match the review’s focus.

title: Computer-aided prototype system for nose surgery
author: Lee T.-Y.; Lin C.-H.; Lin H.-Y.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: Rhinoplasty, or surgery to reshape the nose, is one of the most common of all plastic-surgery procedures. Rhinoplasty can enhance a patient's appearance and self-confidence, may also correct a birth defect or injury, or help relieve some breathing problem. In this paper, we present a three-dimensional (3-D) surgical simulation system, which can assist surgeons in planning rhinoplasty procedures. This system employs computer graphics and image-processing techniques for the simulation of a rhinoplasty. Although the presented algorithms themselves are not new, the proposed system exploits the new idea to apply 3-D morphing for rhinoplasty, and simulation results are useful for the physicians. According to patients' expectation of what they would like their noses to look like, our system simulates expected results. Our tools provide quantitative measurements of a nose structure. Using these quantitative results, surgeons can arrange appropriate preoperative plans for patients. Finally, experimental results and experiences are reported to evaluate the usefulness of the proposed system.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focus is on automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, but the abstract talks about surgical planning and simulation instead.

title: Simulation of the biomechanical behavior of the skin in virtual surgical applications by finite element method
author: Molinari E.; Fato M.; De Leo G.; Riccardo D.; Beltrame F.
abstract: The objective of this study was to develop a software application that is able to support plastic surgeons interested in applying simulations and soft tissue modeling during presurgical planning activities. By using our user-friendly interface and force-displacement graphs, users can analyze scalp skin behaviors when subjected to stress. Users can 1) determine the dynamic of a general point of scalp skin after the application of a specific force, 2) predict the force needed for displacement of a point, and 3) study the deformation of all the points of the entire scalp based on the force applied. Results showed how users are able to manipulate and analyze mechanical behaviors on a mechanical model rather than on a pure geometric qualitative physiological model. The entire application was developed on a Silicon Graphics workstation. © 2005 IEEE.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical simulation for surgical planning without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation, so it doesn't fit the review’s focus.

title: From robotic hands to human hands: A visualization and simulation engine for grasping research
author: Miller A.; Allen P.; Santos V.; Valero-Cuevas F.
abstract: Purpose - Robotic hands are still a long way from matching the grasping and manipulation capability of their human counterparts, but computer simulation may help us understand this disparity. We present our publicly available simulator, and describe our research projects involving the system including the development of a human hand model derived from experimental measurements. Design/methodology/approach - Unlike other simulation systems, our system was built specifically to analyze grasps. It can import a wide variety of robot designs by using standard descriptions of the kinematics and link geometries. Various components support the analysis of grasps, visualization of results, dynamic simulation of grasping tasks, and grasp planning. Findings - The simulator has been used in several grasping research problems and can be used to plan grasps for an actual robot. With the aid of a vision system, we have shown that these grasps can be executed by a robot. Research limitations/implications - We are currently developing methods to handle deformable surfaces, tendon driven models, and non-ideal joints in order to better model human grasping. Practical implications - This work is part of our current project to create a biomechanically realistic human hand model to better understand what features are most important to mimic in the designs of robotic hands. Such a model will also help clinicians better plan reconstructive hand surgeries. Originality/value - We describe our publicly available grasping simulator and review experiments performed with it. The paper demonstrates the usefulness of this system as a tool for grasping research. © Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on robotic hand simulation and biomechanical modeling without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t relate to the review’s topic.

title: A 3D finite element model of the face for simulation in plastic and maxillo-facial surgery
author: Chabanas M.; Payan Y.
journal: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
abstract: This paper introduces a new Finite Element biomechanical model of the human face, which has been developed to be integrated into a simulator for plastic and maxillo-facial surgery. The idea is to be able to predict, from an aesthetic and functional point of view, the deformations of a patient face, resulting from repositioning of the maxillary and mandibular bone structures. This work will complete the simulator for bone-repositioning diagnosis that has been developed by the laboratory. After a description of our research project context, each step of the modeling is precisely described: the continuous and elastic structure of the skin tissues, the orthotropic muscular fibers and their insertions points, and the functional model of force generation. First results of face deformations due to muscles activations are presented. They are qualitatively compared to the functional studies provided by the literature on face muscles roles and actions. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2000.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical modeling and simulation of facial tissue changes but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which is the main interest of this review.

title: Analytical guide wire motion algorithm for simulation of endovascular interventions
author: Konings M.K.; van de Kraats E.B.; Alderliesten T.; Niessen W.J.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Performing minimally invasive vascular interventions requires proper training, as a guide wire needs to be manipulated, by the tail, under fluoroscopic guidance. To provide a training environment, the motion of the guide wire inside the human vasculature can be simulated by computer. Such a simulation needs to be based on an algorithm that is both realistic and fast. To meet these two demands, an analytical solution to the problem of guide wire motion has been derived, using a new parametrisation of guide wire shape. The algorithm is highly generic, is entirely based on elementary physics and has good convergence properties (accuracy of 22 micron after two iterations). In an experimental validation of the algorithm in a planar model, the RMS of the spatial discrepancy between the real and simulated catheter positions was about 10% of the lumen size. Comparison of the simulated guide wire motion with 3D rotational angiography data of a real guide wire advanced in a plastic phantom of the cerebral vasculature showed that the new algorithm produced realistic results.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on simulating guide wire movement in endovascular procedures, which doesn’t relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Computer supported pre-operative simulation of neonatus cranial bone bending in craniosynostosis surgery planning
author: Clijmans T.; Mommaerts M.; Suetens P.; Vander Sloten J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Craniosynostosis refers to a category of skull malformations caused by premature fusion of one or more sutures in the cranial vault. Frequently, during skull reconstruction surgery, pieces of bone, which have been taken out of the skull, need to be deformed within the plastic region before replacement. Since existing surgery planning software does not allow bone bending simulation, the surgeon relies on his experience to determine the correct curvature and to make sure the bone will not fracture. Therefore, there are two important aspects to the bending algorithm presented in this paper: the visualization and the fracture risk assessment. The Matlab® visualization method allows simulating bending of an STL modeled bone segment, obtained from simulation in commercial planning software, in a realistic way. The estimation of the fracture risk is a valuable addition to the simulation environment as the user is informed about the feasibility of his bending actions. The bone bending algorithm has been successfully applied in two clinical cases of skull reconstruction planning for craniosynostosis surgery. During surgery, screenshots of the pre-operatively reshaped bone models established faster and more reliable bone segment bending.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on simulating bone bending before surgery without covering automatic predictions or assessing how the surgery looks afterward, which falls outside the review’s main topics.

title: Computer-based planning of optimal donor sites for autologous osseous grafts
author: Król Z.; Chlebiej M.; Zerfass P.; Zeilhofer H.-F.; Sader R.; Mikołajczak P.; Keeve E.
journal: Proceedings of SPIE-The International Society for Optical Engineering
abstract: Bone graft surgery is often necessary for reconstruction of craniofacial defects after trauma, tumor, infection or congenital malformation. In this operative technique the removed or missing bone segment is filled with a bone graft. The mainstay of the craniofacial reconstruction rests with the replacement of the defected bone by autogeneous bone grafts. To achieve sufficient incorporation of the autograft into the host bone, precise planning and simulation of the surgical intervention is required. The major problem is to determine as accurately as possible the donor site where the graft should be dissected from and to define the shape of the desired transplant. A computer-aided method for semi-automatic selection of optimal donor sites for autografts in craniofacial reconstructive surgery has been developed. The non-automatic step of graft design and constraint setting is followed by a fully automatic procedure to find the best fitting position. In extension to preceding work, a new optimization approach based on the Levenberg-Marquardt method has been implemented and embedded into our computer-based surgical planning system. This new technique enables, once the pre-processing step has been performed, selection of the optimal donor site in time less than one minute. The method has been applied during surgery planning step in more than 20 cases. The postoperative observations have shown that functional results, such as speech and chewing ability as well as restoration of bony continuity were clearly better compared to conventionally planned operations. Moreover, in most cases the duration of the surgical interventions has been distinctly reduced.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on computer-based planning for donor site selection in bone graft surgery, but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, which is what the review is about.

title: A multi-physics growth model with fluid-structure interactions for blood flow and re-stenosis in rat vein grafts: A growth model for blood flow and re-stenosis in grafts
author: Yang C.; Tang D.; Liu S.Q.
abstract: Vein graft is commonly used to replace malfunctioned arteries. However, intimal hyperplasia (IH) and re-stenosis often occur after surgery leading to serious clinical problems. A multi-physics computational model with tube wall growth and fluid-structure interactions and an iterative mixed method using finite volume, generalized finite difference and finite elements are introduced to simulate focal intimal hyperplasia and blood flow in rat abdominal artery with a vein graft. Physical parameters and physiological geometries from in vivo experimental data are used in model development and verifications. Our results indicate that the mismatches in geometry and mechanical properties between the host artery and the vein graft cause considerable disturbance in flow shear stress, eddy flow, tube wall deformation, and tensile stress/strain distributions. Focal intimal hyperplasia and re-stenosis process are closely related to eddy flow and low and oscillating shear stresses. A constitutive growth function which governs the IH growth is quantified based on experimental data and computational simulations. Further investigation of effects of other factors such as tensile stress and various cell interactions is needed to fully understand IH growth and re-stenosis process. © 2003 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Centers on blood flow modeling in vein grafts rather than on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s main focus.

title: Tissue engineered composite of a woven fabric scaffold with tendon cells, response on mechanical simulation in vitro
author: Karamuk E.; Mayer J.; Raeber G.
abstract: In reconstructive surgery, complications of implanted textiles are often associated with mechanical and structural incompatibility between implant and host tissue. Ingrowing cells and maturation of an extracellular matrix form together with the textile a vital/avital composite and by this change mechanical properties of the textile implant. Thus, a profound understanding is required to consider these effects in the design of the implant. Mechanical stimulation in tissue engineering is proposed as a viable experimental technique to investigate structure-properties relations to design vital/avital composites. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate the effects of cyclic mechanical stimulation (2% sinusoidal strain, 1 h at 0.5 Hz stimulation followed by 6 h recreation phase at 0.01 Hz) on a vital/avitat composite that consists of a woven fabric as scaffold and confluent tendon fibroblasts as the vital matrix. The force response during the exertion phase could be correlated to dynamic orientation of f-actin filaments in the cytosceleton. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Highlights effects of mechanical stimulation in tissue scaffolds but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: The application of full-scale 3D anthropometric digital model system on breast reconstruction of plastic surgeries
author: Sun S.-P.; Chen J.-S.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: A full-scale 3D anthropometric digital model system is a set of technology that combines a 3D digital imaging system, computer 3D image processing system, reverse engineering, and Computer-Aided Design. The purpose of this study is to create a full-size solid breast model using the 1:1 anthropometric digital model technique to assist breast reconstruction plastic surgery by matching the size of the symmetrical breast of the patient. The full-sized simulated breast model created in this study not only assists plastic surgeons in achieving more symmetric breasts during reconstruction but also facilitates analysis of breast symmetry. This study uses a 3D optical scanner to capture patients' breast 3D image data, then applies reverse engineering techniques and CAD software to simulate and analyze the 3D image model of the reconstructed breasts. When needed during medical treatment, the 3D digital data can be applied to a Rapid Prototyping machine to produce a full-sized solid model. Doctors can use this solid model for evaluation and surgical planning, serving as an important reference in breast reconstruction surgeries, thereby reducing patient inconvenience and improving medical treatment quality.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on making physical 3D models for surgery instead of using automated tools to predict or evaluate aesthetic results, which isn't covered in this review.

title: Detection and prediction of tooth mobility during the periodontitis healing process
author: Grabec I.; Grošelj D.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The focus of the article is on a generic approach to prediction of a healing process based on automatic measurement and modelling of mechanical disease indicators. As a specific example the healing process after treatment of advanced periodontitis is characterised and predicted based on measurement of tooth mobility (TM). For the measurement a new mechatronic instrument was developed that includes a pneumatically driven probe with incorporated sensors of tooth displacement and loading force. TM is measured by a computer controlled data acquisition system and predicted by a nonparametric regression. Similarly as in the characterisation of technical processes, a measured sample is described by TM time series detected on a particular patient, while the regression is determined by a set of samples obtained from a group of patients following periodontal therapy. The influence of surgical access therapy and systemic administration of metronidazole as an adjunct to the mechanical treatment is demonstrated. For this purpose the average changes of tooth mobility are determined on variously treated subgroups. A new method of healing process prediction is demonstrated and its performance is described by a prediction quality. © 2003 Taylor & Francis Ltd.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on predicting tooth movement during healing, which doesn't relate to predicting aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it falls outside the review's topic.

title: Application of an adaptive control grid interpolation technique to morphological vascular reconstruction
author: Frakes D.H.; Conrad C.P.; Healy T.M.; Monaco J.W.; Fogel M.; Sharma S.; Smith M.J.T.; Yoganathan A.P.
abstract: The problem of interslice magnetic resonance (MR) image reconstruction arises in a broad range of medical applications. In such cases, there is a need to approximate information present in the original subject that is not reflected in contiguously acquired MR images because of hardware sampling limitations. In the context of vascular morphology reconstruction, this information is required in order for subsequent visualization and computational analysis of blood vessels to be most effective. Toward that end we have developed a method of vascular morphology reconstruction based on adaptive control grid interpolation (ACGI) to function as a precursor to visualization and computational analysis. ACGI has previously been implemented in addressing various problems including video coding and tracking. This paper focuses on the novel application of the technique to medical image processing. ACGI combines features of optical flow-based and block-based motion estimation algorithms to enhance insufficiently dense MR data sets accurately with a minimal degree of computational complexity. The resulting enhanced data sets describe vascular geometries. These reconstructions can then be used as visualization tools and in conjunction with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations to offer the pressure and velocity information necessary to quantify power loss. The proposed ACGI methodology is envisioned ultimately to play a role in surgical planning aimed at producing optimal vascular configurations for successful surgical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on imaging techniques for surgery planning but doesn’t cover automated prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s outside the review’s focus.

title: 2D and 3D computer tomography and sinus graft analysis with various graft materials
author: Hrabák K.; Szabó G.; Ewers R.; Gyulai-Gaál S.
journal: Journal of Long-Term Effects of Medical Implants
abstract: Sinus grafting has been a routine surgical procedure since the 1970s. Computer tomography (e.g., SIM/Plant(TM)) is available for planning and simulation, but it has not been used to control the success and the long-term results of the planned surgery. The aim of this work was to apply a prospective examination method to determine (a) the extent to which the success of sinus grafting can be followed through 2D (two-dimensional) and 3D (three-dimensional) CT (computer tomography) reconstruction, (b) when choosing this method is worthwhile, and (c) how to visualize incorporating and transforming various graft materials. Twelve patients received 21 sinus graftings, with immediate implantation. Four 2D and 3D CT reconstructions were performed: (1) preoperatively, (2) 1-2 weeks postoperatively, (3) before loading, and (4) 1 year after completing prosthodontic treatment. The sinus grafts were composed of a mixture of HTR Bioplant(TM) polymer and autograft, or from a mixture of Algipore® (HA, hydroxyapatite) and autograft. In the bilateral cases, both sinus graft mixtures were used, one on each side. The posterior-anterior, the lateral, and the superior-inferior views provided the most useful information; the usefulness of serial images is very limited. Individual 2D and 3D CT reconstructions are proposed, however, in cases of extensive bone atrophy, if complications are expected, if complications arise during surgery, if healing is protracted, or if the documentation is important for other reasons. The long-term results of the two graft materials could be followed up extremely well. Both materials proved outstandingly suitable for sinus grafting.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on CT imaging in dental surgery and doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Calcium phosphate nucleation on surface-modified PTFE membranes
author: Grøndahl L.; Cardona F.; Chiem K.; Wentrup-Byrne E.; Bostrom T.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Highly porous PTFE membranes are currently being used in facial reconstructive surgery. The present study aims at improving this biomaterial through creating a more bioactive surface by introducing ionic groups onto the surface. The unmodified PTFE membrane does not induce inorganic growth after immersion in simulated body fluid (SBF) for up to 4 weeks. Copolymeric grafting with acrylic acid (AAc) by means of gamma irradiation and subsequent in vitro testing in SBF reveals that this copolymer initially acts as an ion-exchange material and subsequently induces growth of a calcium phosphate phase (Ca/P=2.7) when large amounts (15%) of pAAc are introduced onto the membrane surface. This copolymer is not expected to function well from a biomaterials perspective since SEM showed the pores on the surface to be partly blocked. In contrast, the surface of monoacryloxyethyl phosphate (MAEP)-modified samples is altered at a molecular level only. Yet the modified materials are able to induce calcium phosphate nucleation when the external surface coverage is 44% or above. The initial inorganic growth on these membranes in SBF hasa (Ca+ Mg)/P ratio of 1.1 (presumably Brushite or Monetite). The secondary growth, possibly calcium-deficient apatite or tricalcium phosphate, has a (Ca+Mg)/P ratio of 1.5. This result is a promising indicator of a bioactive biomaterial. © 2003 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at biomaterial and calcium phosphate topics, but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s not a fit for this review.

title: Anatomy- and physics-based facial animation for craniofacial surgery simulations
author: Gladilin E.; Zachow S.; Deuflhard P.; Hege H.-C.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: A modelling approach for the realistic simulation of facial expressions of emotion in craniofacial surgery planning is presented. The method is different from conventional, non-physical techniques for character animation in computer graphics. A consistent physiological mechanism for facial expressions was assumed, which was the effect of contracting muscles on soft tissues. For the numerical solution of the linear elastic boundary values, the finite element method on tetrahedral grids was used. The approach was validated on a geometrical model of a human head derived from tomographic data. Using this model, individual facial expressions of emotion were estimated by the superpositioning of precomputed single muscle actions. © IFMBE: 2004.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on facial animation for surgery simulation instead of predicting or evaluating how things will look, which doesn't fit what the review is looking for.

title: Acidic tumor microenvironment-activatable fluorescent diagnostic probe for the rapid identification and resection of human tumors via spraying
author: Liu J.; Xu Z.; Meng C.; Wusiman S.; Xie X.; Wang Y.; Xiao F.; Gu C.; Chen J.; Ling C.-C.; Li P.; Yuan Z.; Ling Y.
abstract: The acidic tumor microenvironment (TME) is a hallmark of solid tumors and has been widely exploited for tumor diagnosis and therapy. Herein, we report a novel acidic TME-activatable fluorescent diagnostic probe (named HMR-1) for the rapid identification and resection of human tumors via spraying. HMR-1 is nonfluorescent under physiological pH but emits strong fluorescence in acidic conditions due to the protonation of the hydroxyl group, enabling the selective visualization of tumor tissues with acidic microenvironment. The probe exhibits high sensitivity and specificity for acidic pH, rapid response, and excellent photostability. In vitro and ex vivo experiments demonstrate that HMR-1 can effectively distinguish tumor tissues from normal tissues. Furthermore, in clinical specimens from patients with various solid tumors, HMR-1 spraying allows for rapid and clear visualization of tumor margins, facilitating precise tumor resection. This study provides a promising strategy for the development of acidic TME-activatable fluorescent probes for clinical tumor diagnosis and surgical guidance.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a fluorescent probe for tumor detection rather than on automatic prediction or evaluation of cosmetic results in surgery, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: Establishment of a keratinocyte and fibroblast bank for clinical applications in Japan
author: Nakano T.; Katayama Y.; Sakamoto M.; Shimizu Y.; Inoie M.; Shimizu N.; Yamanaka H.; Tsuge I.; Saito S.; Morimoto N.
abstract: Establishment of a keratinocyte and fibroblast bank for clinical applications in Japan  Abstract: Cell therapy using cultured epidermal autografts (CEA) has been widely applied for the treatment of severe burns and chronic wounds. However, the preparation of CEA requires a long culture period and is limited by the availability of autologous skin tissue. To overcome these limitations, allogeneic keratinocyte and fibroblast banks have been developed in several countries. In Japan, we established a keratinocyte and fibroblast bank for clinical applications to provide ready-to-use allogeneic cells. We collected skin tissues from healthy donors, isolated keratinocytes and fibroblasts, and expanded them under Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) conditions. The cells were cryopreserved and characterized for quality and safety, including sterility, viability, and absence of tumorigenicity. The banked cells demonstrated stable growth and maintained their phenotypic characteristics after thawing. This keratinocyte and fibroblast bank is expected to facilitate the clinical use of allogeneic cell therapy for wound healing in Japan.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on setting up a cell bank for wound healing, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it falls outside the review's topic.

title: Single-port robotic surgery using the EDGE SP1000 surgical system in gynaecology: Initial experience of a single institution
author: Chen Y.; Zheng Y.; Wang P.; Wang Q.; Yang F.; Zhou S.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and safety of single-port robotic surgery using the EDGE SP1000 surgical system in gynaecology. We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 20 patients who underwent single-port robotic gynaecological surgery with the EDGE SP1000 system at a single institution. Surgical outcomes, including operative time, blood loss, complications, and hospital stay, were analyzed. All procedures were completed successfully without conversion to multiport or open surgery. The median operative time was 120 minutes, and median estimated blood loss was 50 mL. No intraoperative complications occurred, and postoperative complications were minimal and manageable. Our initial experience suggests that single-port robotic surgery using the EDGE SP1000 system is a feasible and safe approach in gynaecological surgery, offering the benefits of minimally invasive surgery with potential for reduced scarring and faster recovery. Further studies with larger cohorts and longer follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the safety and feasibility of robotic gynecological surgery but doesn't cover predicting or assessing aesthetic results, so it doesn't match the review's topic.

title: Craniocaudal toggling increases the risk of screw loosening in osteoporotic vertebrae
author: Song F.; Liu Y.; Fu R.; Gao X.; Iqbal K.; Yang D.; Liu Y.; Yang H.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Craniocaudal toggling is a common phenomenon in spinal instrumentation, especially in osteoporotic vertebrae, which may lead to screw loosening and implant failure. This study aimed to investigate the effect of craniocaudal toggling on the risk of pedicle screw loosening in osteoporotic vertebrae using finite element analysis. A validated finite element model of an osteoporotic lumbar vertebra with pedicle screws was developed. Craniocaudal toggling was simulated by applying cyclic vertical displacement to the screw head. The stress distribution, micromotion at the bone-screw interface, and risk of screw loosening were evaluated. Results showed that craniocaudal toggling significantly increased micromotion and stress concentration around the screw threads, indicating a higher risk of screw loosening in osteoporotic vertebrae. These findings suggest that minimizing craniocaudal toggling through surgical technique or implant design modifications may reduce the risk of pedicle screw loosening in patients with osteoporosis.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on screw loosening in bone rather than predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: PreFlap: From Photoacoustic Tomography Images to Vascular Mapping Sheets for Improved Preoperative Flap Evaluation
author: Munisso M.C.; Liu C.; Yamamoto G.; Kosaka T.; Tsuge I.; Saito S.; Morimoto N.
abstract: Preoperative flap evaluation is crucial for successful reconstructive surgery, requiring detailed vascular mapping to ensure flap viability. Photoacoustic tomography (PAT) offers high-resolution, noninvasive imaging of vascular structures, but translating these images into clinically useful maps remains challenging. We present PreFlap, a novel framework that converts PAT images into vascular mapping sheets tailored for preoperative flap assessment. PreFlap integrates advanced image processing and vessel segmentation techniques to extract and visualize vascular networks, providing surgeons with intuitive, detailed maps of flap vasculature. Validation on clinical PAT datasets demonstrates that PreFlap enhances the accuracy and usability of vascular information, potentially improving surgical planning and outcomes. This approach represents a significant step toward integrating PAT into routine preoperative workflows for reconstructive surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on vascular mapping with photoacoustic tomography but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Polydioxanone Membrane for Guided Conjunctival Tissue Reconstruction: An Experimental Model in Rabbits
author: da Gama D.D.; Martines G.; Rigueiro M.; Cruz M.; Schor P.
doi: Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology Inc.
abstract: Purpose: To evaluate the efficacy of polydioxanone (PDO) membrane as a scaffold for guided conjunctival tissue reconstruction in an experimental rabbit model. Methods: A total of 24 rabbits underwent conjunctival defect creation in the right eye, followed by reconstruction using PDO membrane in the experimental group and autologous conjunctival graft in the control group. Clinical evaluations and histological analyses were performed at 1, 2, and 4 weeks postoperatively to assess epithelialization, inflammation, and fibrosis. Results: The PDO membrane group demonstrated complete epithelialization by 2 weeks, comparable to the control group. Histological examination revealed minimal inflammatory response and organized collagen deposition in the PDO group, indicating favorable tissue integration. No significant differences in fibrosis or neovascularization were observed between groups. Conclusions: The PDO membrane serves as an effective scaffold for conjunctival tissue regeneration, promoting rapid epithelialization and minimal inflammation in a rabbit model. Translational Relevance: PDO membrane may offer a promising alternative for conjunctival reconstruction in clinical settings, potentially reducing donor site morbidity and surgical complexity.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Explores tissue reconstruction in rabbits but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s not a fit for this review.

title: Evaluation of a Bioabsorbable Scaffold and Interlocked Nail System for Segmental Bone Defect
author: Khandaker M.; Lane R.; Yeakley S.; Alizereej H.; Nikfarjam S.; Ait Moussa A.; Vaughan M.B.; Haleem A.M.
abstract: Segmental bone defects remain a significant clinical challenge due to the limited ability of bone to regenerate over large gaps. This study evaluates a novel bioabsorbable scaffold combined with an interlocked nail system designed to support bone regeneration in segmental defects. The scaffold, fabricated from a composite of bioabsorbable polymers and osteoconductive materials, was implanted in a critical-sized segmental defect model in vivo. The interlocked nail system provided mechanical stability while allowing for gradual load transfer to the regenerating bone. Outcomes were assessed through radiographic imaging, histological analysis, and biomechanical testing over a 12-week period. Results demonstrated enhanced bone formation within the scaffold and successful integration with host bone, with the interlocked nail maintaining defect stability throughout the healing process. This combined approach shows promise for improving the treatment of segmental bone defects by facilitating bone regeneration and providing necessary mechanical support.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone regeneration with bioabsorbable scaffolds and stabilization but doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's focus.

title: Impacts of video communication on psychological well-being and cosmetic surgery acceptance
author: Chen Y.; Zhou S.
abstract: This study investigates the impacts of video communication on psychological well-being and cosmetic surgery acceptance. With the rise of video-based interactions, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals have become more exposed to their own image, potentially influencing self-perception and attitudes toward cosmetic procedures. The research examines how increased video communication correlates with body image concerns, self-esteem, and the willingness to undergo cosmetic surgery. Findings suggest that frequent video communication can heighten self-scrutiny and dissatisfaction with appearance, thereby increasing acceptance of cosmetic surgery as a means to improve self-image. The study highlights the psychological implications of video communication technologies and their role in shaping attitudes toward cosmetic enhancements.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on psychological effects and opinions about cosmetic surgery instead of predicting or assessing aesthetic results, which falls outside the review’s main topic.

title: Treatment of Medication-Related Osteonecrosis of the Jaw Without and With the Use of Advanced Platelet-Rich Fibrin: A Retrospective Clinical Study
author: Adamska P.; Stasiak M.; Kobusińska N.; Bartmański M.; Zedler A.; Studniarek M.
abstract: Medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ) is a serious complication in patients treated with antiresorptive or antiangiogenic agents. The aim of this retrospective clinical study was to evaluate the efficacy of advanced platelet-rich fibrin (A-PRF) in the treatment of MRONJ. Forty patients with MRONJ were divided into two groups: group A (n = 20) treated with surgical debridement and primary closure, and group B (n = 20) treated with surgical debridement, A-PRF application, and primary closure. The primary outcome was complete mucosal healing without signs of infection or exposed bone at 3 months postoperatively. Secondary outcomes included pain reduction and quality of life improvement. The results showed that group B had a significantly higher rate of complete healing (85%) compared to group A (60%) (p < 0.05). Additionally, patients in group B reported greater pain relief and improved quality of life scores. The use of A-PRF in the surgical management of MRONJ appears to enhance healing outcomes and patient comfort. Further prospective studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on treatment results for a jaw condition without discussing automatic prediction or assessment of looks, which doesn't match the review's focus.

title: Towards inferring positioning of straight cochlear-implant electrode arrays during insertion using real-time impedance sensing
author: Riojas K.E.; Bruns T.L.; Granna J.; Smetak M.R.; Labadie R.F.; Webster R.J., III
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Real-time impedance sensing during cochlear implant (CI) electrode array insertion has the potential to provide valuable information about the position of the electrode array within the cochlea. This study investigates the feasibility of using impedance measurements to infer the positioning of straight CI electrode arrays during insertion. A computational model of the cochlea and electrode array was developed to simulate impedance changes associated with different electrode positions. Experimental validation was performed using a physical cochlear model and a commercial CI electrode array. Results demonstrate that impedance measurements vary systematically with electrode position, enabling differentiation between scala tympani and scala vestibuli placements as well as detection of electrode array translocations. These findings suggest that real-time impedance sensing could be a useful tool for guiding CI electrode insertion and improving surgical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Talks about real-time sensing in cochlear implant surgery, which doesn't connect to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Mechanical fabrication and evaluation of bioresorbable barbed sutures with different barb geometries
author: Nambi Gowri K.; King M.W.
abstract: Barbed sutures have been widely used in clinical applications due to their self-anchoring ability and knotless feature. However, the barbs on current barbed sutures are mostly fabricated by post-processing methods, which are time-consuming and costly. In this study, a mechanical fabrication method was developed to produce bioresorbable barbed sutures with different barb geometries. The barbs were fabricated by a single-step mechanical cutting process on polydioxanone (PDO) monofilament sutures. The effects of barb geometry, including barb length, barb angle, and barb spacing, on the mechanical properties and tissue holding capacity of the barbed sutures were systematically evaluated. The results showed that the mechanical cutting method could produce barbs with precise geometry and good surface quality. The barb geometry significantly influenced the tensile strength, barb pull-out force, and tissue holding capacity of the sutures. Sutures with longer barb length and smaller barb angle exhibited higher tissue holding capacity but reduced tensile strength. The optimized barb geometry achieved a balance between mechanical strength and tissue anchoring ability. This study provides a novel and efficient approach for fabricating bioresorbable barbed sutures with tunable mechanical and functional properties, which could facilitate their clinical translation and application.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses solely on making and testing barbed sutures without covering automatic prediction or assessment of how things look after plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: Heterogeneous pHPMA hydrogel promotes neuronal differentiation of bone marrow derived stromal cells in vitro and in vivo
author: Rybachuk O.; Savytska N.; Pinet I.; Yaminsky Y.; Medvediev V.
abstract: Hydrogels with heterogeneous microenvironments have been demonstrated to regulate cell behaviors and tissue regeneration. However, the effect of heterogeneous hydrogels on neuronal differentiation of bone marrow derived stromal cells (BMSCs) remains unclear. Herein, a heterogeneous poly(N-(2-hydroxypropyl)methacrylamide) (pHPMA) hydrogel was fabricated by combining two pHPMA hydrogels with different stiffnesses. The heterogeneous pHPMA hydrogel exhibited a gradient stiffness from 0.5 to 15 kPa, mimicking the mechanical heterogeneity of native neural tissue. BMSCs cultured on the heterogeneous hydrogel showed enhanced neuronal differentiation compared to those on homogeneous hydrogels, as evidenced by increased expression of neuronal markers βIII-tubulin and MAP2. In vivo implantation of BMSCs-laden heterogeneous hydrogel into a rat spinal cord injury model promoted neuronal differentiation and improved functional recovery. These findings suggest that the heterogeneous pHPMA hydrogel provides a favorable microenvironment for neuronal differentiation of BMSCs and holds potential for neural tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focus lies on hydrogel-based neuronal differentiation and tissue engineering, which doesn't connect with predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Effects of the learning curve on operative time and lymph node harvesting during robotic gastrectomy
author: Staderini F.; Barbato G.; Bottari A.; Russo E.; Fortuna L.; Giudici F.; Coratti F.; Stacchini L.; Indennitate G.; Cianchi F.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of the learning curve on operative time and lymph node harvesting during robotic gastrectomy. We retrospectively reviewed 100 consecutive patients who underwent robotic gastrectomy for gastric cancer. The learning curve was analyzed using the cumulative sum (CUSUM) method based on operative time. Patients were divided into two groups: the early phase (cases 1–40) and the late phase (cases 41–100). We compared operative time, number of harvested lymph nodes, and perioperative outcomes between the two groups. The CUSUM analysis showed a significant reduction in operative time after 40 cases. The mean operative time was significantly shorter in the late phase group compared to the early phase group (210 ± 35 minutes vs. 270 ± 40 minutes, p < 0.001). The number of harvested lymph nodes was significantly higher in the late phase group (35 ± 8 vs. 28 ± 7, p < 0.001). There were no significant differences in perioperative complications between the two groups. In conclusion, the learning curve for robotic gastrectomy affects operative time and lymph node harvesting, with improvements observed after 40 cases. These findings suggest that surgical proficiency in robotic gastrectomy can be achieved with experience, leading to more efficient surgery and improved oncological outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on surgical timing and lymph node harvesting in robotic gastrectomy, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is the main interest here.

title: Long-term in vivo performance of silicone membrane lungs coated with novel methacryloyloxyethyl phosphorylcholine polymers: A pilot study
author: Anraku M.; Yokoi R.; Hara S.; Nobori Y.; Nakao K.; Fukumoto K.; Ono T.; Sato K.; Watanabe F.; Isoyama T.; Oshiyama H.; Ono M.; Nakajima J.; Takai M.
abstract: Abstract  The long-term in vivo performance of silicone membrane lungs coated with novel methacryloyloxyethyl phosphorylcholine (MPC) polymers was evaluated in a pilot study. The MPC polymers were designed to improve the biocompatibility and reduce thrombogenicity of the silicone membrane lungs used in extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). Silicone membrane lungs coated with MPC polymers were implanted in an animal model and monitored over an extended period. The study assessed gas exchange efficiency, hemocompatibility, and the extent of thrombus formation on the membrane surface. Results demonstrated that the MPC-coated silicone membrane lungs maintained stable gas exchange performance and exhibited significantly reduced thrombus formation compared to uncoated controls. These findings suggest that MPC polymer coatings may enhance the long-term functionality and safety of silicone membrane lungs in clinical ECMO applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on silicone membrane lungs in ECMO, which doesn't relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Short-term outcomes of robot-assisted versus thoracoscopic-assisted Mckeown esophagectomy
author: Meng Y.-Q.; Li B.; Wang C.; Jiang P.; Song T.-N.; Feng H.-M.; Lin J.-P.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to compare the short-term outcomes of robot-assisted McKeown esophagectomy (RAME) and thoracoscopic-assisted McKeown esophagectomy (TAME) for esophageal cancer. A total of 60 patients who underwent minimally invasive McKeown esophagectomy were retrospectively analyzed, including 30 patients in the RAME group and 30 patients in the TAME group. Perioperative outcomes, including operative time, blood loss, number of lymph nodes harvested, postoperative complications, and length of hospital stay, were compared between the two groups. The results showed that the RAME group had a longer operative time but less intraoperative blood loss compared to the TAME group. The number of lymph nodes harvested was significantly higher in the RAME group. Postoperative complication rates and length of hospital stay were similar between the two groups. The study concluded that robot-assisted McKeown esophagectomy is a safe and feasible procedure with comparable short-term outcomes to thoracoscopic-assisted McKeown esophagectomy, offering advantages in lymph node dissection and reduced blood loss.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on comparing surgical methods and immediate results, with no mention of predicting or assessing aesthetic outcomes, so it doesn’t align with the review’s goals.

title: Antibody Profiling and In Silico Functional Analysis of Differentially Reactive Antibody Signatures of Glioblastomas and Meningiomas
author: Milchram L.; Kulovics R.; Sonntagbauer M.; Schönthaler S.; Vierlinger K.; Dorfer C.; Cameron C.; Saydam O.; Weinhäusel A.
abstract: Glioblastomas (GBM) and meningiomas (MEN) are the most common primary brain tumors in adults. The identification of tumor-specific antibody signatures may provide new insights into tumor biology and aid in the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. In this study, we performed antibody profiling using high-density peptide microarrays to identify differentially reactive antibody signatures in sera from patients with GBM and MEN compared to healthy controls. We identified distinct antibody reactivity patterns that differentiate GBM and MEN patients from controls and from each other. In silico functional analysis of the differentially reactive peptides revealed enrichment in pathways related to tumor progression, immune response, and cell signaling. Our findings suggest that antibody profiling combined with computational analysis can uncover tumor-specific immune signatures, offering potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for brain tumors.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks into antibody profiling and brain tumor biology without touching on automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: In vitro and in vivo evaluation of a modified porcine acellular dermal matrix for soft tissue augmentation
author: Zhang B.; Ma L.; Tang L.S.; Song D.W.; Guo J.; Zhang F.; Xu X.
abstract: Background: Porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) is widely used in soft tissue augmentation. However, its clinical application is limited by poor mechanical properties and rapid degradation. This study aimed to develop a modified PADM (mPADM) with improved mechanical strength and degradation resistance and to evaluate its biocompatibility and efficacy in vitro and in vivo. Methods: PADM was cross-linked using a novel chemical agent to produce mPADM. Mechanical properties were assessed by tensile testing. In vitro degradation was evaluated by collagenase digestion. Biocompatibility was tested using human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) for cell viability and proliferation. In vivo, mPADM and PADM were implanted subcutaneously in rats for 12 weeks to assess tissue integration, inflammatory response, and volume maintenance. Results: mPADM exhibited significantly higher tensile strength and lower degradation rate compared to PADM (p < 0.05). HGFs cultured on mPADM showed enhanced viability and proliferation. In vivo, mPADM demonstrated better volume maintenance and reduced inflammatory infiltration than PADM. Histological analysis revealed improved collagen deposition and neovascularization in mPADM implants. Conclusion: The modified PADM showed enhanced mechanical properties, biocompatibility, and in vivo performance, indicating its potential as a superior scaffold for soft tissue augmentation.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract centers on creating and testing a biomaterial for tissue augmentation but doesn’t touch on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, so it doesn’t match the review’s focus.

title: Hybrid registration of the fibula for electromagnetically navigated osteotomies in mandibular reconstructive surgery: a phantom study
author: Aukema L.M.N.; de Geer A.F.; van Alphen M.J.A.; Schreuder W.H.; van Veen R.L.P.; Ruers T.J.M.; Siepel F.J.; Karakullukcu M.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Electromagnetic (EM) navigation is a promising technique for guiding osteotomies in mandibular reconstructive surgery. However, the registration of the fibula, which is the donor bone, remains challenging due to its complex shape and limited anatomical landmarks. This study proposes a hybrid registration method combining surface and landmark-based approaches to improve the accuracy and robustness of fibula registration for EM-navigated osteotomies. Methods A phantom model of the fibula was used to simulate the registration process. The hybrid method involved initial landmark-based registration using fiducial markers followed by surface-based refinement using iterative closest point (ICP) algorithm. The accuracy of the hybrid registration was compared to landmark-only and surface-only methods by measuring the target registration error (TRE) at predefined points. Results The hybrid registration method achieved a significantly lower mean TRE (1.2 ± 0.3 mm) compared to landmark-only (2.5 ± 0.7 mm) and surface-only (1.8 ± 0.5 mm) methods (p < 0.01). The hybrid approach also demonstrated improved robustness against noise and partial surface data. Conclusion The proposed hybrid registration method enhances the accuracy and reliability of fibula registration for EM-navigated mandibular reconstructive surgery. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes by enabling precise osteotomies and better alignment of the fibula graft. Further studies on clinical data are warranted to validate these findings.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on technical tweaks in fibula registration but doesn't cover automatic prediction or how the results look in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: A Fixed Reconstruction and Immediate Rehabilitation of Fully Edentulous Arch Using the All-on-Four Concept: Case Series
author: Choudhary A.; Vashist S.; Chopra M.; Sharma A.
journal: Journal of Long-Term Effects of Medical Implants
abstract: The All-on-Four concept is a treatment modality for the rehabilitation of completely edentulous arches using four implants to support a fixed prosthesis. This case series presents the clinical outcomes of patients treated with the All-on-Four protocol, focusing on immediate loading and rehabilitation. The study highlights the surgical and prosthetic procedures, emphasizing the advantages of this approach, including reduced treatment time, cost-effectiveness, and improved patient satisfaction. The results demonstrate successful osseointegration and functional restoration, supporting the All-on-Four concept as a viable option for full-arch rehabilitation in edentulous patients.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on dental implant rehab and function, but doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which is what the review is about.

title: Systematic Analysis of PTFE Monocusp Leaflet Design in a Patient-Based 3D in-Vitro Model of Tetralogy of Fallot
author: Zhang X.; Kizilski S.B.; Recco D.P.; Chaillo Lizarraga M.D.; Kneier N.E.; Schulz N.E.; Baird C.W.; Hammer P.E.; Hoganson D.M.
abstract: Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is a common long-term complication after repair of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Implantation of a monocusp valve during the initial repair has been proposed to reduce PR and improve right ventricular function. However, the optimal design of the monocusp leaflet remains unclear. This study aimed to systematically analyze the hemodynamic performance of different polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) monocusp leaflet designs in a patient-based 3D in-vitro model of TOF. A patient-specific right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) model was 3D printed and integrated into a pulsatile flow loop simulating physiological conditions. Various PTFE monocusp leaflets differing in size, shape, and thickness were fabricated and tested. Hemodynamic parameters including regurgitant fraction, transvalvular pressure gradient, and effective orifice area were measured. Results demonstrated that leaflet design significantly influenced valve competence and flow dynamics. Larger and thicker leaflets reduced PR but increased transvalvular gradients, while smaller and thinner leaflets had the opposite effect. An optimal balance was identified that minimized PR without causing significant obstruction. This study provides valuable insights into PTFE monocusp design optimization, potentially guiding surgical strategies to improve outcomes in TOF repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at blood flow in heart valve repairs, which doesn’t connect to predicting or evaluating how surgeries look in plastic or cancer-related procedures.

title: Assessment of Concentration KRT6 Proteins in Tumor and Matching Surgical Margin from Patients with Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma
author: Nałęcz D.; Świętek A.; Hudy D.; Wiczkowski K.; Złotopolska Z.; Strzelczyk J.K.
abstract: Cytokeratins (KRTs) are intermediate filament proteins that play a crucial role in the structural integrity of epithelial cells. Among them, KRT6 isoforms have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various cancers, including head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). This study aimed to assess the concentration of KRT6 proteins in tumor tissues and matching surgical margins from patients with HNSCC. Using quantitative proteomic analysis, we measured KRT6 levels in paired samples and evaluated their potential as biomarkers for tumor presence and margin status. Our results demonstrated a significant elevation of KRT6 proteins in tumor tissues compared to surgical margins, suggesting their involvement in tumor biology and potential utility in surgical margin assessment.
