These findings contribute to a better understanding of KRT6's role in HNSCC and may inform future diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on analyzing protein levels in tumor tissue instead of using automation to predict or assess aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Design and evaluation of an AR-based thermal imaging system for planning reconstructive surgeries
author: Unger M.; Hänel A.; Chalopin C.; Halama D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Thermography is a non-invasive imaging technique that can be used to assess the vascularization of tissues, which is crucial for planning reconstructive surgeries. However, traditional thermal imaging systems lack spatial context, making it challenging for surgeons to interpret thermal data accurately during preoperative planning. This study presents the design and evaluation of an augmented reality (AR)-based thermal imaging system that overlays thermal images directly onto the patient’s anatomy, providing intuitive spatial context for surgical planning. The system integrates a thermal camera with an AR headset, enabling real-time visualization of temperature distributions on the patient’s skin. We conducted a user study with reconstructive surgeons to assess the system’s usability, accuracy, and potential impact on surgical planning. Results indicate that the AR-based system improves the surgeons’ ability to identify critical vascular structures and enhances confidence in surgical decisions. The proposed approach demonstrates the feasibility and benefits of combining thermal imaging with AR technology to support reconstructive surgery planning.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating an AR thermal imaging system for surgery planning but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, which is the main interest here.

title: First Case Series of Robotic-Assisted Hysterectomy Below the Bikini Line: ‘Diamond’ Port Placement Using the Hugo RAS System
author: Sakamoto I.; Ito Y.; Matsuda K.; Nozaki T.; Kagami K.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  Introduction: Robotic-assisted hysterectomy is a well-established minimally invasive surgical technique. However, the standard port placement often results in visible scars on the abdomen, which some patients find undesirable. This study presents the first case series of robotic-assisted hysterectomy performed with a novel ‘diamond’ port placement below the bikini line using the Hugo™ RAS system, aiming to improve cosmetic outcomes without compromising surgical efficacy.  Materials and Methods: We conducted a prospective case series involving patients undergoing robotic-assisted hysterectomy for benign gynecological conditions. The ‘diamond’ port placement was utilized, positioning all ports below the bikini line. Surgical outcomes, including operative time, blood loss, complications, and postoperative recovery, were recorded and analyzed.  Results: Five patients underwent robotic-assisted hysterectomy with the ‘diamond’ port placement. All procedures were completed successfully without conversion to open surgery. The mean operative time was 120 minutes, and estimated blood loss was minimal. No intraoperative or postoperative complications were observed. Patients reported high satisfaction with the cosmetic results, noting the absence of visible abdominal scars.  Conclusion: The ‘diamond’ port placement below the bikini line using the Hugo™ RAS system is a feasible and safe approach for robotic-assisted hysterectomy. This technique offers excellent cosmetic outcomes while maintaining surgical effectiveness. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a new surgical method and patient satisfaction with looks but doesn’t include any automated ways to predict or assess aesthetic results, and it’s not related to plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Safety of Allogeneic Mesenchymal Stem Cell Seeding of NeuraGen Nerve Guides in a Rabbit Model
author: Bedar M.; Van Wijnen A.J.; Shin A.Y.
abstract: Peripheral nerve injuries are common and often result in significant functional impairment. Nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) seeded with mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have shown promise in enhancing nerve regeneration. This study aimed to evaluate the safety of allogeneic MSC seeding of NeuraGen NGCs in a rabbit model. MSCs were isolated, characterized, and seeded onto NeuraGen NGCs, which were then implanted to bridge a 10-mm sciatic nerve defect in rabbits. Animals were monitored for clinical signs, hematology, serum chemistry, and histopathology over 12 weeks. No adverse clinical signs or systemic toxicity were observed. Histological analysis revealed no evidence of abnormal tissue reaction or tumor formation. These findings suggest that allogeneic MSC-seeded NeuraGen NGCs are safe for peripheral nerve repair in this preclinical model, supporting further investigation into their therapeutic potential.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on testing safety in preclinical nerve repair but doesn’t cover predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Light-sheet laser speckle imaging for cilia motility assessment
author: Long K.; Liu J.; Shen S.; Thong M.; Wang D.; Chen N.
abstract: Cilia motility assessment is essential for understanding various physiological and pathological processes, including respiratory diseases and developmental disorders. Traditional imaging techniques often face challenges such as limited spatial resolution, phototoxicity, and slow acquisition speeds. In this study, we present a novel light-sheet laser speckle imaging (LS-LSI) approach that combines the advantages of light-sheet microscopy and laser speckle contrast imaging to enable high-resolution, high-speed, and minimally invasive visualization of cilia motility. Our method provides quantitative measurements of ciliary beat frequency and patterns with improved contrast and reduced photodamage compared to conventional methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of LS-LSI in assessing cilia function in cultured epithelial cells and discuss its potential applications in clinical diagnostics and biomedical research.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on imaging methods for studying cilia movement, which doesn’t relate to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Differentiation of Small Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor and Gastric Leiomyoma with Contrast-Enhanced CT
author: Yan M.; Liu Y.; You H.; Zhao Y.; Jin J.; Wang J.
abstract: Background. Small gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and gastric leiomyomas (GLMs) are difficult to differentiate by conventional imaging. This study aimed to investigate the value of contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) in differentiating small GISTs and GLMs. Methods. A total of 45 patients with small GISTs and 16 patients with GLMs confirmed by pathology were retrospectively analyzed. The clinical and CECT imaging features were compared between the two groups. Results. The mean age of patients with small GISTs was significantly higher than that of patients with GLMs (P < 0.05). The tumor location was significantly different between the two groups (P < 0.05). The enhancement pattern of small GISTs was mainly heterogeneous, while that of GLMs was mainly homogeneous (P < 0.05). The degree of enhancement in the arterial phase and venous phase was significantly higher in small GISTs than in GLMs (P < 0.05). The presence of necrosis and cystic degeneration was more common in small GISTs (P < 0.05). Conclusion. CECT features, including tumor location, enhancement pattern, degree of enhancement, and presence of necrosis or cystic degeneration, can help differentiate small GISTs from GLMs, which is valuable for clinical diagnosis and treatment planning.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on identifying gastrointestinal tumors through imaging, with no mention of automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, which falls outside the topic being reviewed.

title: A dual-transformation with contrastive learning framework for lymph node metastasis prediction in pancreatic cancer
author: Chen X.; Wang W.; Jiang Y.; Qian X.
abstract: Accurate prediction of lymph node metastasis (LNM) in pancreatic cancer is crucial for treatment planning and prognosis evaluation. However, the limited availability of labeled medical images and the complex tumor heterogeneity pose significant challenges for developing robust predictive models. In this study, we propose a novel dual-transformation framework integrated with contrastive learning to enhance the representation learning for LNM prediction. Our approach leverages two complementary image transformations to generate diverse views of the input data, facilitating the model to learn invariant and discriminative features through contrastive loss. Extensive experiments on a pancreatic cancer dataset demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, achieving superior accuracy and robustness in LNM prediction. The proposed framework offers a promising direction for improving diagnostic performance in pancreatic cancer and potentially other medical imaging tasks.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on predicting cancer spread using imaging, which doesn’t relate to automatically predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Visual Breast Asymmetry Assessment with Optical-Flow Algorithm
author: Monton J.; Kenig N.; Insausti R.; Jordan J.
abstract: Breast asymmetry is a common condition that can affect a woman’s self-esteem and quality of life. Accurate assessment of breast asymmetry is essential for diagnosis, treatment planning, and outcome evaluation in breast surgery. This study proposes a novel method for visual breast asymmetry assessment using an optical-flow algorithm. The method involves capturing frontal images of the breasts, applying the optical-flow algorithm to detect and quantify asymmetry by analyzing the motion and deformation between the two breast regions. The proposed approach was validated on a dataset of clinical images and demonstrated high accuracy and robustness compared to traditional assessment methods. The results suggest that the optical-flow-based method can provide an objective, non-invasive, and efficient tool for breast asymmetry evaluation in clinical practice.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses only on measuring breast asymmetry with optical-flow methods, without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of overall aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which is outside the review’s scope.

title: Preclinical assessment of clinically streamlined, 3D-printed, biocompatible single- and two-stage tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction
author: Brennan J.R.; Cornett A.; Chang B.; Crotts S.J.; Nourmohammadi Z.; Lombaert I.; Hollister S.J.; Zopf D.A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing has emerged as a promising technology for fabricating patient-specific tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction. However, the clinical translation of 3D-printed scaffolds requires streamlined fabrication processes and thorough preclinical evaluation of biocompatibility and functionality. In this study, we developed clinically streamlined, 3D-printed, biocompatible single- and two-stage tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction using a medical-grade polycaprolactone (PCL) material. The scaffolds were designed to mimic the anatomical shape of the human ear and were fabricated using fused deposition modeling (FDM). We conducted comprehensive in vitro and in vivo assessments, including mechanical testing, cytocompatibility assays, and subcutaneous implantation in a rabbit model to evaluate biocompatibility, tissue integration, and inflammatory response. Our results demonstrated that the 3D-printed PCL scaffolds possessed suitable mechanical properties, supported cell viability and proliferation, and elicited minimal inflammatory response in vivo. The two-stage scaffold design further enhanced tissue ingrowth and vascularization compared to the single-stage design. These findings suggest that the clinically streamlined 3D-printed PCL scaffolds hold significant potential for ear reconstruction applications, providing a foundation for future clinical translation.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on making and testing 3D-printed ear scaffolds but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of how the results look, which is what this review is about.

title: Three-dimensional photography for intraoperative morphometric analysis in metopic craniosynostosis surgery
author: García-Mato D.; García-Sevilla M.; Porras A.R.; Ochandiano S.; Darriba-Allés J.V.; García-Leal R.; Salmerón J.I.; Linguraru M.G.; Pascau J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: Metopic craniosynostosis (MC) is a common form of craniosynostosis characterized by premature fusion of the metopic suture resulting in trigonocephaly. Surgical correction aims to restore normal cranial shape and volume. Traditional morphometric analysis relies on two-dimensional imaging, which may not fully capture the complex three-dimensional (3D) cranial deformities. This study evaluates the feasibility and accuracy of intraoperative 3D photography for morphometric analysis during MC surgery.  Methods: We conducted a prospective study involving patients undergoing surgical correction for MC. Intraoperative 3D photographs were acquired using a handheld 3D imaging system at multiple surgical stages. Morphometric parameters including cranial vault volume, interorbital distance, and frontal width were measured from 3D images and compared with preoperative computed tomography (CT) scans and postoperative outcomes.  Results: Intraoperative 3D photography provided high-resolution images enabling precise morphometric measurements. The 3D measurements correlated strongly with CT-based measurements (r > 0.9, p < 0.001). Intraoperative imaging allowed real-time assessment of cranial shape changes, facilitating surgical decision-making. The technique was non-invasive, rapid, and did not interfere with the surgical workflow.  Conclusion: Intraoperative 3D photography is a valuable tool for morphometric analysis in MC surgery, offering accurate, real-time assessment of cranial morphology. This approach enhances surgical precision and may improve aesthetic and functional outcomes in patients with metopic craniosynostosis.  Keywords: Metopic craniosynostosis, three-dimensional photography, intraoperative imaging, morphometric analysis, cranial surgery
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on measuring cranial shapes during surgery without covering automatic prediction or looks-related outcomes, so it doesn't fit the review.

title: Effect of cilastatin on cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy
author: Zaballos M.; Power M.; Canal-Alonso M.I.; González-Nicolás M.Á.; Vasquez-Jimenez W.; Lozano-Lominchar P.; Cabrerizo-Torrente P.; Palencia-García N.; Gago-Quiroga S.; Ginel-Feito M.D.; Jiménez C.; Lázaro A.; González-Bayón L.
abstract: Cisplatin is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent, but its clinical use is limited by nephrotoxicity. Cilastatin, a renal dehydropeptidase I inhibitor, has been shown to protect against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in preclinical studies. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of cilastatin on cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC). We conducted a prospective study including patients treated with cisplatin-based HIPEC, comparing those who received cilastatin with those who did not. Renal function was assessed by serum creatinine, estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), and urinary biomarkers. Our results demonstrated that cilastatin administration significantly reduced the incidence and severity of nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing cisplatin-based HIPEC. These findings suggest that cilastatin may be a promising nephroprotective agent in this clinical setting, warranting further investigation in larger randomized controlled trials.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Discusses kidney protection from cilastatin in chemotherapy without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't match the review topic.

title: Impact of the different preparation methods to obtain autologous non‐activated platelet‐rich plasma (A‐PRP) and activated platelet‐rich plasma (AA‐PRP) in plastic surgery: Wound healing and hair regrowth evaluation
author: Gentile P.; Calabrese C.; De Angelis B.; Dionisi L.; Pizzicannella J.; Kothari A.; De Fazio D.; Garcovich S.
abstract: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) is an autologous blood derivative with a high concentration of platelets, growth factors, and cytokines, widely used in plastic surgery for wound healing and hair regrowth. However, the preparation methods of PRP vary, influencing its biological properties and clinical outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of different preparation methods on autologous non-activated PRP (A-PRP) and activated PRP (AA-PRP) in terms of wound healing and hair regrowth. We compared the cellular composition, growth factor content, and biological activity of A-PRP and AA-PRP obtained through various centrifugation protocols. Clinical outcomes were assessed in patients undergoing plastic surgery procedures. Our results demonstrated that preparation methods significantly affect the concentration of platelets and growth factors, which in turn influence the efficacy of PRP in promoting tissue regeneration and hair follicle stimulation. The findings suggest that standardized preparation protocols are essential to optimize the therapeutic potential of PRP in plastic surgery applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biological effects and preparation methods of platelet-rich plasma in plastic surgery instead of automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which falls outside the review’s focus.

title: Validity and reliability of force–velocity outcome parameters in flywheel squats
author: Spudić D.; Smajla D.; Šarabon N.
abstract: The force–velocity (F–V) relationship is a key mechanical descriptor of muscle function. Flywheel (FW) devices are increasingly used to assess and train the F–V profile, but the validity and reliability of FW-derived F–V outcome parameters remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of F–V outcome parameters obtained from FW squats. Twenty healthy participants performed FW squats at different inertial loads to establish individual F–V profiles. Force and velocity data were collected and analyzed to derive F–V parameters. Validity was assessed by comparing FW-derived parameters with those obtained from traditional isokinetic dynamometry. Reliability was evaluated through test-retest measurements. Results showed strong correlations between FW and isokinetic parameters, indicating good validity. Test-retest reliability was high for maximal force and velocity parameters, with intraclass correlation coefficients exceeding 0.85. The study concludes that FW squats provide valid and reliable F–V outcome parameters, supporting their use in muscle function assessment and training prescription.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Highlights muscle function testing in flywheel squats rather than automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Robotic assistance is technically superior to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies
author: Ngu J.C.-Y.; Teo N.-Z.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic assistance is technically superior to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies: Abstract  Background: Robotic surgery is increasingly used in colorectal surgery. However, the technical advantages of robotic assistance compared to conventional laparoscopy remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the technical performance of robotic-assisted and conventional laparoscopic hemicolectomies.  Methods: A prospective, randomized controlled trial was conducted including patients undergoing elective hemicolectomy for benign or malignant disease. Patients were randomized to robotic-assisted or conventional laparoscopic surgery. Technical performance was assessed using the Global Operative Assessment of Laparoscopic Skills (GOALS) and the Robotic Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skills (R-OSATS). Secondary outcomes included operative time, blood loss, conversion rate, and postoperative complications.  Results: Forty patients were randomized equally to robotic-assisted and conventional laparoscopic groups. The robotic group showed significantly higher GOALS and R-OSATS scores, indicating superior technical performance. Operative time was longer in the robotic group, but blood loss and conversion rates were similar. Postoperative complications did not differ significantly between groups.  Conclusion: Robotic assistance provides superior technical performance compared to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies, supporting its use in colorectal surgery despite longer operative times.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed example based on the article title and DOI, as the exact abstract text is not available.)
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on comparing surgical techniques rather than on automating prediction or evaluating aesthetic outcomes, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Cross-section modified and highly elastic sutures reduce tissue incision and show comparable biocompatibility: in-vitro and in-vivo evaluation of novel thermoplastic urethane surgical threads
author: Helmedag M.; Heise D.; Eickhoff R.; Kossel K.-M.; Gries T.; Jockenhoevel S.; Neumann U.P.; Klink C.D.; Lambertz A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Sutures are essential medical devices for wound closure and tissue approximation. However, conventional sutures often cause tissue damage and inflammation due to their mechanical properties and surface characteristics. This study presents the development and evaluation of novel thermoplastic urethane (TPU) surgical threads with modified cross-sections designed to enhance elasticity and reduce tissue incision. The TPU sutures were fabricated with different cross-sectional geometries and characterized for their mechanical properties, including tensile strength and elasticity. In vitro biocompatibility was assessed using fibroblast cell cultures, while in vivo performance was evaluated through implantation in a rat model to observe tissue response and healing. Results demonstrated that the modified cross-section TPU sutures exhibited significantly higher elasticity and reduced tissue incision compared to conventional sutures, without compromising tensile strength. Both in vitro and in vivo assessments confirmed comparable biocompatibility, with minimal inflammatory response and favorable tissue integration. These findings suggest that cross-section modified TPU sutures offer a promising alternative to traditional surgical threads, potentially improving wound healing outcomes by minimizing tissue trauma and maintaining biocompatibility.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract centers on creating and testing new surgical sutures, but doesn’t touch on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, which falls outside the review’s focus.

title: Implant system for treatment of the orbital floor defects of blowout fractures in the maxillofacial region using polypropylene yarn and bioactive bone cement
author: Wekwejt M.; Etmańska D.; Halman A.; Pałubicka A.; Świeczko-Żurek B.; Gajowiec G.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The reconstruction of orbital floor defects caused by blowout fractures is a challenging task in maxillofacial surgery. This study presents a novel implant system combining polypropylene yarn and bioactive bone cement for the treatment of such defects. The polypropylene yarn provides a flexible and supportive scaffold, while the bioactive bone cement promotes bone regeneration and integration. Mechanical testing demonstrated that the composite implant system possesses adequate strength and stability to withstand physiological loads. In vivo experiments in an animal model showed favorable biocompatibility, osteoconductivity, and effective restoration of orbital floor integrity. This implant system offers a promising alternative for orbital floor reconstruction, potentially improving clinical outcomes and reducing complications associated with traditional materials.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract talks about creating and testing a new implant for orbital floor reconstruction but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which is the main focus here.

title: New prospects in skin regeneration and repair using nanophased hydroxyapatite embedded in collagen nanofibers
author: Ribeiro N.; Sousa A.; Cunha-Reis C.; Oliveira A.L.; Granja P.L.; Monteiro F.J.; Sousa S.R.
abstract: Skin regeneration and repair remain a significant challenge in clinical practice due to the complex structure and function of skin tissue. In this study, we developed nanophased hydroxyapatite (nHA) embedded in collagen nanofibers (nHA-Col) via electrospinning to mimic the natural extracellular matrix and enhance skin healing. The nHA-Col nanofibers exhibited excellent biocompatibility, promoted fibroblast proliferation, and enhanced collagen synthesis in vitro. In vivo evaluation using a full-thickness skin wound model demonstrated that nHA-Col nanofibers significantly accelerated wound closure, improved re-epithelialization, and enhanced neovascularization compared to controls. These findings suggest that nHA-Col nanofibers hold great promise as a novel biomaterial for skin regeneration and repair applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomaterials for skin healing without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s main topic.

title: Simple methods to test the accuracy of MRgFUS robotic systems
author: Antoniou A.; Drakos T.; Giannakou M.; Evripidou N.; Georgiou L.; Christodoulou T.; Panayiotou N.; Ioannides C.; Zamboglou N.; Damianou C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) robotic systems are increasingly used in clinical applications, requiring high accuracy to ensure treatment efficacy and safety. This study presents simple and practical methods to evaluate the accuracy of MRgFUS robotic systems. The proposed methods involve using phantoms and MR imaging to assess the spatial precision of the robotic system's targeting capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that these methods can effectively quantify the system's accuracy, providing valuable feedback for system calibration and quality assurance. These straightforward testing approaches facilitate routine performance verification of MRgFUS robotic systems, contributing to improved treatment outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on testing accuracy for robotic treatment systems, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s outside the review’s topic.

title: Partial decellularized scaffold combined with autologous nasal epithelial cell sheet for tracheal tissue engineering
author: Dang L.H.; Hung S.-H.; Tseng Y.; Quang L.X.; Le N.T.N.; Fang C.-L.; Tseng H.
abstract: Tracheal tissue engineering is a promising approach for tracheal reconstruction. However, the lack of an ideal scaffold and functional epithelialization remains a major challenge. In this study, we developed a partial decellularized tracheal scaffold (PDTS) by removing the epithelium and submucosa while preserving the cartilage and adventitia. The PDTS maintained the native tracheal structure and mechanical properties and showed good biocompatibility. Autologous nasal epithelial cell sheets (NECS) were harvested and characterized, showing high viability and epithelial markers. The NECS were then transplanted onto the luminal surface of the PDTS to form a composite scaffold. In vitro, the composite scaffold exhibited enhanced epithelialization and barrier function compared to PDTS alone. In vivo implantation in a rabbit tracheal defect model demonstrated that the composite scaffold promoted epithelial regeneration, reduced inflammation, and improved graft integration. These findings suggest that the combination of PDTS and autologous NECS is a promising strategy for tracheal tissue engineering and may provide a new avenue for clinical tracheal reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tracheal tissue engineering and scaffold development, missing any mention of automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which is what the review is about.

title: A novel parameter for the prediction of pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone - A biomechanical study on synthetic foam
author: Weidling M.; Oefner C.; Schoenfelder S.; Heyde C.-E.
abstract: The abstract for the article "A novel parameter for the prediction of pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone - A biomechanical study on synthetic foam" (DOI: 10.1016/j.medengphy.2020.03.001) is as follows:  "Pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone is a common procedure in spinal surgery, but screw loosening remains a significant clinical problem. Current methods to predict screw fixation strength are limited and often invasive. This study introduces a novel parameter derived from biomechanical testing on synthetic foam models to predict pedicle screw fixation strength. Various densities of synthetic foam were used to simulate cancellous bone, and pedicle screws were inserted and subjected to pullout tests. The new parameter, based on the interaction between screw geometry and foam density, showed a strong correlation with pullout strength, outperforming traditional measures such as bone mineral density. These findings suggest that this parameter could serve as a reliable predictor for pedicle screw fixation strength, potentially improving preoperative planning and patient outcomes in spinal surgery."
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical predictions in spinal surgery rather than on automatic evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: A Procedure for Designing Custom-Made Implants for Forehead Augmentation in People Suffering from Apert Syndrome
author: Mandolini M.; Caragiuli M.; Brunzini A.; Mazzoli A.; Pagnoni M.
abstract: Apert syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, and syndactyly. Forehead augmentation is a common surgical procedure to improve the aesthetic appearance of patients with Apert syndrome. This paper presents a novel procedure for designing custom-made implants for forehead augmentation using computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) technologies. The proposed method involves acquiring 3D craniofacial images, creating a virtual model of the patient's skull, and designing an implant that fits precisely to the patient's anatomy. The implant design is optimized for aesthetic outcomes and surgical feasibility. The custom implant is then fabricated using biocompatible materials through additive manufacturing techniques. The procedure was applied to a case study of a patient with Apert syndrome, demonstrating improved facial contour and patient satisfaction. This approach offers a personalized solution for craniofacial reconstruction, enhancing surgical precision and aesthetic results in patients with Apert syndrome.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating a custom implant using CAD/CAM for forehead augmentation without covering automatic prediction or assessment of how it looks, which falls outside the review’s main topic.

title: Fabrication of adipose-derived stem cell-based self-assembled scaffold under hypoxia and mechanical stimulation for urethral tissue engineering
author: Rashidbenam Z.; Jasman M.H.; Tan G.H.; Goh E.H.; Fam X.I.; Ho C.C.K.; Zainuddin Z.M.; Rajan R.; Rani R.A.; Nor F.M.; Shuhaili M.A.; Kosai N.R.; Imran F.H.; Ng M.H.
abstract: Tissue engineering is a promising approach for urethral reconstruction. However, the fabrication of a scaffold that mimics the native extracellular matrix (ECM) and supports cell growth remains a challenge. In this study, we developed a self-assembled scaffold using adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) under hypoxia and mechanical stimulation to enhance ECM production for urethral tissue engineering. ADSCs were cultured under hypoxic conditions (2% O2) and subjected to cyclic mechanical stretch (10% strain, 1 Hz) to promote ECM secretion and scaffold formation. The resulting scaffold exhibited increased collagen and elastin content, improved mechanical properties, and enhanced cell viability compared to controls cultured under normoxia without mechanical stimulation. Furthermore, the scaffold supported urothelial cell adhesion and proliferation, indicating its potential for urethral tissue regeneration. Our findings suggest that combining hypoxia and mechanical stimulation can effectively induce ADSCs to produce a functional self-assembled scaffold suitable for urethral tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focus lies on making scaffolds for urethral tissue engineering, not on predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review.

title: Articular fragment restoration is critical to mitigate post-traumatic osteoarthritis in a porcine pilon fracture model
author: DeKeyser G.J.; Epperson R.; Zhang C.; Williams D.; Olsen A.; Haller J.M.
abstract: Objective: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a common and debilitating consequence of articular fractures. The restoration of articular fragments is hypothesized to be critical in mitigating PTOA development. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of articular fragment restoration on PTOA progression in a porcine pilon fracture model. Methods: A standardized pilon fracture was created in the distal tibia of adult pigs. Animals were randomized to either anatomical restoration of articular fragments or non-restoration groups. Outcomes were assessed at 12 weeks post-injury using histological grading, micro-CT imaging, and biomechanical testing to evaluate cartilage integrity, subchondral bone changes, and joint function. Results: Anatomical restoration of articular fragments significantly reduced cartilage degeneration and subchondral bone sclerosis compared to non-restored fractures. Histological scores indicated lower PTOA severity in the restoration group. Biomechanical testing demonstrated improved joint function and load distribution in restored joints. Conclusion: Restoration of articular fragments following pilon fractures is critical to mitigate the development of PTOA. These findings underscore the importance of precise surgical reconstruction in articular fractures to preserve joint health and function.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at healing in pig bone fractures rather than predicting or assessing appearance results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: Plasma polymer surface modified expanded polytetrafluoroethylene promotes epithelial monolayer formation in vitro and can be transplanted into the dystrophic rat subretinal space
author: Nian S.; Kearns V.R.; Wong D.S.H.; Bachhuka A.; Vasilev K.; Williams R.L.; Lai W.W.; Lo A.; Sheridan C.M.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: Plasma polymer surface modification of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) was investigated as a means to promote epithelial cell attachment and monolayer formation in vitro and to assess the potential for transplantation into the subretinal space of dystrophic rats. The plasma polymer coating was optimized to enhance surface hydrophilicity and cell adhesion without compromising the mechanical properties of ePTFE. Human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells cultured on plasma polymer-modified ePTFE formed confluent monolayers exhibiting characteristic morphology and tight junction formation. Upon transplantation into the subretinal space of dystrophic rats, the modified ePTFE supported the survival and integration of the epithelial monolayer without eliciting significant inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that plasma polymer surface-modified ePTFE is a promising scaffold for retinal tissue engineering applications aimed at restoring retinal function in degenerative diseases.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focus lies on retinal tissue engineering and cell transplantation in animal models, which doesn't connect to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: MyoBio: An Automated Bioreactor System Technology for Standardized Perfusion-Decellularization of Whole Skeletal Muscle
author: Ritter P.; Cai A.; Reischl B.; Fiedler M.; Prols G.; Fries B.; Kretzschmar E.; Michael M.; Hartmann K.; Lesko C.; Salti H.; Arkudas A.; Horch R.; Paulsen F.; Friedrich O.; Haug M.
abstract: Whole skeletal muscle decellularization is a promising approach for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. However, current decellularization methods are often manual, time-consuming, and lack standardization, leading to variability in the quality of the extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds produced. Here, we present MyoBio, an automated bioreactor system designed for standardized perfusion-decellularization of whole skeletal muscle. MyoBio integrates precise control of perfusion parameters, including flow rate, pressure, and temperature, with real-time monitoring to ensure consistent decellularization outcomes. We demonstrate the system's capability by decellularizing rat tibialis anterior muscles, achieving complete cell removal while preserving ECM architecture and composition. The automated process reduces operator dependency and processing time, enhancing reproducibility and scalability. MyoBio represents a significant advancement in skeletal muscle tissue engineering, providing a reliable platform for producing high-quality ECM scaffolds for research and clinical applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering methods instead of predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t match the review’s topic.

title: Assessment of human adipose-derived stem cell on surface-modified silicone implant to reduce capsular contracture formation
author: Sutthiwanjampa C.; Shin B.H.; Ryu N.E.; Kang S.H.; Heo C.Y.; Park H.
abstract: Capsular contracture is a common complication after silicone implant-based breast reconstruction. Human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs) have been reported to have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the effect of hASCs on surface-modified silicone implants to reduce capsular contracture formation. We modified the surface of silicone implants with polydopamine (PDA) and immobilized hASCs on the PDA-coated surface. The hASC-immobilized implants were implanted subcutaneously in rats, and the formation of capsular contracture was assessed. Our results showed that the hASC-immobilized implants significantly reduced capsule thickness and collagen density compared to unmodified implants. Moreover, the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and myofibroblast markers was decreased in the hASC group. These findings suggest that hASC immobilization on surface-modified silicone implants can effectively reduce capsular contracture formation by modulating the inflammatory response and fibrotic processes. This approach may provide a promising strategy to improve the outcomes of silicone implant-based breast reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biological effects of stem cell implants but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in surgery, so it falls outside the review’s scope.

title: RGD-Modified Alginate-GelMA Hydrogel Sheet Containing Gingival Mesenchymal Stem Cells: A Unique Platform for Wound Healing and Soft Tissue Regeneration
author: Ansari S.; Pouraghaei Sevari S.; Chen C.; Sarrion P.; Moshaverinia A.
abstract: Wound healing and soft tissue regeneration remain a clinical challenge due to the lack of suitable biomaterials that can provide a conducive microenvironment for cell growth and tissue repair. Herein, we report the development of an RGD-modified alginate-gelatin methacryloyl (GelMA) hydrogel sheet encapsulating gingival mesenchymal stem cells (GMSCs) as a unique platform for wound healing and soft tissue regeneration. The hydrogel sheet was fabricated by combining the bioactivity of GelMA with the mechanical stability of alginate, further enhanced by RGD peptide modification to promote cell adhesion. The encapsulated GMSCs maintained high viability, proliferation, and multilineage differentiation potential within the hydrogel matrix. In vitro studies demonstrated enhanced cell spreading and migration, while in vivo implantation in a rat skin wound model showed accelerated wound closure, increased neovascularization, and improved extracellular matrix deposition compared to controls. These findings suggest that the RGD-modified alginate-GelMA hydrogel sheet containing GMSCs offers a promising biomaterial platform for effective wound healing and soft tissue regeneration applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomaterial development for healing rather than automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Digitizing rhinoplasty: a web application with three-dimensional preoperative evaluation to assist rhinoplasty surgeons with surgical planning
author: Topsakal O.; Akbaş M.İ.; Demirel D.; Nunez R.; Smith B.S.; Perez M.F.; Celikoyar M.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Rhinoplasty is a challenging surgical procedure that requires a thorough preoperative evaluation to achieve optimal aesthetic and functional outcomes. Three-dimensional (3D) imaging has been increasingly used to assist in surgical planning; however, its accessibility and ease of use remain limited. This study presents a web application designed to facilitate 3D preoperative evaluation for rhinoplasty surgeons, aiming to improve surgical planning and patient communication. Methods The web application integrates 3D facial scanning, morphometric analysis, and simulation tools to provide a comprehensive platform for rhinoplasty assessment. It allows surgeons to upload patient images, perform 3D reconstructions, analyze nasal morphology, and simulate surgical outcomes. The application was evaluated through usability testing with rhinoplasty surgeons and feedback was collected regarding its functionality and clinical utility. Results The web application demonstrated effective 3D visualization and morphometric analysis capabilities, enabling detailed preoperative assessment. Surgeons reported that the tool enhanced their surgical planning process and improved patient understanding of potential outcomes. The platform's web-based nature facilitated easy access without the need for specialized hardware or software. Conclusion The developed web application offers a practical and accessible solution for 3D preoperative evaluation in rhinoplasty. By integrating advanced imaging and simulation features into a user-friendly interface, it supports surgeons in planning procedures and communicating with patients, potentially leading to improved surgical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a web app for 3D surgical planning in rhinoplasty without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which falls outside the review’s scope.

title: Evaluating the agreement and reliability of a web-based facial analysis tool for rhinoplasty
author: Topsakal O.; Akbaş M.İ.; Smith B.S.; Perez M.F.; Guden E.C.; Celikoyar M.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: The aim of this study was to evaluate the agreement and reliability of a web-based facial analysis tool for rhinoplasty. Methods: A total of 50 patients who underwent rhinoplasty were included in this study. Preoperative and postoperative photographs were analyzed using a web-based facial analysis tool. Measurements of nasal angles and proportions were obtained and compared with manual measurements performed by experienced surgeons. Intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) and Bland-Altman plots were used to assess agreement and reliability. Results: The web-based tool showed good to excellent agreement with manual measurements, with ICCs ranging from 0.78 to 0.92 for various nasal parameters. Bland-Altman analysis demonstrated minimal bias and acceptable limits of agreement. The tool also exhibited high test-retest reliability. Conclusion: The web-based facial analysis tool provides reliable and accurate measurements for rhinoplasty assessment, supporting its use as a convenient and objective method in clinical practice.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses only on how consistent a facial analysis tool's measurements are, without covering automatic prediction or judging aesthetic results, which falls outside this review’s area.

title: Movement-level process modeling of microsurgical bimanual and unimanual tasks
author: Koskinen J.; Huotarinen A.; Elomaa A.-P.; Zheng B.; Bednarik R.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Microsurgical training is a challenging task that requires the development of fine motor skills and bimanual coordination. Objective assessment of surgical skills is essential for effective training and evaluation. This study aims to develop a movement-level process model to analyze and differentiate microsurgical bimanual and unimanual tasks using kinematic data.  Methods We collected kinematic data from expert and novice surgeons performing microsurgical tasks using a robotic system. A movement-level process model was developed to segment and classify the surgical motions into meaningful primitives. Statistical analysis was conducted to compare the movement patterns between bimanual and unimanual tasks and between skill levels.  Results The proposed model successfully segmented the surgical motions into distinct movement primitives, revealing significant differences in movement patterns between bimanual and unimanual tasks. Experts demonstrated smoother and more coordinated movements compared to novices. The model effectively captured the complexity of bimanual coordination and provided quantitative metrics for skill assessment.  Conclusion The movement-level process model offers a novel approach to objectively analyze microsurgical skills by capturing detailed movement patterns. This method can enhance surgical training by providing targeted feedback and improving the assessment of bimanual coordination in microsurgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on modeling surgical skills for training, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: In vivo evaluation of bone regeneration behavior of novel β-tricalcium phosphate/layered double hydroxide nanocomposite granule as bone graft substitutes
author: Eskandari N.; Shafiei S.S.; Dehghan M.M.; Farzad-Mohajeri S.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The development of novel bone graft substitutes with enhanced osteogenic properties is crucial for effective bone regeneration. In this study, we fabricated β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP)/layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanocomposite granules and evaluated their bone regeneration behavior in vivo. The β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules were characterized for their physicochemical properties, and their biocompatibility was assessed. Subsequently, the granules were implanted into critical-sized bone defects in a rabbit model to assess new bone formation and material resorption over time. Histological and micro-computed tomography analyses demonstrated that the β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules significantly enhanced new bone formation compared to pure β-TCP granules. The incorporation of LDH improved the osteoconductivity and bioactivity of β-TCP, promoting better integration with host bone tissue. These findings suggest that β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules are promising candidates as bone graft substitutes for clinical applications in bone defect repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone graft materials for bone healing, which doesn’t relate to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: Zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage modulate the activity of adipose tissue-derived stem cells in cartilage regeneration
author: Kuhlmann C.; Schenck T.L.; Aszodi A.; Giunta R.E.; Wiggenhauser P.S.
abstract: Cartilage tissue engineering is a promising approach for the treatment of cartilage defects. Decellularized extracellular matrix (dECM) scaffolds derived from native cartilage have been shown to provide a favorable microenvironment for cartilage regeneration. However, the heterogeneity of cartilage tissue, especially in the nasal septum, raises questions about the influence of zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of dECM on stem cell behavior. In this study, we investigated the zone-dependent characteristics of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage and their effects on the activity of adipose tissue-derived stem cells (ASCs) in cartilage regeneration. The nasal cartilage was divided into superficial, intermediate, and deep zones, and each zone was decellularized separately. Histological and biochemical analyses revealed distinct zone-dependent differences in collagen and glycosaminoglycan content after decellularization. ASCs cultured on dECM scaffolds from different zones exhibited varied proliferation, chondrogenic differentiation, and extracellular matrix production. Our findings demonstrate that the zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage modulate ASC activity, suggesting that tailored dECM scaffolds could enhance cartilage tissue engineering strategies.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at cartilage tissue engineering and stem cell behavior in the lab but doesn’t cover automated prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Implementation of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision by multiple surgeons in a large teaching hospital: Morbidity, long-term oncological and functional outcome
author: Hol J.C.; Dogan K.; Blanken-Peeters C.F.J.M.; van Eekeren R.R.J.P.; de Roos M.A.J.; Sietses C.; Spillenaar Bilgen E.J.; Witteman B.P.L.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  The aim of this study was to evaluate the implementation of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision (R-TME) by multiple surgeons in a large teaching hospital, focusing on morbidity, long-term oncological, and functional outcomes. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients undergoing R-TME for rectal cancer. Data on perioperative morbidity, pathological outcomes, local recurrence, disease-free survival, and functional results including bowel, urinary, and sexual function were collected and analyzed. The study demonstrated that R-TME can be safely implemented by multiple surgeons with acceptable morbidity rates. Long-term oncological outcomes were comparable to established standards, and functional outcomes showed preservation of bowel and urinary function with acceptable sexual function recovery. These findings support the feasibility and effectiveness of R-TME in a teaching hospital setting with multiple surgeons.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on clinical results of robot-assisted rectal cancer surgery and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic outcomes, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: An extracellular matrix-mimicking, bilayered, heterogeneous, porous, nanofibrous scaffold for anterior urethroplasty in a rabbit model
author: Wan X.; Zheng D.; Yao H.; Fu S.; Wei Z.; Wang Z.; Xie M.
abstract: Tissue engineering offers promising alternatives for urethral reconstruction. Herein, we developed a bilayered, heterogeneous, porous, nanofibrous scaffold mimicking the extracellular matrix (ECM) for anterior urethroplasty. The scaffold was fabricated by electrospinning a blend of polycaprolactone (PCL) and gelatin to form a porous nanofibrous layer, combined with a dense PCL layer to provide mechanical support and prevent urine leakage. The bilayered scaffold exhibited suitable mechanical properties, high porosity, and excellent biocompatibility. In vitro studies demonstrated that the scaffold supported the adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of urothelial and smooth muscle cells. In a rabbit model of anterior urethral defect, the scaffold facilitated effective urethral regeneration with well-organized epithelial and smooth muscle layers, minimal inflammation, and no stricture formation. These findings suggest that the ECM-mimicking bilayered scaffold holds great potential for clinical application in urethral tissue engineering.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering in rabbits and doesn’t cover automated prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which is outside the review's main topic.

title: Acellular Biologic Nipple-Areolar Complex Graft: In Vivo Murine and Nonhuman Primate Host Response Evaluation
author: Pashos N.C.; Graham D.M.; Burkett B.J.; O'Donnell B.; Sabol R.A.; Helm J.; Martin E.C.; Bowles A.C.; Heim W.M.; Caronna V.C.; Miller K.S.; Grasperge B.; Sullivan S.; Chaffin A.E.; Bunnell B.A.
abstract: The nipple-areolar complex (NAC) is a critical aesthetic and functional component of the breast. Reconstruction of the NAC after mastectomy remains a challenge, with current techniques often resulting in suboptimal outcomes. This study evaluates the host response to an acellular biologic NAC graft in vivo using murine and nonhuman primate models. The acellular graft was prepared through decellularization processes to remove cellular components while preserving the extracellular matrix architecture. Following implantation, histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to assess cellular infiltration, neovascularization, and immune response over time. Results demonstrated favorable integration of the graft with minimal inflammatory response and evidence of tissue remodeling and revascularization. These findings suggest that acellular biologic NAC grafts may provide a promising approach for NAC reconstruction, warranting further investigation toward clinical application.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biological grafts in animals instead of predicting or assessing aesthetic results in human plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn’t match the review’s topic.

title: Bone surface reconstruction and clinical features estimation from sparse landmarks and Statistical Shape Models: a feasibility study on the femur
author: Asvadi A.; Dardenne G.; Troccaz J.; Burdin V.
abstract: Bone surface reconstruction from sparse landmarks is a challenging problem in medical image analysis, especially when the available data is limited and noisy. This study investigates the feasibility of using Statistical Shape Models (SSMs) to reconstruct the femur bone surface and estimate clinical features from sparse anatomical landmarks. We propose a method that integrates sparse landmark data with a pre-built SSM of the femur to generate accurate 3D reconstructions. The approach is evaluated on a dataset of femur shapes, assessing reconstruction accuracy and the estimation of clinically relevant parameters such as bone length and curvature. Results demonstrate that the proposed method can reliably reconstruct femur surfaces and estimate clinical features with acceptable accuracy, even with a limited number of landmarks. This feasibility study suggests that SSM-based reconstruction from sparse landmarks has potential applications in preoperative planning and orthopedic assessments where full imaging data may not be available.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone reconstruction in orthopedics rather than predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Evaluation of clinical performance of tini-based implants used in chest wall repair after resection for malignant tumors
author: Topolnitskiy E.; Chekalkin T.; Marchenko E.; Yasenchuk Y.; Kang S.-B.; Kang J.-H.; Obrosov A.
abstract: The use of titanium implants in chest wall reconstruction after tumor resection has become increasingly common due to their favorable mechanical properties and biocompatibility. This study evaluates the clinical performance of titanium-based implants in patients undergoing chest wall repair following malignant tumor resection. We conducted a retrospective analysis of patients treated with titanium implants, assessing postoperative outcomes, complications, and implant integration over a defined follow-up period. Our findings indicate that titanium implants provide effective structural support, exhibit low complication rates, and contribute to satisfactory functional and aesthetic results. These results support the continued use of titanium-based materials in chest wall reconstruction, highlighting their role in improving patient recovery and quality of life after oncologic surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on clinical results of implants without covering automatic methods for predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes, which falls outside the review's focus.

title: Stereolithography (STL) measurement rubric for the evaluation of craniomaxillofacial STLs
author: Muller H.; Fossey A.
abstract: Background: Stereolithography (STL) files are widely used in craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery for virtual surgical planning and 3D printing. However, there is a lack of standardized methods to evaluate the quality of these STL files, which can impact surgical outcomes. This study aims to develop and validate a measurement rubric for assessing the quality of CMF STL files.  Methods: A measurement rubric was created based on key parameters affecting STL quality, including surface integrity, anatomical accuracy, and file completeness. The rubric was applied to a set of CMF STL files generated from various imaging modalities and segmentation software. Inter-rater reliability and validity of the rubric were assessed.  Results: The developed rubric demonstrated high inter-rater reliability (intraclass correlation coefficient > 0.85) and effectively differentiated STL files based on quality parameters. The rubric facilitated objective assessment and comparison of STL files, highlighting areas for improvement in STL generation workflows.  Conclusions: The proposed STL measurement rubric provides a standardized tool for evaluating CMF STL files, promoting consistency and quality in virtual surgical planning and 3D printing applications. Adoption of this rubric can enhance surgical outcomes by ensuring high-quality STL models.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating a tool to assess technical quality of STL files in surgery but doesn’t touch on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, which is what the review is looking for.

title: Sustained release of stromal cell–derived factor-1 alpha from silk fibroin microfiber promotes urethral reconstruction in rabbits
author: Liu Y.; Huang L.; Yuan W.; Zhang D.; Gu Y.; Huang J.; Murphy S.; Ali M.; Zhang Y.; Song L.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Sustained release of stromal cell–derived factor-1 alpha (SDF-1α) from silk fibroin (SF) microfiber was developed to promote urethral reconstruction in rabbits. SF microfibers were fabricated by electrospinning and then loaded with SDF-1α. The release profile of SDF-1α from SF microfibers was evaluated in vitro. The bioactivity of released SDF-1α was confirmed by chemotaxis assay of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs). The SF microfibers loaded with SDF-1α were used to repair urethral defects in rabbits. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to evaluate tissue regeneration and angiogenesis. The results showed that SDF-1α was released from SF microfibers in a sustained manner for over 28 days. The released SDF-1α retained its bioactivity and effectively induced BMSC migration. In vivo, the SDF-1α-loaded SF microfibers significantly enhanced urethral tissue regeneration and neovascularization compared to controls. This study demonstrates that SF microfibers can serve as an effective delivery system for SDF-1α, promoting urethral reconstruction by recruiting endogenous stem cells and enhancing angiogenesis.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tissue regeneration in rabbits and doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, which is outside the review's main topic.

title: Titanium-coated polypropylene mesh as innovative bioactive material in conservatives mastectomies and pre-pectoral breast reconstruction
author: Gentile P.; Bernini M.; Orzalesi L.; Sordi S.; Meattini I.; Lessi F.; Kothari A.; Calabrese C.
abstract: Titanium-coated polypropylene mesh (TCPM) is a new bioactive material used in conservative mastectomies and pre-pectoral breast reconstruction. This study evaluates the clinical outcomes, safety, and aesthetic results of TCPM in breast reconstruction. A total of 55 patients underwent conservative mastectomies with immediate pre-pectoral implant-based reconstruction using TCPM. The results showed that TCPM is a safe and effective material, providing good implant coverage and support, with low complication rates and satisfactory aesthetic outcomes. The bioactive properties of TCPM may contribute to improved tissue integration and reduced inflammatory response, making it a promising option in breast reconstructive surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses mainly on clinical evaluation of a biomaterial in breast reconstruction and doesn't cover automatic prediction or computational assessment of aesthetic results, which is the key interest here.

title: Self-swelling tissue expander for soft tissue reconstruction in the craniofacial region: An in vitro and in vivo evaluation
author: Chang Y.; Zhang F.; Liu F.; Shi L.; Zhang L.; Zhu H.
abstract: Tissue expansion is a widely used technique in reconstructive surgery to generate additional soft tissue for defect coverage. Conventional tissue expanders require multiple surgical interventions and patient discomfort. This study presents a novel self-swelling tissue expander composed of a hydrogel that absorbs body fluids and expands autonomously, reducing the need for repeated surgeries. The hydrogel was synthesized and characterized in vitro for swelling behavior, mechanical properties, and biocompatibility. Subsequently, in vivo evaluation was conducted in a craniofacial animal model to assess the expansion capacity, tissue response, and integration. Results demonstrated that the self-swelling expander achieved controlled and predictable expansion, elicited minimal inflammatory response, and facilitated soft tissue generation suitable for reconstructive purposes. This innovative approach offers a promising alternative to traditional expanders, potentially improving patient outcomes in craniofacial soft tissue reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating and testing a new tissue expander device, but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, which is the main interest here.

title: Multimodal mixed reality visualisation for intraoperative surgical guidance
author: Cartucho J.; Shapira D.; Ashrafian H.; Giannarou S.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Mixed reality (MR) is an emerging technology that can be used to support intraoperative surgical guidance by providing surgeons with intuitive visualizations of patient-specific data. This paper presents a multimodal MR visualization framework that integrates preoperative imaging, intraoperative data, and surgical instrument tracking to enhance surgical navigation and decision-making. Methods The proposed framework combines volumetric rendering of preoperative images, real-time tracking of surgical instruments, and intraoperative imaging updates within a head-mounted display. The system was evaluated in a simulated surgical environment with surgeons performing navigation tasks. Results The multimodal MR visualization improved spatial understanding and accuracy in instrument placement compared to conventional navigation methods. Surgeons reported enhanced situational awareness and usability of the system. Conclusion The integration of multimodal data in MR provides a promising approach for intraoperative surgical guidance, potentially improving surgical outcomes and reducing operative times. Further clinical studies are warranted to validate the system in real surgical scenarios.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on mixed reality for surgical guidance but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic outcomes, so it’s outside the review’s focus.

title: Mitral Valve Posterior Leaflet Reconstruction Using Extracellular Matrix: In Vitro Evaluation
author: Tjørnild M.J.; Sørensen S.W.; Carlson Hanse L.; Skov S.N.; Røpcke D.M.; Nielsen S.L.; Hasenkam J.M.
abstract: Mitral valve (MV) repair is the preferred treatment for mitral regurgitation, but leaflet reconstruction remains challenging. Extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds have been proposed as a promising material for leaflet reconstruction due to their bioactivity and potential for remodeling. This study aimed to evaluate the mechanical and functional performance of ECM scaffolds used for posterior leaflet reconstruction in an in vitro MV model. Porcine ECM patches were sutured to replace the posterior leaflet in excised porcine MVs mounted in a left heart simulator. Hemodynamic parameters, leaflet kinematics, and coaptation were assessed under physiological conditions and compared to native valves. The ECM-reconstructed valves demonstrated effective coaptation and maintained competent valve function with no significant regurgitation. Mechanical testing revealed that ECM patches exhibited suitable stiffness and durability for leaflet replacement. These findings suggest that ECM scaffolds can restore MV function and may be a viable option for posterior leaflet reconstruction, warranting further in vivo studies to assess long-term remodeling and durability.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on lab-based mitral valve reconstruction, which doesn’t relate to predicting or assessing results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Effect of digital-enabled multidisciplinary therapy conferences on efficiency and quality of the decision making in prostate cancer care
author: Ronmark E.; Hoffmann R.; Skokic V.; De Klerk-Starmans M.; Jaderling F.; Vos P.; Gayet M.C.W.; Hofstraat H.; Janssen M.; Akre O.; Vincent P.H.
abstract: Background: Multidisciplinary therapy conferences (MDTs) are essential for decision making in cancer care but are often time-consuming and lack digital support. This study evaluates the effect of a digital-enabled MDT platform on the efficiency and quality of decision making in prostate cancer care.  Methods: We conducted a prospective observational study comparing MDTs before and after implementation of a digital platform designed to support case preparation, presentation, and documentation. Efficiency was measured by time spent per patient and overall conference duration. Quality was assessed using validated metrics for decision-making completeness and adherence to clinical guidelines.  Results: Implementation of the digital platform significantly reduced the average time spent per patient (p<0.01) and total conference duration (p<0.05). The quality of decisions improved, with increased completeness of case information and higher adherence to guidelines (p<0.05). User satisfaction with the MDT process also increased.  Conclusions: Digital-enabled MDTs enhance efficiency and quality in prostate cancer care decision making. Adoption of such platforms can optimize resource use and improve patient management outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on digital tools for prostate cancer decisions, missing topics like automatic predictions or assessing cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which are the main interests here.

title: Does the use of a uterine manipulator in robotic surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer affect oncological outcomes?
author: Ito H.; Moritake T.; Isaka K.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  The use of a uterine manipulator (UM) in minimally invasive surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer (EC) remains controversial due to concerns about potential tumor dissemination and impact on oncological outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of UM use during robotic surgery on oncological outcomes in patients with early-stage EC. We conducted a retrospective analysis of patients with stage I–II EC who underwent robotic hysterectomy with or without UM between 2010 and 2018. Oncological outcomes, including recurrence rates, disease-free survival (DFS), and overall survival (OS), were compared between the two groups. A total of 150 patients were included, with 90 in the UM group and 60 in the no-UM group. There were no significant differences in baseline characteristics between groups. The recurrence rate was 5.6% in the UM group and 6.7% in the no-UM group (p = 0.78). The 3-year DFS and OS rates were comparable between groups (DFS: 94.4% vs. 93.3%, p = 0.85; OS: 96.7% vs. 95.0%, p = 0.72). Multivariate analysis showed that UM use was not an independent predictor of recurrence or survival. Our findings suggest that the use of a uterine manipulator during robotic surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer does not adversely affect oncological outcomes. These results support the safe use of UM in minimally invasive surgical management of early-stage EC.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on cancer-related results from using uterine manipulators in robotic surgery, without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic outcomes, which is outside the review's topic.

title: The mechanism of balloon Eustachian tuboplasty: a biomechanical study
author: Smith M.E.; Weir A.E.; Prior D.C.C.; Cope W.; Tysome J.R.; Sutcliffe M.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Balloon Eustachian tuboplasty (BET) is a minimally invasive treatment for Eustachian tube dysfunction (ETD). However, the mechanism of BET remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the biomechanical mechanism of BET by measuring the deformation of the Eustachian tube (ET) cartilage during balloon inflation. Fresh human cadaveric temporal bones were used. A balloon catheter was inserted into the ET lumen and inflated to 10 atm. The deformation of the ET cartilage was measured using digital image correlation (DIC) techniques. The results showed that balloon inflation caused significant expansion and deformation of the ET cartilage, particularly in the lateral lamina. The maximum principal strain reached up to 20%, indicating plastic deformation. These findings suggest that BET works by mechanically dilating and remodeling the ET cartilage, which may restore ET function in patients with ETD. This biomechanical insight provides a foundation for optimizing BET procedures and improving clinical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the biomechanics of balloon Eustachian tuboplasty, which doesn’t relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Laparoscopic augmented reality registration for oncological resection site repair
author: Joeres F.; Mielke T.; Hansen C.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Augmented reality (AR) can improve the surgeon’s perception of the surgical site by overlaying preoperative imaging data onto the intraoperative scene. However, the registration of preoperative data to the intraoperative scene remains a challenging task, especially in laparoscopic surgery where the field of view is limited and soft tissue deformation occurs. This paper presents a novel method for laparoscopic AR registration specifically designed for oncological resection site repair. Methods The proposed method uses a combination of feature-based and intensity-based registration techniques to align preoperative computed tomography (CT) images with intraoperative laparoscopic video. The approach incorporates a deformable model to account for soft tissue deformation and employs a real-time tracking system to maintain registration accuracy during surgery. The method was evaluated on a dataset of laparoscopic oncological resections with ground truth annotations. Results The proposed registration method achieved a mean target registration error (TRE) of 3.2 mm, demonstrating improved accuracy compared to existing approaches. The system operated in real-time, maintaining registration throughout the surgical procedure. Qualitative feedback from surgeons indicated enhanced spatial understanding of the resection site. Conclusion The presented laparoscopic AR registration method provides accurate and real-time alignment of preoperative imaging with intraoperative laparoscopic views, facilitating oncological resection site repair. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes by enhancing the surgeon’s perception and precision during minimally invasive oncological procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on augmented reality methods for surgical navigation without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, which falls outside the review’s scope.

title: Transplantation of patient-specific bile duct bioengineered with chemically reprogrammed and microtopographically differentiated cells
author: Buisson E.M.; Park S.-H.; Kim M.; Kang K.; Yoon S.; Lee J.E.; Kim Y.W.; Lee N.K.; Jeong M.A.; Kang B.-K.; Lee S.B.; Factor V.M.; Seo D.; Kim H.; Jeong J.; Kim H.J.; Choi D.
abstract: The shortage of donor organs and the lack of effective treatments for biliary diseases have motivated the development of bioengineered bile ducts. Here, we report the transplantation of patient-specific bile ducts bioengineered with chemically reprogrammed and microtopographically differentiated cells. Human chemically derived hepatic progenitor cells (hCdHPCs) were generated from patient-specific fibroblasts using a chemical reprogramming approach. These hCdHPCs were then cultured on microtopographically patterned scaffolds to induce differentiation into cholangiocyte-like cells, forming a functional bile duct tissue. The bioengineered bile ducts exhibited appropriate cellular morphology, marker expression, and bile acid transport function in vitro. Upon transplantation into a rat model with bile duct injury, the bioengineered bile ducts integrated with host tissue, restored bile flow, and improved liver function without eliciting significant immune rejection. This study demonstrates the feasibility of generating patient-specific bioengineered bile ducts using chemically reprogrammed cells and microtopographical cues, offering a promising strategy for personalized regenerative therapy in biliary diseases.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focus on bioengineering and bile duct transplantation doesn’t connect with predicting or evaluating looks in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: The Use of Infrared Thermography in Determining Timing for Early Pedicle Division of the Preexpanded Bipedicled Visor Flap after Ischemic Preconditioning
author: Xiao W.; Zhang S.; Li H.; Feng S.; Nicoli F.; Huynh R.; Lu J.; Zhang Y.; Min P.
abstract: The bipedicled visor flap is a reliable flap for total upper and lower lip reconstruction. However, the timing of pedicle division is crucial to avoid flap necrosis. This study aimed to evaluate the use of infrared thermography (IRT) in determining the timing for early pedicle division of the preexpanded bipedicled visor flap after ischemic preconditioning. A prospective study was conducted on patients undergoing total lip reconstruction with the preexpanded bipedicled visor flap. Ischemic preconditioning was performed by sequential clamping of the pedicles, and IRT was used to monitor flap temperature changes. The timing for pedicle division was determined based on the temperature difference between the flap and surrounding tissue. The results showed that IRT could effectively detect changes in flap perfusion, allowing safe early pedicle division without flap necrosis. The use of IRT provides a noninvasive, real-time, and reliable method to guide the timing of pedicle division in preexpanded bipedicled visor flaps after ischemic preconditioning, potentially reducing the overall treatment time and improving patient outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on using infrared thermography for surgical timing but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or how the results look, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Microfluidic-prepared, monodisperse, X-ray-visible, embolic microspheres for non-oncological embolization applications
author: Beh C.W.; Fu Y.; Weiss C.R.; Hu C.; Arepally A.; Mao H.-Q.; Wang T.-H.; Kraitchman D.L.
abstract: Transcatheter embolization is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat a variety of conditions by occluding blood vessels. Current embolic agents, such as polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) particles and microspheres, have limitations including polydispersity and lack of visibility under X-ray imaging, which can affect treatment precision and outcomes. Here, we report the development of monodisperse, X-ray-visible embolic microspheres prepared using a microfluidic platform.
