These microspheres are composed of a biocompatible polymer matrix loaded with bismuth nanoparticles to confer radiopacity. The microfluidic synthesis allows precise control over particle size and uniformity, resulting in microspheres with narrow size distributions. In vitro characterization demonstrates their stability, biocompatibility, and strong X-ray contrast. Furthermore, in vivo embolization studies in a rabbit model confirm effective vessel occlusion and real-time visualization under fluoroscopy. This work presents a promising approach for producing embolic agents with improved size control and imaging capabilities, potentially enhancing the safety and efficacy of non-oncological embolization procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating embolic microspheres for non-cancer treatments and doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Biocompatibility and degradation comparisons of four biodegradable copolymeric osteosynthesis systems used in maxillofacial surgery: A goat model with four years follow-up
author: Gareb B.; van Bakelen N.B.; Driessen L.; Buma P.; Kuipers J.; Grijpma D.W.; Vissink A.; Bos R.R.M.; van Minnen B.
abstract: Biodegradable osteosynthesis systems (BOS) have been widely used in maxillofacial surgery, but their long-term biocompatibility and degradation behavior remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the biocompatibility and degradation of four biodegradable copolymeric BOS in a goat model over a four-year follow-up period. Forty-eight goats were randomly assigned to four groups, each receiving one type of BOS: poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA), poly(L-lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA), poly(L-lactic acid-co-ε-caprolactone) (PLLA-PCL), and poly(L-lactic acid-co-trimethylene carbonate) (PLLA-TMC). Clinical, radiographic, histological, and molecular analyses were performed at 6, 12, 24, and 48 months post-implantation. Results showed that all BOS provided adequate fixation and gradually degraded without adverse tissue reactions. PLLA and PLLA-PCL exhibited slower degradation rates with sustained mechanical integrity, while PLGA and PLLA-TMC degraded faster but induced mild inflammatory responses during early degradation phases. Histological evaluation revealed progressive replacement of BOS by new bone tissue, with PLLA-PCL demonstrating superior osteoconductivity. Molecular assays indicated transient upregulation of inflammatory cytokines correlating with degradation stages. Overall, PLLA-PCL presented the best balance between biocompatibility, degradation rate, and osteointegration, suggesting its potential as an optimal BOS for maxillofacial applications. This long-term comparative study provides valuable insights for selecting biodegradable materials in clinical practice.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biocompatibility and breakdown of bone-fixing devices in animals rather than on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Nonrigid reconstruction of 3D breast surfaces with a low-cost RGBD camera for surgical planning and aesthetic evaluation
author: Lacher R.M.; Vasconcelos F.; Williams N.R.; Rindermann G.; Hipwell J.; Hawkes D.; Stoyanov D.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) surface reconstruction of the breast is a key step in computer-assisted breast surgery planning and aesthetic evaluation. However, current 3D imaging systems are either expensive or require complex setups, limiting their clinical use. In this paper, we propose a novel nonrigid reconstruction method using a low-cost RGBD camera to capture the breast surface in multiple views. Our approach addresses the challenges posed by breast deformation and patient movement during acquisition by integrating a nonrigid registration framework that aligns partial scans into a consistent 3D model. We validate our method on synthetic and real data, demonstrating improved accuracy and robustness compared to rigid registration techniques. The proposed system offers a cost-effective and practical solution for 3D breast surface reconstruction, facilitating enhanced surgical planning and aesthetic assessment in clinical practice.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses mainly on a technical method for 3D breast surface reconstruction rather than on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results, which doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Muscle volume reconstruction from several short magnetic resonance imaging sequences
author: Marzilger R.; Schroll A.; Bohm S.; Arampatzis A.
abstract: Muscle volume is an important parameter for biomechanical modeling and clinical applications. However, acquiring full muscle volume data using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be time-consuming and challenging, especially in clinical settings. This study proposes a method to reconstruct muscle volume from several short MRI sequences, reducing acquisition time while maintaining accuracy. The approach involves segmenting muscle cross-sectional areas from limited MRI slices and employing interpolation techniques to estimate the full muscle volume. Validation against complete MRI datasets demonstrates that the reconstructed volumes closely approximate the actual muscle volumes, suggesting that this method can effectively facilitate muscle volume estimation in both research and clinical contexts.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on muscle volume reconstruction from MRI scans instead of predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Safety profile and oncological outcomes of gastric gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) robotic resection: Single center experience
author: Maggioni C.; Shida A.; Mancini R.; Ioni L.; Pernazza G.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic surgery has been increasingly used for the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) of the stomach. This study aims to evaluate the safety profile and oncological outcomes of robotic gastric GIST resection in a single center experience. We retrospectively analyzed data from patients who underwent robotic resection for gastric GISTs, focusing on perioperative outcomes, complications, and long-term oncological results. Our findings demonstrate that robotic resection is a safe and feasible approach with low morbidity and favorable oncological outcomes, suggesting it as a viable minimally invasive option for gastric GIST management.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on surgical safety and cancer outcomes of robotic gastric tumor removal without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t match the review’s topic.

title: Comparisons of anterior plate screw pullout strength between polyurethane foams and thoracolumbar cadaveric vertebrae
author: Nagaraja S.; Palepu V.
abstract: Anterior plate fixation is a common technique used in spinal surgery to stabilize the vertebrae. The pullout strength of screws used in anterior plates is critical for the success of the fixation. This study compares the pullout strength of anterior plate screws in polyurethane foams, which are commonly used as bone substitutes in biomechanical testing, with that in thoracolumbar cadaveric vertebrae. The objective is to evaluate the validity of using polyurethane foams as a surrogate for human vertebrae in biomechanical testing of anterior plate screw fixation. The results indicate differences in pullout strength between the two materials, providing insights into the appropriateness of polyurethane foams for simulating human vertebral bone in such tests.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Examines spinal screw materials without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Regenerating a ventricular cavity during left ventricular assist device implantation
author: Altas O.; Ozer T.; Ozgur M.M.; Sarikaya S.; Kirali K.
abstract: Left ventricular assist device (LVAD) implantation is a well-established therapy for patients with end-stage heart failure. However, the presence of a severely dilated and dysfunctional left ventricle (LV) can complicate the procedure and affect postoperative outcomes. This study explores a novel surgical technique aimed at regenerating the ventricular cavity during LVAD implantation to optimize device function and patient prognosis. By employing targeted myocardial remodeling and cavity reshaping strategies, the approach seeks to restore more physiological LV geometry and improve hemodynamics. Initial clinical experiences suggest that this method may enhance LVAD performance and patient recovery, warranting further investigation in larger cohorts.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a surgical method for heart support that doesn’t relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: 3D collagen microfibers stimulate the functionality of preadipocytes and maintain the phenotype of mature adipocytes for long term cultures
author: Louis F.; Kitano S.; Mano J.F.; Matsusaki M.
abstract: Adipose tissue engineering is a promising approach for soft tissue reconstruction and in vitro models for drug screening and disease modeling. However, maintaining mature adipocytes in culture remains challenging due to their fragility and tendency to dedifferentiate. Here, we developed a 3D culture system based on collagen microfibers to support both preadipocytes and mature adipocytes. Collagen microfibers were produced by electrospinning and assembled into 3D scaffolds that mimic the native extracellular matrix architecture. Preadipocytes cultured on these scaffolds showed enhanced proliferation and differentiation capacity compared to 2D cultures. Importantly, mature adipocytes maintained their phenotype, including lipid content and adipogenic marker expression, for extended periods in 3D culture, whereas they rapidly lost these features in 2D. This 3D collagen microfiber system provides a physiologically relevant microenvironment that supports adipocyte functionality and phenotype maintenance, offering a valuable platform for adipose tissue engineering and related biomedical applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on building a 3D system for fat cell function in tissue engineering, but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review topic.

title: Mechanical stretching stimulates growth of the basal layer and rete ridges in the epidermis
author: Topczewska J.M.; Ledwon J.K.; Vaca E.E.; Gosain A.K.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: Mechanical stretching is known to influence skin growth and remodeling, but the underlying cellular mechanisms remain unclear. This study investigates the effects of mechanical stretching on the basal layer and rete ridges of the epidermis. Using an in vitro skin model subjected to controlled mechanical stretching, we observed significant stimulation of basal keratinocyte proliferation and elongation of rete ridges. Histological analysis revealed increased thickness of the basal layer and enhanced epidermal-dermal interactions. These findings suggest that mechanical stretching promotes epidermal growth by stimulating basal layer expansion and rete ridge formation, providing insights into skin regeneration and potential therapeutic approaches for wound healing and tissue engineering.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on how skin cells grow with stretching but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in surgery, which is the main interest here.

title: Error-Free Text Typing Performance of an Inductive Intra-Oral Tongue Computer Interface for Severely Disabled Individuals
author: Andreasen Struijk L.N.S.; Bentsen B.; Gaihede M.; Lontis E.R.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
doi: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
abstract: This paper presents an inductive intra-oral tongue computer interface (ITCI) designed to enable severely disabled individuals to perform error-free text typing. The ITCI system utilizes an inductive sensing mechanism embedded within a dental retainer, which detects tongue movements and translates them into computer commands. The study evaluates the system's performance in terms of typing speed, accuracy, and user comfort. Experimental results demonstrate that the ITCI achieves high accuracy with error-free text input and offers a promising communication solution for individuals with severe motor impairments. The findings suggest that the ITCI can significantly enhance the quality of life for users by providing an effective and reliable means of computer interaction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a tongue-computer interface to help disabled people communicate, which doesn’t connect to predicting or evaluating how plastic or cancer surgeries look.

title: The Application of Three-Dimensional Printing in Animal Model of Augmentation Rhinoplasty
author: Kim Y.S.; Shin Y.S.; Park D.Y.; Choi J.W.; Park J.K.; Kim D.H.; Kim C.H.; Park S.A.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing has been widely used in medical fields, but its application in animal models of augmentation rhinoplasty has not been reported. This study aimed to explore the feasibility and effectiveness of 3D printing technology in establishing an animal model of augmentation rhinoplasty. A 3D digital model of the nasal implant was designed based on computed tomography (CT) data of a rabbit's nasal bone and soft tissue. The implant was fabricated using 3D printing technology with biocompatible materials. The implant was surgically implanted into the nasal dorsum of rabbits to simulate augmentation rhinoplasty. Postoperative evaluation included clinical observation, CT imaging, and histological analysis. The results demonstrated that the 3D-printed implant fit well with the nasal anatomy, maintained its shape and position, and induced minimal inflammatory response. This study indicates that 3D printing technology can be effectively applied to create precise and individualized implants for animal models of augmentation rhinoplasty, providing a valuable platform for further research in nasal reconstruction and implant development.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on 3D-printed implants in animals instead of automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in human plastic or cancer surgery, which falls outside the review's main topic.

title: Electrospun nanofiber mesh with fibroblast growth factor and stem cells for pelvic floor repair
author: Hansen S.G.; Taskin M.B.; Chen M.; Wogensen L.; Vinge Nygaard J.; Axelsen S.M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Electrospun nanofiber mesh with fibroblast growth factor and stem cells for pelvic floor repair  Abstract: Pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) are common conditions that significantly affect women's quality of life. Current surgical treatments often involve synthetic meshes, which can lead to complications such as erosion and infection. Tissue engineering approaches using biocompatible scaffolds combined with bioactive molecules and stem cells offer promising alternatives. In this study, we developed an electrospun nanofiber mesh incorporating fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) to enhance pelvic floor repair. The mesh was fabricated using polycaprolactone (PCL) and gelatin, providing a suitable microenvironment for cell attachment and proliferation. FGF was incorporated to promote angiogenesis and tissue regeneration. In vitro assays demonstrated that the FGF-loaded mesh supported ADSC viability, proliferation, and differentiation. In vivo implantation in a rat model of pelvic floor injury showed improved tissue integration, neovascularization, and mechanical strength compared to control meshes. These findings suggest that the electrospun nanofiber mesh with FGF and ADSCs is a promising candidate for pelvic floor tissue engineering and repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating a scaffold for pelvic floor repair but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it falls outside the review’s focus.

title: Nyquist and Bode stability criteria to assess changes in dynamic knee stability in healthy and anterior cruciate ligament reconstructed individuals during walking
author: Morgan K.D.; Zheng Y.; Bush H.; Noehren B.
abstract: Dynamic knee stability is essential for normal walking and is often compromised following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR). Traditional biomechanical measures may not fully capture the dynamic stability of the knee joint during gait. This study applied Nyquist and Bode stability criteria, commonly used in control systems engineering, to assess changes in dynamic knee stability in healthy individuals and those with ACLR during walking. Knee joint kinematics and kinetics were recorded, and system stability was evaluated by analyzing the frequency response of knee joint dynamics. Results indicated that individuals with ACLR exhibited altered dynamic stability characteristics compared to healthy controls, with implications for rehabilitation and injury prevention strategies. These findings suggest that Nyquist and Bode criteria provide valuable insights into knee joint stability beyond conventional biomechanical assessments.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on knee stability and engineering measures in ACL reconstruction, which doesn’t match topics about predicting or evaluating looks in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction for intracranial aneurysm rupture risk assessment based on morphological parameters
author: Saalfeld S.; Berg P.; Niemann A.; Luz M.; Preim B.; Beuing O.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The rupture risk assessment of intracranial aneurysms (IAs) is a challenging task in clinical practice. Morphological parameters of IAs have been widely used for rupture risk assessment. However, the neck curve, which is the boundary between the aneurysm sac and the parent vessel, is difficult to reconstruct accurately and consistently. This paper proposes a semiautomatic method for neck curve reconstruction to improve the accuracy and reproducibility of morphological parameters for IA rupture risk assessment. Methods The proposed method first extracts the IA sac and parent vessel from 3D rotational angiography images. Then, a semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction algorithm is applied, which involves initial manual selection of points on the neck region followed by an automatic curve fitting process. Morphological parameters based on the reconstructed neck curve are calculated and used for rupture risk assessment. Results The method was evaluated on a dataset of 50 IAs, demonstrating improved accuracy and reproducibility of neck curve reconstruction compared to manual delineation. The morphological parameters derived from the semiautomatic neck curve showed better discrimination between ruptured and unruptured IAs. Conclusion The proposed semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction method provides a reliable and consistent way to define the neck boundary of IAs, enhancing the morphological analysis for rupture risk assessment. This approach has the potential to assist clinicians in making more informed treatment decisions.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on intracranial aneurysm risk assessment, which doesn’t relate to predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it isn’t a fit for this review.

title: In vivo endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia assessment after angioplasty of sheep carotid artery with a novel polycarbonate polyurethane patch
author: Jalaie H.; Steitz J.; Afify M.; Barbati M.E.; Hoeft K.; Assar M.A.M.; Hermanns-Sachweh B.; Tolba R.H.; Jacobs M.J.; Schleimer K.
abstract: Endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia are critical factors influencing the long-term success of vascular patches used in angioplasty. This study evaluates the in vivo endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia of a novel polycarbonate polyurethane (PCU) patch implanted in the sheep carotid artery following angioplasty. The PCU patch was implanted in 12 sheep, and assessments were conducted at 1, 3, and 6 months post-implantation. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to evaluate endothelial coverage and neointimal thickness. Results demonstrated progressive endothelialization over the PCU patch surface, with complete endothelial coverage observed by 6 months. Neointimal hyperplasia was minimal and stable over time, indicating favorable vascular healing responses. These findings suggest that the novel PCU patch promotes effective endothelialization while limiting neointimal hyperplasia, supporting its potential use in vascular reconstructive procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on blood vessel healing during angioplasty rather than on predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: Performance of marrow stromal cell-seeded small-caliber multilayered vascular graft in a senescent sheep model
author: Madhavan K.; Elliot W.; Tan Y.; Monnet E.; Tan W.
abstract: The development of small-caliber vascular grafts (SCVGs) with long-term patency remains a challenge in tissue engineering. Here, we fabricated a multilayered SCVG composed of an inner electrospun polycaprolactone (PCL) layer, a middle layer of PCL and gelatin, and an outer layer of PCL and collagen. The graft was seeded with autologous bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs) and implanted into the carotid artery of senescent sheep (aged 7–9 years) for 6 months. The BMSC-seeded grafts showed a patency rate of 83.3% (5/6), whereas the unseeded grafts had a patency rate of 50% (3/6). Histological analysis revealed endothelialization and smooth muscle cell infiltration in the BMSC-seeded grafts, with extracellular matrix deposition and neovascularization. The results demonstrate that BMSC seeding enhances the performance of multilayered SCVGs in a senescent large animal model, suggesting potential for clinical application in elderly patients.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on testing vascular grafts in animals, not on predicting or evaluating beauty results in surgery.

title: Robotic assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy using contrast-enhanced ultrasound scan to map renal blood flow
author: Alenezi A.; Motiwala A.; Eves S.; Gray R.; Thomas A.; Meiers I.; Sharif H.; Motiwala H.; Laniado M.; Karim O.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) is a novel imaging technique that allows real-time visualization of microvascular blood flow. We report the first case of robotic-assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy (RALPN) using intraoperative CEUS to map renal blood flow. A 62-year-old man with a 3.5 cm left renal mass underwent RALPN. After hilar clamping, CEUS was performed using an intravenous bolus of SonoVue® to identify the tumor and assess the perfusion of the renal parenchyma. CEUS allowed clear delineation of the tumor and identification of the ischemic area, guiding precise tumor excision and minimizing ischemic injury to the remaining kidney. The procedure was completed successfully with minimal blood loss and no complications. This case demonstrates that intraoperative CEUS is a feasible and valuable adjunct in RALPN, providing real-time assessment of renal perfusion and aiding in surgical decision-making. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its impact on surgical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on imaging during kidney surgery and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Chitosan-film enhanced chitosan nerve guides for long-distance regeneration of peripheral nerves
author: Meyer C.; Stenberg L.; Gonzalez-Perez F.; Wrobel S.; Ronchi G.; Udina E.; Suganuma S.; Geuna S.; Navarro X.; Dahlin L.B.; Grothe C.; Haastert-Talini K.
abstract: Peripheral nerve injuries with long gaps require nerve autografts for repair, but these have limitations such as donor site morbidity and limited availability. Artificial nerve guides are promising alternatives, but their efficacy decreases with increasing gap length. In this study, we developed chitosan-film enhanced chitosan nerve guides (CFeCNGs) by inserting a perforated chitosan film into hollow chitosan nerve guides to create two chambers, aiming to improve long-distance peripheral nerve regeneration. We evaluated their performance in a 15 mm rat sciatic nerve defect model compared to hollow chitosan nerve guides (hCNGs) and autologous nerve grafts (ANGs). Functional recovery was assessed by walking track analysis, electrophysiology, and histomorphometry after 4 and 12 weeks. CFeCNGs showed significantly improved functional and morphological outcomes compared to hCNGs and approached the results of ANGs. The chitosan film likely provides additional guidance cues and a favorable microenvironment for axonal growth. These findings suggest that CFeCNGs are a promising strategy for enhancing peripheral nerve regeneration over long gaps.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on nerve regeneration with chitosan guides but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation in surgery, which is the main topic of the review.

title: Rothmund-Thomson syndrome: Insights from new patients on the genetic variability underpinning clinical presentation and cancer outcome
author: Colombo E.A.; Locatelli A.; Sánchez L.C.; Romeo S.; Elcioglu N.H.; Maystadt I.; Martínez A.E.; Sironi A.; Fontana L.; Finelli P.; Gervasini C.; Pecile V.; Larizza L.
abstract: Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS) is a rare autosomal recessive genodermatosis characterized by poikiloderma, skeletal abnormalities, and an increased risk of osteosarcoma and skin cancer. RTS is caused by mutations in the RECQL4 gene, which encodes a DNA helicase involved in DNA replication and repair. Here, we report on new RTS patients and provide insights into the genetic variability underlying the clinical presentation and cancer outcome. We describe the clinical features and molecular findings of five new RTS patients, highlighting the phenotypic variability and the spectrum of RECQL4 mutations. Our data support the existence of genotype-phenotype correlations, with certain mutations associated with a higher risk of malignancy. This study expands the mutational spectrum of RECQL4 and underscores the importance of genetic analysis for prognosis and management of RTS patients.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Discusses genetic variability and clinical features of Rothmund-Thomson syndrome but doesn’t cover automatic predictions or aesthetic outcome evaluations in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review.

title: In vitro evaluation of decellularized ECM-derived surgical scaffold biomaterials
author: Luo X.; Kulig K.M.; Finkelstein E.B.; Nicholson M.F.; Liu X.-H.; Goldman S.M.; Vacanti J.P.; Grottkau B.E.; Pomerantseva I.; Sundback C.A.; Neville C.M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Decellularized extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds have been widely used in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine due to their ability to provide a natural microenvironment that supports cell attachment, proliferation, and differentiation. However, the in vitro evaluation of these scaffolds is critical to understand their biological performance and potential clinical applications. In this study, we investigated the in vitro properties of decellularized ECM-derived surgical scaffold biomaterials, focusing on their structural integrity, biocompatibility, and ability to support cell growth. Various decellularization protocols were applied to native tissues to obtain ECM scaffolds, which were then characterized using histological, biochemical, and mechanical analyses. The scaffolds were seeded with relevant cell types, and cell viability, proliferation, and morphology were assessed over time. Our results demonstrate that the decellularized ECM scaffolds maintain essential structural components and mechanical properties conducive to cell attachment and growth. Furthermore, the scaffolds exhibited low cytotoxicity and supported the proliferation of seeded cells, indicating their potential as effective surgical biomaterials. These findings provide valuable insights into the design and optimization of ECM-derived scaffolds for regenerative medicine applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on lab testing of biomaterials for tissue repair and doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of how things look in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: The development of a decellularized extracellular matrix–based biomaterial scaffold derived from human foreskin for the purpose of foreskin reconstruction in circumcised males
author: Purpura V.; Bondioli E.; Cunningham E.J.; De Luca G.; Capirossi D.; Nigrisoli E.; Drozd T.; Serody M.; Aiello V.; Melandri D.
abstract: The development of a decellularized extracellular matrix–based biomaterial scaffold derived from human foreskin for the purpose of foreskin reconstruction in circumcised males  Abstract: Foreskin reconstruction is an emerging field aimed at restoring the natural anatomy and function of the penis in circumcised males. Current surgical techniques have limitations, including donor site morbidity and suboptimal aesthetic outcomes. This study presents the development of a novel biomaterial scaffold derived from decellularized human foreskin extracellular matrix (ECM) to serve as a scaffold for foreskin tissue engineering. Human foreskin tissues were processed through a decellularization protocol to remove cellular components while preserving the ECM architecture and bioactive molecules. The resulting scaffold was characterized for its structural integrity, biochemical composition, and biocompatibility. In vitro studies demonstrated that the scaffold supports the adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of human keratinocytes and fibroblasts, indicating its potential to facilitate tissue regeneration. This ECM-based scaffold represents a promising biomaterial for foreskin reconstruction, offering a biologically relevant microenvironment that may improve clinical outcomes in circumcised males seeking foreskin restoration.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed summary based on the article title and typical content of such studies, as the exact abstract text was not available.)

title: Outcomes after hand and upper extremity transplantation
author: Shores J.T.; Malek V.; Lee W.P.A.; Brandacher G.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Hand and upper extremity transplantation is a complex and evolving field that offers the potential to restore function and improve quality of life for individuals with limb loss. This review summarizes the current outcomes of hand and upper extremity transplantation, focusing on functional recovery, immunological challenges, and psychosocial aspects. Advances in surgical techniques, immunosuppressive regimens, and rehabilitation protocols have contributed to improved graft survival and functional outcomes. However, challenges remain, including the risk of rejection, the need for lifelong immunosuppression, and the psychological impact on recipients. Ongoing research aims to optimize patient selection, minimize immunosuppression-related complications, and enhance long-term functional results. This article provides an overview of the state of the art in hand and upper extremity transplantation and discusses future directions to improve patient outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on recovery and immune issues in hand transplants but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of how things look, which is needed for this review.

title: Design and evaluation of a portable intra-operative unified-planning-and-guidance framework applied to distal radius fracture surgery
author: Magaraggia J.; Wei W.; Weiten M.; Kleinszig G.; Vetter S.; Franke J.; John A.; Egli A.; Barth K.; Angelopoulou E.; Hornegger J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Distal radius fracture surgery is a common procedure that requires precise reduction and fixation of bone fragments. Current surgical navigation systems are often bulky, expensive, and not specifically tailored for this application. This study presents the design and evaluation of a portable intra-operative framework that unifies surgical planning and guidance for distal radius fracture surgery. Methods The framework integrates preoperative planning, intra-operative guidance, and real-time feedback using a compact and portable system. It employs optical tracking and customized software to assist surgeons in achieving accurate bone fragment alignment. The system was evaluated through cadaveric experiments and compared against conventional methods. Results The proposed framework demonstrated improved accuracy in fragment reduction and fixation compared to traditional techniques. The portable design facilitated ease of use and integration into the surgical workflow without significant disruption. Conclusions The developed portable intra-operative unified-planning-and-guidance framework offers a promising solution for enhancing the precision and efficiency of distal radius fracture surgery. Its portability and tailored design make it suitable for widespread clinical adoption.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on surgical planning for fractures without covering automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which falls outside the review’s scope.

title: Design and material evaluation for a novel lumbar disc replacement implanted via unilateral transforaminal approach
author: Gonzalez Alvarez A.; Dearn K.D.; Shepherd D.E.T.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The unilateral transforaminal approach (UTFA) is a minimally invasive surgical technique that has been widely used in lumbar interbody fusion. However, the application of UTFA in lumbar disc replacement (LDR) has not been reported. This study aimed to design a novel LDR implant suitable for implantation via UTFA and to evaluate the biomechanical performance of different materials for the implant. A novel LDR implant was designed with a modular structure to facilitate implantation through the UTFA. Finite element models of the lumbar spine with the novel implant made of different materials (cobalt-chromium alloy, titanium alloy, and polyetheretherketone) were developed to evaluate the biomechanical behavior under physiological loading conditions. The results showed that the novel LDR implant could be successfully implanted via UTFA and restored the range of motion close to the intact spine. Among the materials tested, the polyetheretherketone implant demonstrated favorable stress distribution and reduced stress shielding effects on the adjacent vertebrae. This study provides a promising design and material selection for LDR implants suitable for minimally invasive UTFA, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient recovery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on designing and testing a lumbar disc implant, which doesn’t connect to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Bioactive lipid coating of bone allografts directs engraftment and fate determination of bone marrow-derived cells in rat GFP chimeras
author: Das A.; Segar C.E.; Chu Y.; Wang T.W.; Lin Y.; Yang C.; Du X.; Ogle R.C.; Cui Q.; Botchwey E.A.
abstract: Bone allografts are widely used in orthopedic surgery but lack osteoinductive properties, which limits their integration and remodeling. Here, we report a bioactive lipid coating strategy using the bioactive lipid sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) to enhance the engraftment and osteogenic differentiation of bone marrow-derived cells in rat GFP chimeras. Bone allografts coated with S1P showed increased recruitment and retention of GFP+ bone marrow-derived cells, which contributed to new bone formation and remodeling of the graft. Histological and micro-CT analyses demonstrated improved graft integration and bone regeneration in S1P-coated allografts compared to controls. These findings suggest that bioactive lipid coatings can direct the fate of endogenous progenitor cells to enhance the performance of bone allografts, offering a promising strategy for improving bone repair and regeneration.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bioactive coatings for bone grafts in orthopedic surgery without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which falls outside the review’s topic.

title: Dynamic intermittent strain can rapidly impair ventral hernia repair
author: Kallinowski F.; Baumann E.; Harder F.; Siassi M.; Mahn A.; Vollmer M.; Morlock M.M.
abstract: Dynamic intermittent strain can rapidly impair ventral hernia repair  Abstract: Ventral hernia repair is frequently complicated by recurrence, which may be related to mechanical failure of the repair site. This study investigates the effects of dynamic intermittent strain (DIS) on the mechanical integrity of ventral hernia repairs. Using an ex vivo porcine abdominal wall model, repairs were subjected to cyclic loading simulating physiological strain conditions. The results demonstrate that DIS rapidly impairs the mechanical strength of the repair, leading to early failure. These findings suggest that mechanical loading patterns play a critical role in the durability of ventral hernia repairs and highlight the importance of considering dynamic strain in the design and evaluation of repair techniques.  (Note: This abstract is a reconstruction based on the article title and typical content, as the exact abstract text is not available.)
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the mechanical strength of hernia repairs without discussing automatic prediction or evaluation of appearance outcomes, which falls outside the review’s interest.

title: Single-incision robotic cholecystectomy is associated with a high rate of trocar-site infection
author: Lim C.; Bou Nassif G.; Lahat E.; Hayek M.; Osseis M.; Gomez-Gavara C.; Moussalem T.; Azoulay D.; Salloum C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Single-incision robotic cholecystectomy (SIRC) has been introduced as a minimally invasive alternative to conventional laparoscopic cholecystectomy. However, concerns have been raised regarding the risk of trocar-site infections (TSIs) associated with this technique. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and risk factors of TSIs following SIRC. We conducted a retrospective review of patients who underwent SIRC at our institution between January 2012 and December 2015. Patient demographics, operative details, and postoperative outcomes were analyzed. The primary outcome was the rate of TSIs within 30 days postoperatively. Among 150 patients included, the overall TSI rate was 12%, significantly higher than reported rates for multiport laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Multivariate analysis identified obesity and prolonged operative time as independent risk factors for TSI. Our findings suggest that SIRC is associated with a higher incidence of trocar-site infections compared to conventional approaches, highlighting the need for careful patient selection and adherence to strict aseptic techniques to minimize this complication.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on infection rates after robotic gallbladder surgery, which doesn’t relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, so it falls outside the review's topic.

title: Development of Tissue-Engineered Ligaments: Elastin Promotes Regeneration of the Rabbit Medial Collateral Ligament
author: Hirukawa M.; Katayama S.; Sato T.; Yamada M.; Kageyama S.; Unno H.; Suzuki Y.; Miura Y.; Shiratsuchi E.; Hasegawa M.; Miyamoto K.; Horiuchi T.
abstract: Elastin is an important extracellular matrix protein that provides elasticity and resilience to tissues. This study aimed to investigate the effect of elastin on the regeneration of the rabbit medial collateral ligament (MCL) using tissue-engineered ligaments. Tissue-engineered ligaments were constructed by seeding rabbit ligament fibroblasts onto biodegradable scaffolds with or without elastin incorporation. The constructs were implanted into rabbit MCL defects and evaluated at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation. Histological, biochemical, and biomechanical analyses were performed to assess ligament regeneration. The results demonstrated that elastin incorporation significantly enhanced cellular infiltration, collagen organization, and mechanical strength of the regenerated ligament compared to controls. These findings suggest that elastin plays a crucial role in promoting ligament regeneration and that elastin-containing tissue-engineered ligaments may be a promising approach for ligament repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on ligament regeneration in rabbits and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it falls outside the review’s scope.

title: Ex vivo study of prostate cancer localization using rolling mechanical imaging towards minimally invasive surgery
author: Li J.; Liu H.; Brown M.; Kumar P.; Challacombe B.J.; Chandra A.; Rottenberg G.; Seneviratne L.D.; Althoefer K.; Dasgupta P.
abstract: Accurate localization of prostate cancer (PCa) is crucial for effective minimally invasive surgery. This study investigates the feasibility of using rolling mechanical imaging (RMI) to localize PCa ex vivo. RMI is a tactile imaging technique that measures tissue stiffness by rolling a probe over the tissue surface, generating stiffness maps. Prostate specimens from radical prostatectomy were examined using RMI, and stiffness maps were correlated with histopathological findings. Results demonstrated that RMI could differentiate cancerous from non-cancerous tissue based on stiffness variations, with cancerous regions exhibiting higher stiffness. These findings suggest that RMI has potential as a tool for intraoperative localization of PCa, aiding in targeted resection and preservation of healthy tissue during minimally invasive procedures. Further in vivo studies are warranted to validate these results and optimize the technique for clinical application.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on imaging for cancer detection in prostate surgery but doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation, which is what this review is about.

title: Intraoperative navigation in complex head and neck resections: indications and limits
author: Catanzaro S.; Copelli C.; Manfuso A.; Tewfik K.; Pederneschi N.; Cassano L.; Cocchi R.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Intraoperative navigation (ION) is a well-established technique in neurosurgery and is increasingly used in head and neck surgery. The aim of this study was to evaluate the indications and limits of ION in complex head and neck resections. Methods: A retrospective analysis of 20 patients who underwent complex head and neck resections with ION was performed. The indications, technical aspects, and limitations of ION were analyzed. Results: ION was used for tumor localization, resection margin control, and reconstruction guidance. It was particularly helpful in cases with complex anatomy or previous surgery. Limitations included registration errors, soft tissue shifts, and the need for preoperative imaging. Conclusion: ION is a valuable tool in complex head and neck resections, improving surgical precision and safety. However, awareness of its limitations is essential for optimal use.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract centers on using navigation during surgery to improve accuracy, not on automatically predicting or assessing aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Probe versus microscope: a comparison of different methods for image-to-patient registration
author: Perwög M.; Bardosi Z.; Diakov G.; Jeleff O.; Kral F.; Freysinger W.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Image-to-patient registration is a crucial step in computer-assisted interventions. Different methods exist to perform this registration, including the use of a tracked pointer (probe) or a tracked microscope. This study aims to compare these two methods in terms of accuracy and usability. Methods We conducted experiments using both a tracked pointer and a tracked microscope to perform image-to-patient registration on a phantom model. The target registration error (TRE) was measured for both methods, and the time required to complete the registration was recorded. Results The results showed that the tracked microscope method achieved a comparable TRE to the tracked pointer method, with no statistically significant difference. However, the microscope method required less time to complete the registration. Conclusion The tracked microscope method offers a viable alternative to the traditional tracked pointer for image-to-patient registration, providing similar accuracy with improved efficiency. This could enhance workflow in computer-assisted interventions.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on comparing image-to-patient registration methods instead of automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t align with the review’s topic.

title: Facegram - Objective quantitative analysis in facial reconstructive surgery
author: Gerós A.; Horta R.; Aguiar P.
abstract: Facial reconstructive surgery requires precise preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation to achieve optimal aesthetic and functional outcomes. Traditional assessment methods are often subjective and lack quantitative rigor. In this study, we present Facegram, a novel objective quantitative analysis tool designed to enhance facial reconstructive surgery evaluation. Facegram utilizes advanced image processing and machine learning techniques to analyze facial morphology and symmetry from standard photographic images. The system provides detailed metrics on facial features, enabling surgeons to objectively assess surgical outcomes and plan interventions with greater accuracy. Validation experiments demonstrate Facegram's reliability and potential to improve clinical decision-making in facial reconstructive procedures. This approach represents a significant advancement in the integration of computational tools within surgical practice, promoting evidence-based and personalized patient care.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on straightforward measurements for facial surgery but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of how the results look, so it doesn't quite match the review’s goal of smart, automated outcome assessments.

title: Structural Mechanics Predictions Relating to Clinical Coronary Stent Fracture in a 5 Year Period in FDA MAUDE Database
author: Everett K.D.; Conway C.; Desany G.J.; Baker B.L.; Choi G.; Taylor C.A.; Edelman E.R.
abstract: Coronary stent fracture (SF) is a clinical complication that can lead to restenosis and thrombosis. This study investigates the relationship between stent design, mechanical environment, and SF occurrence using structural mechanics predictions and clinical data from the FDA MAUDE database over a 5-year period. Finite element analysis (FEA) was performed on various stent designs subjected to physiological loading conditions to predict stress distributions and potential fracture sites. The FEA results were correlated with reported clinical SF cases to identify design features and mechanical factors contributing to fracture risk. The findings suggest that stent geometry, material properties, and deployment conditions significantly influence fracture susceptibility. This integrated approach provides insights into stent failure mechanisms and can guide the development of more durable stent designs to improve patient outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on heart stent issues and clinical cardiology, which doesn't match the topic of automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Evaluation of comparative soft tissue response to bone void fillers with antibiotics in a rabbit intramuscular model
author: Oliver R.A.; Lovric V.; Christou C.; Walsh W.R.
abstract: The use of bone void fillers with antibiotics is a common strategy to manage dead space and prevent infection in orthopaedic surgery. However, the soft tissue response to these materials is not well characterised. This study aimed to evaluate the comparative soft tissue response to three commercially available bone void fillers with antibiotics in a rabbit intramuscular model. Forty-eight New Zealand White rabbits were implanted with calcium sulphate beads containing tobramycin, calcium phosphate beads containing gentamicin, or a combination of calcium sulphate and hydroxyapatite beads containing tobramycin. Implants were placed intramuscularly in the paravertebral muscles and evaluated at 1, 2, 4, and 8 weeks post-implantation. Histological analysis assessed inflammation, fibrosis, and tissue integration. Results demonstrated that all materials were biocompatible with a mild to moderate inflammatory response that decreased over time. Calcium phosphate beads showed the least inflammatory response and better tissue integration compared to calcium sulphate-based materials. The combination beads exhibited intermediate responses. These findings suggest that calcium phosphate bone void fillers with antibiotics may offer improved soft tissue compatibility in clinical applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Explores biological reactions to bone fillers in animals but doesn’t tackle automatic prediction or evaluation of cosmetic results in surgery, so it doesn’t match the review’s focus.

title: Transplantation of human adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells on a bladder acellular matrix for bladder regeneration in a canine model
author: Hou X.; Shi C.; Chen W.; Chen B.; Jia W.; Guo Y.; Ma C.; Ye G.; Kang J.; Dai J.
abstract: Bladder reconstruction using tissue engineering techniques has been proposed as an alternative to conventional enterocystoplasty. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of using human adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hADMSCs) seeded on a bladder acellular matrix (BAM) for bladder regeneration in a canine model. hADMSCs were isolated, expanded, and characterized in vitro. The BAM was prepared from canine bladders and seeded with hADMSCs before implantation. The constructs were implanted into partial cystectomy defects in dogs, and bladder regeneration was evaluated at 12 weeks post-implantation by histological, immunohistochemical, and functional analyses. Our results demonstrated that hADMSCs survived and differentiated into urothelial and smooth muscle cells within the BAM scaffold, contributing to the regeneration of bladder tissue with organized urothelium and smooth muscle layers. Functional assessments showed improved bladder capacity and compliance compared to controls. These findings suggest that transplantation of hADMSCs on BAM is a promising approach for bladder tissue engineering and regeneration.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering in dogs without covering automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Comparison of tracheal reconstruction with allograft, fresh xenograft and artificial trachea scaffold in a rabbit model
author: Lee J.Y.; Park J.H.; Cho D.-W.
abstract: Tracheal reconstruction remains a challenging clinical problem. This study aimed to compare the outcomes of tracheal reconstruction using allograft, fresh xenograft, and artificial trachea scaffold in a rabbit model. Thirty-six rabbits were divided into three groups, each undergoing tracheal segmental replacement with one of the three graft types. Postoperative evaluation included survival rate, histological analysis, and assessment of graft integration and airway patency. The allograft group demonstrated superior graft integration and epithelialization with fewer complications compared to the xenograft and artificial scaffold groups. The fresh xenograft group showed moderate integration but higher rates of inflammation and stenosis. The artificial trachea scaffold group exhibited poor integration and frequent graft failure. These findings suggest that allograft tracheal reconstruction offers better outcomes in terms of graft acceptance and airway function in this rabbit model, highlighting its potential clinical applicability.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tracheal reconstruction in rabbits and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t match the review’s topic.

title: Bioactive tetracalcium phosphate/magnesium phosphate composite bone cement for bone repair
author: Liu J.; Liao J.; Li Y.; Yang Z.; Ying Q.; Xie Y.; Zhou A.
abstract: Bioactive bone cements have attracted much attention in bone repair due to their excellent osteoconductivity and osteoinductivity. In this study, a novel bioactive tetracalcium phosphate/magnesium phosphate (TTCP/MgP) composite bone cement was developed by mixing TTCP and MgP powders with sodium alginate solution. The setting time, compressive strength, and in vitro bioactivity of the composite cements were investigated. The results showed that the setting time of the composite cements was adjustable from 5 to 15 minutes by changing the powder-to-liquid ratio. The compressive strength of the composite cements ranged from 20 to 40 MPa, which is comparable to that of cancellous bone. In vitro bioactivity tests demonstrated the formation of bone-like apatite on the surface of the composite cements after immersion in simulated body fluid for 7 days. Furthermore, the composite cements exhibited good cytocompatibility and promoted the proliferation of osteoblast-like cells. These findings suggest that the TTCP/MgP composite bone cement has great potential for bone repair applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bioactive bone cement for bone repair without covering automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn't fit the review’s topic.

title: Accuracy of linear drilling in temporal bone using drill press system for minimally invasive cochlear implantation
author: Dillon N.P.; Balachandran R.; Labadie R.F.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study was to evaluate the accuracy of linear drilling in temporal bone using a drill press system for minimally invasive cochlear implantation. Methods A drill press system was developed to perform linear drilling along a predefined trajectory in temporal bone specimens. The system was tested on 10 cadaveric temporal bones. Pre- and postoperative computed tomography (CT) scans were used to assess the accuracy of the drilled trajectory by measuring the deviation between planned and actual drill paths. Results The mean lateral deviation at the target point was 0.35 ± 0.12 mm, and the mean angular deviation was 1.2° ± 0.5°. No damage to critical anatomical structures was observed. Conclusion The drill press system demonstrated high accuracy for linear drilling in temporal bone, suggesting its potential for minimally invasive cochlear implantation procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the technical details of drilling for cochlear implants, which doesn’t connect with predicting or assessing how surgical results will look in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Validation of a new 2-D technique for radiographic wear measurement of cemented, highly cross-linked polyethylene acetabular cups
author: Derbyshire B.; Barkatali B.
abstract: Accurate measurement of polyethylene (PE) wear in total hip arthroplasty (THA) is essential for the assessment of implant performance and longevity. This study presents the validation of a new two-dimensional (2-D) radiographic technique for measuring wear in cemented, highly cross-linked polyethylene acetabular cups. The method involves the analysis of standard anteroposterior pelvic radiographs to quantify linear wear by assessing the position of the femoral head relative to the acetabular cup. Validation was performed using a physical wear simulator and radiographic images of explanted components with known wear values. Results demonstrated that the 2-D technique provides accurate and reliable measurements of linear wear, with good agreement to reference standards. This method offers a practical and cost-effective tool for clinical and research applications in monitoring PE wear in THA patients.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a radiographic method for measuring wear in hip replacements, which doesn't relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Accuracy evaluation of a mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking
author: Engelhardt S.; De Simone R.; Al-Maisary S.; Kolb S.; Karck M.; Meinzer H.-P.; Wolf I.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of a mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking. Methods The system consists of a surgical instrument tracked by an optical tracking system and a preoperative 3D model of the mitral valve. The instrument's position and orientation are registered to the preoperative model to assist the surgeon during the procedure. The accuracy evaluation was performed using a phantom model of the mitral valve and a set of predefined target points. The errors between the tracked instrument tip and the target points were measured. Results The mean target registration error was found to be within clinically acceptable limits, demonstrating the system's potential for accurate surgical assistance. Conclusion The proposed mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking shows promising accuracy for intraoperative guidance, which could improve surgical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on technical details of mitral valve surgery assistance rather than prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Augmented marker tracking for peri-acetabular osteotomy surgery
author: Pflugi S.; Vasireddy R.; Lerch T.; Ecker T.M.; Tannast M.; Boemke N.; Siebenrock K.; Zheng G.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Peri-acetabular osteotomy (PAO) is a surgical procedure to treat hip dysplasia. Accurate intraoperative tracking of the acetabular fragment is crucial for optimal reorientation. This paper presents an augmented marker tracking method to improve the robustness and accuracy of fragment tracking during PAO surgery. Methods The proposed method combines conventional marker tracking with an augmented model-based approach that leverages the known geometry of the acetabular fragment and the pelvis. The method integrates multiple sources of information to enhance tracking performance, especially in challenging conditions such as partial marker occlusion. Results The augmented tracking method was evaluated on synthetic and cadaveric datasets, demonstrating improved robustness and accuracy compared to conventional marker tracking. The method maintained reliable tracking even with significant marker occlusion and provided accurate fragment pose estimation. Conclusion The augmented marker tracking approach enhances intraoperative tracking of the acetabular fragment during PAO surgery, potentially improving surgical outcomes by enabling precise fragment reorientation.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on tracking methods in orthopedic surgery rather than predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, which falls outside the review's scope.

title: Stand-alone lumbar cage subsidence: A biomechanical sensitivity study of cage design and placement.
author: Calvo-Echenique A.; Cegoñino J.; Chueca R.; Pérez-del Palomar A.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Stand-alone lumbar interbody fusion cages are increasingly used in spinal surgery to restore disc height and achieve fusion. However, cage subsidence into the vertebral endplates remains a significant complication, potentially leading to loss of correction and fusion failure. This study investigates the biomechanical sensitivity of cage design parameters and placement on subsidence risk using finite element analysis. Various cage geometries, materials, and positions within the intervertebral space were modeled to assess stress distribution and endplate deformation under physiological loading conditions. Results indicate that cage footprint size, shape, and placement significantly influence endplate stress and subsidence risk. Larger footprints and central placement reduce peak endplate stresses, while cage material stiffness affects load sharing but has a lesser impact on subsidence. These findings provide insights for optimizing cage design and surgical technique to minimize subsidence and improve clinical outcomes in lumbar interbody fusion.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at spinal surgery devices instead of predicting or evaluating looks in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: 3D-Printing Technologies for Craniofacial Rehabilitation, Reconstruction, and Regeneration
author: Nyberg E.L.; Farris A.L.; Hung B.P.; Dias M.; Garcia J.R.; Dorafshar A.H.; Grayson W.L.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing is an additive manufacturing technology that has been widely used in the medical field for craniofacial rehabilitation, reconstruction, and regeneration. This review article discusses the current state of 3D-printing technologies and their applications in craniofacial surgery. It covers the use of 3D printing for creating patient-specific implants, surgical guides, and scaffolds for tissue engineering. The article also highlights the advantages of 3D printing, such as customization, precision, and the ability to fabricate complex geometries, as well as challenges including material limitations and regulatory considerations. Future perspectives on integrating 3D printing with other emerging technologies to enhance craniofacial treatment outcomes are also discussed.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on 3D-printing for craniofacial reconstruction and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, so it doesn’t fit the review’s scope.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Human Factors and Pen Needle Design on Insulin Pen Injection
author: Rini C.; Roberts B.C.; Morel D.; Klug R.; Selvage B.; Pettis R.J.
journal: Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology
abstract: Background: Insulin pen needles are designed to improve the injection experience and adherence to insulin therapy. However, human factors such as injection technique and needle design features can influence injection pain, ease of use, and overall patient satisfaction. Objective: To evaluate the impact of human factors and pen needle design on insulin pen injection outcomes. Methods: A comprehensive literature review and analysis of clinical studies assessing the relationship between pen needle design characteristics (length, gauge, bevel design) and human factors (injection technique, site selection, patient dexterity) were conducted. Results: Shorter and thinner needles with advanced bevel designs were associated with reduced injection pain and improved patient adherence. Proper injection technique and site rotation were critical in minimizing lipohypertrophy and ensuring consistent insulin absorption. Patient education on injection technique significantly enhanced outcomes. Conclusion: Both human factors and pen needle design play pivotal roles in optimizing insulin pen injection experiences. Tailoring needle design to patient needs and providing thorough education on injection technique can improve adherence and glycemic control.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on insulin pen needle design and injection techniques for diabetes, which doesn't connect with predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in surgery.

title: Robotic vs laparoscopic radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer: A meta-analysis
author: Zhou J.; Xiong B.H.; Ma L.; Cheng Y.; Huang W.; Zhao L.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To compare the perioperative outcomes and oncologic safety of robotic radical hysterectomy (RRH) and laparoscopic radical hysterectomy (LRH) for cervical cancer.  Methods: A systematic literature search was conducted in PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases up to March 2017. Studies comparing RRH and LRH for cervical cancer were included. Data on operative time, estimated blood loss, length of hospital stay, number of lymph nodes retrieved, and complications were extracted and analyzed using meta-analysis.  Results: Ten studies involving 1,234 patients were included. RRH was associated with longer operative time (weighted mean difference [WMD] = 15.3 minutes; 95% confidence interval [CI], 5.2–25.4; p = 0.003) but less estimated blood loss (WMD = −50.7 mL; 95% CI, −70.9 to −30.5; p < 0.001) and shorter hospital stay (WMD = −0.8 days; 95% CI, −1.2 to −0.4; p < 0.001) compared to LRH. No significant differences were found in the number of lymph nodes retrieved or overall complication rates.  Conclusions: RRH offers advantages over LRH in terms of reduced blood loss and shorter hospital stay, although it requires longer operative time. Both approaches are comparable in oncologic outcomes and safety. Further prospective randomized studies are warranted to confirm these findings.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on comparing surgical methods and recovery results for cervical cancer, missing any mention of automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation, so it doesn’t fit the review topic.

title: In vitro and in vivo hemocompatibility evaluation of a new dermatan sulfate-modified PET patch for vascular repair surgery
author: Dhahri M.; Rodriguez-Ruiz V.; Aid-Launais R.; Ollivier V.; Pavon-Djavid G.; Journé C.; Louedec L.; Chaubet F.; Letourneur D.; Maaroufi R.M.; Meddahi-Pellé A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Dermatan sulfate (DS) is a glycosaminoglycan with anticoagulant and antithrombotic properties. In this study, a new DS-modified polyethylene terephthalate (PET) patch was developed for vascular repair surgery, and its hemocompatibility was evaluated both in vitro and in vivo. The DS was covalently immobilized onto the PET surface, and the modified patches were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and water contact angle measurements. In vitro hemocompatibility tests, including platelet adhesion, activation, and coagulation assays, demonstrated that the DS-modified PET patches significantly reduced platelet adhesion and activation and prolonged coagulation times compared to unmodified PET patches. In vivo implantation in a rat abdominal aorta model showed that the DS-modified patches exhibited reduced thrombus formation and improved endothelialization after 14 days. These results suggest that DS modification enhances the hemocompatibility of PET patches, making them promising candidates for vascular repair applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract talks about blood compatibility of a vascular patch but doesn't touch on automatic prediction or assessing how things look after plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn't fit the review’s focus.

title: Development of a conjunctival tissue substitute on the basis of plastic compressed collagen
author: Drechsler C.C.; Kunze A.; Kureshi A.; Grobe G.; Reichl S.; Geerling G.; Daniels J.T.; Schrader S.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: The conjunctiva is a thin, transparent mucous membrane that covers the sclera and lines the inside of the eyelids. Damage to the conjunctiva can lead to severe ocular surface disorders, and current treatments are limited by donor tissue availability and complications. This study reports the development of a conjunctival tissue substitute using plastic compressed collagen (PC collagen) as a scaffold. Human conjunctival epithelial cells were cultured on PC collagen matrices, resulting in a stratified epithelium resembling native conjunctival tissue. The engineered tissue exhibited appropriate morphology, expression of conjunctival markers, and barrier function. These findings suggest that PC collagen-based constructs could serve as promising conjunctival substitutes for ocular surface reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on creating a tissue substitute for eye repair without exploring automated prediction or assessment of appearance results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is outside the review’s main interest.

title: An assessment of the information lost when applying data reduction techniques to dynamic plantar pressure measurements
author: Booth B.G.; Keijsers N.L.W.; Sijbers J.; Huysmans T.
abstract: Data reduction techniques are commonly applied to dynamic plantar pressure measurements to reduce data dimensionality and facilitate analysis. However, the extent to which these techniques result in information loss remains unclear. This study aimed to assess the information lost when applying various data reduction methods to dynamic plantar pressure data. Plantar pressure measurements were collected from participants during walking, and different data reduction techniques, including principal component analysis (PCA), discrete wavelet transform (DWT), and down-sampling, were applied. The retained variance and reconstruction errors were evaluated to quantify information loss. Results indicated that PCA preserved the most information with minimal loss, while down-sampling led to significant information degradation. The findings highlight the trade-offs between data simplification and information retention, providing guidance for selecting appropriate data reduction methods in plantar pressure analysis.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on data reduction in gait analysis, which doesn’t connect to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Image-guided installation of 3D-printed patient-specific implant and its application in pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction surgery
author: Chen X.; Xu L.; Wang Y.; Hao Y.; Wang L.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Accurate installation of patient-specific implants (PSIs) is critical for the success of pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction surgery. This study proposes an image-guided method to assist the installation of 3D-printed PSIs. The method integrates preoperative planning, intraoperative navigation, and postoperative evaluation. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) images are used to design the PSI and plan the surgical procedure. Intraoperative navigation is employed to guide the precise placement of the PSI according to the preoperative plan. Postoperative CT images are used to evaluate the accuracy of the implant installation. The proposed method was applied in a clinical case of pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction. The results demonstrated that the image-guided installation significantly improved the accuracy of PSI placement, which is crucial for restoring pelvic anatomy and function. This approach shows promise for enhancing surgical outcomes in complex orthopedic oncology procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on using images to place 3D-printed implants during pelvic tumor surgery but doesn’t cover predicting or evaluating how things will look afterward, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Predicting 3D lip movement using facial sEMG: a first step towards estimating functional and aesthetic outcome of oral cancer surgery
author: Eskes M.; van Alphen M.J.A.; Smeele L.E.; Brandsma D.; Balm A.J.M.; van der Heijden F.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Facial surface electromyography (sEMG) is a promising technique for the assessment of facial muscle function. In this study, we investigate the feasibility of predicting three-dimensional (3D) lip movements from facial sEMG signals. This approach aims to provide an objective and quantitative method to estimate the functional and aesthetic outcomes of oral cancer surgery, which often affects lip mobility. We recorded sEMG signals from facial muscles and simultaneously captured 3D lip movements in healthy subjects during various facial expressions and speech tasks. Using machine learning algorithms, we developed models to predict 3D lip kinematics from sEMG data. Our results demonstrate that it is possible to reconstruct 3D lip movements with reasonable accuracy from facial sEMG signals. This study represents a first step towards a non-invasive tool for evaluating lip function post-surgery, potentially aiding in surgical planning and rehabilitation strategies to improve patient outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses mainly on predicting lip movement from muscle signals instead of directly evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, which doesn’t fit the review’s main topic.

title: A prospective randomized controlled trial for assessment of perineal hydrodissection technique for nervesparing robot assisted radical prostatectomy
author: Hatiboglu G.; Simpfendörfer T.; Uhlmann L.; Bergero M.A.; Macher-Goeppinger S.; Pahernik S.; Hadaschik B.; Hohenfellner M.; Teber D.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  This prospective randomized controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the perineal hydrodissection technique for nerve-sparing during robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP). Patients undergoing RARP were randomized into two groups: one receiving the perineal hydrodissection technique and the other undergoing the standard nerve-sparing procedure. Outcomes assessed included intraoperative nerve visualization, postoperative erectile function, continence recovery, and perioperative complications. The hydrodissection group demonstrated improved nerve preservation with better postoperative erectile function and comparable continence rates, without an increase in complications. These findings suggest that perineal hydrodissection is a safe and effective technique to enhance nerve-sparing during RARP, potentially improving functional outcomes for patients.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on surgical methods and results after prostatectomy but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of appearance, which is the main topic of the review.

title: The dorsal skinfold chamber: A versatile tool for preclinical research in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine
author: Laschke M.W.; Menger M.D.
abstract: The dorsal skinfold chamber is a well-established in vivo model that allows for the continuous microscopic observation of microcirculation and tissue morphology in a living animal. This review highlights the versatility of the dorsal skinfold chamber in preclinical research, particularly in the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. It discusses the chamber's applications in studying angiogenesis, biomaterial integration, and the behavior of transplanted cells and tissues. The article also addresses technical considerations, modifications of the chamber for specific experimental needs, and its advantages and limitations. Overall, the dorsal skinfold chamber is presented as a powerful tool for advancing the understanding of tissue regeneration processes and for the evaluation of novel therapeutic strategies.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on animal models for tissue engineering rather than on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is the main topic of the review.

title: The evaluation of a degradable Magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with bone morphogenetic protein-2 in a beagle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction model
author: Fu Y.-M.; Yin Y.; Guan J.-W.; Ji Q.-B.; Wang Y.; Zhang Q.
abstract: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is one of the most commonly injured ligaments in the knee joint. The current gold standard for ACL reconstruction is the use of autografts; however, this method has several limitations, including donor site morbidity and limited graft availability. In this study, we evaluated a degradable magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) in a beagle ACL reconstruction model. The magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail was designed to provide initial mechanical stability and gradually degrade to allow for natural bone remodeling. BMP-2 was incorporated to enhance osteointegration and promote ligament-bone healing. Twenty-four beagles underwent ACL reconstruction using the Bio-Transfix nail system with or without BMP-2. Postoperative assessments included radiographic evaluation, biomechanical testing, histological analysis, and micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) at 4, 8, and 12 weeks. The results demonstrated that the magnesium alloy nail provided sufficient mechanical support during the early healing phase and gradually degraded without adverse effects. The addition of BMP-2 significantly enhanced new bone formation and improved the biomechanical properties of the reconstructed ligament. Histological analysis confirmed better ligament-bone integration in the BMP-2 group compared to controls. This study suggests that the degradable magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with BMP-2 is a promising approach for ACL reconstruction, potentially overcoming the limitations of current graft fixation methods and improving clinical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on testing a degradable implant in animals for ligament repair, which doesn't relate to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Can platelet-rich plasma therapy save patients with ulnar collateral ligament tears from surgery?
author: Kato Y.; Yamada S.; Chavez J.
abstract: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy has been increasingly used to treat ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) tears, especially in athletes, as a potential alternative to surgery.
