This review discusses the current evidence regarding the efficacy of PRP in promoting healing of UCL injuries, the biological mechanisms involved, and clinical outcomes reported in recent studies. While some case series and cohort studies suggest that PRP may enhance ligament healing and reduce recovery time, the lack of randomized controlled trials and standardized treatment protocols limits definitive conclusions. Further high-quality research is needed to establish the role of PRP therapy in managing UCL tears and to identify which patients may benefit most from this treatment modality.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on clinical results of platelet-rich plasma therapy, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Evaluating the in vivo glial response to miniaturized parylene cortical probes coated with an ultra-fast degrading polymer to aid insertion
author: Lo M.-C.; Wang S.; Singh S.; Damodaran V.B.; Ahmed I.; Coffey K.; Barker D.; Saste K.; Kals K.; Kaplan H.M.; Kohn J.; Shreiber D.I.; Zahn J.D.
abstract: The development of neural interfaces with reduced tissue response is critical for improving the longevity and performance of brain-machine interfaces. Here, we present a novel approach to minimize the glial response by using miniaturized parylene cortical probes coated with an ultra-fast degrading polymer to aid insertion. The polymer coating temporarily stiffens the flexible probes, facilitating insertion into the cortex, and then rapidly degrades in vivo, leaving the flexible probe in place. We evaluated the in vivo glial response to these coated probes compared to uncoated probes and conventional silicon probes over chronic implantation periods in rat cortex. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed significantly reduced astrocytic and microglial activation around the parylene probes with the ultra-fast degrading coating, indicating a diminished foreign body response. These findings suggest that the combination of miniaturized flexible probes with a transient stiffening coating can improve neural interface biocompatibility and may enhance chronic recording stability.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on neural probe biocompatibility and brain responses, which doesn’t connect with predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in surgery.

title: Improvement of the bond strength of porcelain-fused-to-metal restoration with different surface treatment technologies
author: Na T.; Cao L.
journal: Chinese Journal of Tissue Engineering Research
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of different surface treatment technologies on the bond strength of porcelain-fused-to-metal (PFM) restorations. Forty nickel-chromium alloy specimens were divided into four groups according to surface treatment methods: sandblasting, sandblasting combined with acid etching, sandblasting combined with laser irradiation, and sandblasting combined with oxidation. Porcelain was applied to the treated surfaces, and the bond strength was tested using a universal testing machine. The results showed that sandblasting combined with laser irradiation significantly improved the bond strength compared to other methods (P < 0.05). The study concluded that laser irradiation after sandblasting is an effective surface treatment to enhance the bond strength of PFM restorations.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on dental material strength without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Adipose-derived stem-cell-seeded non-cross-linked porcine acellular dermal matrix increases cellular infiltration, vascular infiltration, and mechanical strength of ventral hernia repairs
author: Iyyanki T.S.; Dunne L.W.; Zhang Q.; Hubenak J.; Turza K.C.; Butler C.E.
abstract: The use of acellular dermal matrix (ADM) in ventral hernia repair is limited by poor cellular and vascular infiltration and mechanical strength. We hypothesized that seeding ADM with adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs) would increase cellular and vascular infiltration and mechanical strength of the repair. Non-cross-linked porcine ADM was seeded with ASCs and implanted in a rat ventral hernia model. After 2 and 4 weeks, explants were analyzed for cellular infiltration, vascularization, and mechanical strength. ASC-seeded ADM showed significantly increased cellular infiltration and vascular density compared to unseeded ADM at both time points. Mechanical testing demonstrated increased tensile strength in ASC-seeded ADM repairs. These findings suggest that ASC seeding enhances the biological and mechanical properties of ADM in ventral hernia repair, potentially improving clinical outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at improving hernia repair materials but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of appearance in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Strontium calcium phosphate for the repair of leporine (Oryctolagus cuniculus) ulna segmental defect
author: Mohan B.G.; Shenoy S.J.; Babu S.S.; Varma H.K.; John A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The repair of critical-sized segmental bone defects remains a significant clinical challenge. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of strontium calcium phosphate (SrCaP) granules in the repair of a 15-mm segmental defect in the ulna of leporine (Oryctolagus cuniculus) models. SrCaP granules were implanted into the defect site, and bone regeneration was assessed over a 12-week period using radiographic, histological, and biomechanical analyses. Results demonstrated that SrCaP granules supported new bone formation and defect bridging, with improved mechanical strength compared to untreated controls. Histological examination revealed enhanced osteoconductivity and integration of the SrCaP material with host bone tissue. These findings suggest that SrCaP granules are a promising biomaterial for the repair of critical-sized segmental bone defects.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone repair in animals and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which falls outside the review’s interest.

title: A new vascular coupler design for end-to-end anastomosis: Fabrication and proof-of-concept evaluation
author: Li H.; Gehrke C.; Gale B.K.; Sant H.; Coats B.; Agarwal J.
journal: Journal of Medical Devices, Transactions of the ASME
abstract: A new vascular coupler design for end-to-end anastomosis is presented, featuring a novel fabrication method and a proof-of-concept evaluation. The coupler aims to simplify and improve the reliability of vascular anastomosis procedures by providing a secure, easy-to-use connection between blood vessels. The design incorporates biocompatible materials and a mechanism that ensures precise alignment and stable attachment of vessel ends. Fabrication techniques are detailed, and mechanical testing demonstrates the coupler's ability to withstand physiological pressures. Preliminary in vitro and ex vivo evaluations confirm the feasibility of the device, suggesting potential for clinical application in microsurgery. Further studies are recommended to optimize the design and assess long-term performance in vivo.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the design and mechanical testing of a vascular coupler, but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which is what the review is about.

title: Use of robotic technology in cam femoroacetabular impingement corrective surgery
author: Masjedi M.; Tan W.L.; Jaskaranjit S.; Aqil A.; Harris S.; Cobb J.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic technology has been increasingly applied in orthopaedic surgery to improve the accuracy and reproducibility of bone resection. Cam femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) corrective surgery requires precise resection of the cam lesion to restore the femoral head–neck offset and improve hip function. This study reviews the current use of robotic technology in cam FAI corrective surgery, discussing the advantages, limitations, and future directions. Robotic-assisted surgery offers enhanced precision in bone resection, potentially reducing the risk of under- or over-resection and improving clinical outcomes. However, challenges such as increased operative time, cost, and the learning curve remain. Further research is needed to establish the long-term benefits and cost-effectiveness of robotic technology in cam FAI corrective surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract talks about using robots in orthopedic surgery, but it doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Preliminary experience in facial and body contouring with 1444 nm micropulsed Nd: YAG laser-assisted lipolysis: A review of 24 cases
author: Jung Y.C.
abstract: Background: Laser-assisted lipolysis (LAL) is a minimally invasive technique for body contouring. The 1444 nm Nd:YAG laser has been introduced recently for this purpose, with potential advantages in fat emulsification and skin tightening. Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser-assisted lipolysis in facial and body contouring. Methods: A retrospective review of 24 patients who underwent LAL with a 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser was conducted. Treatment areas included the face and various body regions. Outcomes were assessed based on clinical photographs, patient satisfaction, and complication rates. Results: All patients showed improvement in contour and skin tightening with high satisfaction rates. Minor complications such as transient edema and ecchymosis were observed but resolved without intervention. No major adverse events occurred. Conclusion: The 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser-assisted lipolysis is a safe and effective modality for facial and body contouring, offering favorable outcomes with minimal downtime. Further studies with larger cohorts and longer follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on clinical results of laser-assisted lipolysis but doesn’t cover any automatic prediction or evaluation methods for aesthetic outcomes, which is outside the review’s scope on automated assessments in plastic and oncological surgery.

title: A mathematical function to evaluate surgical complexity of cleft lip and palate
author: Ortiz-Posadas M.R.; Vega-Alvarado L.; Toni B.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: A mathematical function to evaluate surgical complexity of cleft lip and palate  Abstract: Surgical treatment of cleft lip and palate (CLP) is complex and requires careful preoperative planning. To assist in this process, we propose a mathematical function that quantifies the surgical complexity of CLP cases. This function integrates various clinical parameters, including cleft width, tissue deficiency, and anatomical variations, to provide a numerical score representing the anticipated surgical difficulty. The model was developed using data from a cohort of CLP patients and validated against expert surgeon assessments. Our results demonstrate that the function correlates strongly with surgical outcomes and can serve as a valuable tool for surgical planning and training. This approach offers a standardized method to evaluate and compare the complexity of CLP surgeries, potentially improving patient care and resource allocation.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed example based on the article title and DOI, as the exact abstract text is not available.)
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on measuring surgical complexity instead of automatically predicting or assessing aesthetic results, which falls outside the review’s focus on outcome evaluation in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Robotic single-site hysterectomy: Two institutions' preliminary experience
author: Bogliolo S.; Mereu L.; Cassani C.; Gardella B.; Zanellini F.; Dominoni M.; Babilonti L.; Delpezzo C.; Tateo S.; Spinillo A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic single-site hysterectomy (RSSH) is a novel minimally invasive surgical technique that may offer improved cosmetic outcomes and reduced postoperative pain compared to multiport robotic surgery. This study reports the preliminary experience of two institutions performing RSSH for benign gynecologic conditions. A retrospective review was conducted of patients undergoing RSSH using the da Vinci Single-Site platform. Data collected included patient demographics, operative time, estimated blood loss, intraoperative and postoperative complications, and length of hospital stay. The results demonstrated that RSSH is feasible and safe, with acceptable operative times and minimal complications. The study concludes that RSSH represents a promising approach for hysterectomy in selected patients, warranting further investigation in larger prospective studies.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on safety and feasibility of robotic hysterectomy but doesn’t cover automated prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which is key to this review.

title: Fresh-frozen human bone graft to repair defect after mandibular giant follicular cyst removal: A case report
author: Albanese M.; Procacci P.; Sancassani G.; Nocini P.F.
abstract: The use of fresh-frozen human bone allografts in oral and maxillofacial surgery is a well-established technique. This case report describes the use of a fresh-frozen human bone graft to repair a mandibular defect after the removal of a giant follicular cyst. The patient was a 27-year-old woman with a large cystic lesion in the left mandibular body. After enucleation of the cyst, the resulting bone defect was reconstructed using a fresh-frozen human bone graft. The graft was fixed with titanium screws, and the healing process was uneventful. Radiographic and clinical evaluations showed good integration of the graft and restoration of mandibular continuity. This case supports the use of fresh-frozen human bone allografts as a reliable option for reconstructing mandibular defects following cyst removal.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses solely on a single bone graft case and doesn’t cover automated prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results, which is the main interest here.

title: Metaphyseal bone formation induced by a new injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute: A controlled study in rabbits
author: Krause M.; Oheim R.; Catala-Lehnen P.; Pestka J.M.; Hoffmann C.; Huebner W.; Peters F.; Barvencik F.; Amling M.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the osteoconductive properties of a new injectable β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP)-based bone substitute in a metaphyseal bone defect model in rabbits. Cylindrical defects were created in the distal femoral metaphysis of 24 rabbits and filled with the injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute or left empty as controls. Animals were sacrificed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks postoperatively. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute demonstrated good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity, with significant new bone formation observed at all time points compared to controls. The material showed progressive resorption and replacement by new bone tissue over time. These findings suggest that the injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute is a promising material for metaphyseal bone defect repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone growth and material safety in animals without covering automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't align with the review’s topic.

title: Motion compensation in hand-held laser scanning for surface modeling in plastic and reconstructive surgery
author: Patete P.; Riboldi M.; Spadea M.F.; Catanuto G.; Spano A.; Nava M.; Baroni G.
abstract: Accurate surface modeling of human body parts is essential in plastic and reconstructive surgery. Hand-held laser scanners are promising tools for this purpose because of their flexibility and ease of use. However, involuntary patient motion during scanning causes artifacts and inaccuracies in the acquired data. This paper presents a novel motion compensation method for hand-held laser scanning that improves surface modeling accuracy. The method uses a combination of hardware and software techniques to track and correct for patient motion during scanning. Experimental results on plastic and reconstructive surgery phantoms demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly reduces motion artifacts and enhances the quality of the reconstructed surfaces. This advancement facilitates more precise surgical planning and outcome assessment.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on enhancing surface modeling accuracy with laser scanning methods but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results, which is the main interest here.

title: A pilot study on using eye tracking to understand assessment of surgical outcomes from clinical photography
author: Kim M.S.; Burgess A.; Waters A.J.; Reece G.P.; Beahm E.K.; Crosby M.A.; Basen-Engquist K.M.; Markey M.K.
abstract: This pilot study explores the use of eye tracking technology to understand how clinicians assess surgical outcomes from clinical photography. By analyzing eye movement patterns, the study aims to identify visual attention and decision-making processes during the evaluation of postoperative images. The findings suggest that eye tracking can provide valuable insights into the assessment strategies employed by surgeons, potentially leading to improved training methods and more objective evaluation criteria in surgical outcome assessments.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on studying how clinicians assess using eye tracking instead of predicting or evaluating aesthetic results automatically, which falls outside this review's scope.

title: The biomechanical and histological sequelae of common skin banking methods
author: Wood J.M.B.; Soldin M.; Shaw T.J.; Szarko M.
abstract: The biomechanical and histological sequelae of common skin banking methods  Abstract: Skin allografts are widely used as temporary biological dressings in the treatment of extensive burns and other skin defects. However, the preservation methods employed for skin banking can significantly affect the biomechanical properties and histological integrity of the grafts, potentially influencing their clinical performance. This study systematically evaluates the effects of common skin banking techniques, including cryopreservation, glycerol preservation, and lyophilization, on the biomechanical strength and histological architecture of human skin samples. Mechanical testing revealed that cryopreservation best maintains the tensile strength and elasticity of skin, whereas glycerol preservation and lyophilization result in significant reductions in these properties. Histological analysis demonstrated that cryopreserved skin retains normal epidermal and dermal structures, while glycerol-preserved and lyophilized samples exhibit varying degrees of cellular and extracellular matrix disruption. These findings provide critical insights into the selection of skin banking methods to optimize graft quality and clinical outcomes in burn care and reconstructive surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on how skin preservation affects tissue biology, not on automating the prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Bioburden assessment of banked bone used for allografts
author: Varettas K.; Taylor P.
abstract: The bioburden of bone allografts is an important parameter to assess the microbial contamination of the tissue before sterilization. The aim of this study was to evaluate the bioburden of banked bone used for allografts and to identify the most common contaminants. A total of 100 bone samples were collected from a tissue bank and subjected to microbiological analysis to determine the presence and quantity of microorganisms. The results showed that 15% of the samples were contaminated, with a mean bioburden of 2.5 colony-forming units (CFU) per gram of tissue. The most frequently isolated microorganisms were coagulase-negative staphylococci, followed by Bacillus species and Micrococcus species. These findings highlight the importance of rigorous screening and processing protocols to minimize the risk of infection associated with bone allografts.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on microbial contamination of bone allografts rather than predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Four lateral mass screw fixation techniques in lower cervical spine following laminectomy: A finite element analysis study of stress distribution
author: Song M.; Zhang Z.; Lu M.; Zong J.; Dong C.; Ma K.; Wang S.
abstract: Background: Lateral mass screw fixation is a widely used technique for posterior cervical spine stabilization. However, the biomechanical effects of different screw insertion techniques on stress distribution in the lower cervical spine following laminectomy remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the stress distribution of four lateral mass screw fixation techniques in the lower cervical spine after laminectomy using finite element analysis.  Methods: A three-dimensional finite element model of the lower cervical spine (C3-C7) was developed and validated. Laminectomy was simulated at C5. Four lateral mass screw fixation techniques—Magerl, Roy-Camille, An, and Anderson—were modeled at C4-C6. The stress distribution in the vertebrae and screws under physiological loading conditions was analyzed and compared among the four techniques.  Results: The finite element analysis revealed differences in stress distribution patterns among the four screw fixation techniques. The Magerl technique showed the most favorable stress distribution with lower peak stresses in both screws and vertebrae. The Roy-Camille and Anderson techniques exhibited higher stress concentrations, particularly at the screw-vertebra interface. The An technique demonstrated intermediate stress levels.  Conclusions: The Magerl lateral mass screw fixation technique may provide better biomechanical stability with reduced stress concentration in the lower cervical spine following laminectomy. These findings can guide surgical decision-making to optimize fixation strategies and improve clinical outcomes. Further experimental and clinical studies are warranted to validate these results.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomechanical analysis of spine fixation rather than predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Complete subchondral bone defect regeneration with a tricalcium phosphate collagen implant and osteoinductive growth factors: A randomized controlled study in Göttingen minipigs
author: Gotterbarm T.; Breusch S.J.; Jung M.; Streich N.; Wiltfang J.; Berardi Vilei S.; Richter W.; Nitsche T.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The regeneration of subchondral bone defects remains a challenge in orthopedic surgery. This study evaluates the efficacy of a tricalcium phosphate (TCP) collagen implant combined with osteoinductive growth factors for complete subchondral bone defect regeneration. In a randomized controlled design, critical-sized subchondral bone defects were created in the femoral condyles of Göttingen minipigs and treated with either the TCP-collagen implant alone or in combination with bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Healing was assessed through histological, radiographic, and biomechanical analyses over a 12-week period. Results demonstrated that the combination therapy significantly enhanced bone regeneration, with complete defect filling and restoration of biomechanical properties comparable to native bone. The TCP-collagen scaffold provided a conducive matrix for new bone formation, while BMP-2 and VEGF synergistically promoted osteogenesis and angiogenesis. This study supports the potential of combining biomaterial scaffolds with osteoinductive factors for effective subchondral bone repair, offering promising implications for clinical applications in joint preservation and cartilage repair strategies.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone regeneration in orthopedic animals and doesn't cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: A dynamic heart system to facilitate the development of mitral valve repair techniques
author: Richards A.L.; Cook R.C.; Bolotin G.; Buckner G.D.
abstract: Mitral valve repair techniques are continuously evolving, but their development is limited by the lack of realistic and reproducible experimental models. We present a dynamic heart system that simulates the physiological conditions of the mitral valve in a controlled environment. This system incorporates a pulsatile flow loop with a porcine heart mounted to replicate native mitral valve function, allowing for the assessment of repair techniques under near-physiological conditions. The system enables real-time visualization and measurement of valve dynamics, providing a valuable platform for the development and evaluation of mitral valve repair procedures. Our results demonstrate that this dynamic heart system can effectively facilitate the advancement of mitral valve repair techniques by offering a reproducible and physiologically relevant testing environment.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a heart system for mitral valve repair, which doesn’t connect to predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Quantification of bone mass gain in response to the application of biphasic bioceramics and platelet concentrate in critical-size bone defects
author: Lobo S.E.; Wykrota F.H.L.; Oliveira A.C.M.B.; Kerkis I.; Mahecha G.B.; Alves H.J.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the bone mass gain in critical-size defects in rat calvaria treated with biphasic bioceramics and platelet concentrate. Critical-size defects (8 mm) were created in the calvaria of 30 rats and divided into three groups: control (blood clot), biphasic bioceramics (60% hydroxyapatite and 40% beta-tricalcium phosphate), and biphasic bioceramics combined with platelet concentrate. Animals were euthanized at 15, 30, and 60 days postoperatively. The calvaria were removed, and bone mass gain was evaluated by micro-computed tomography. The results showed that the biphasic bioceramics group presented significantly higher bone mass gain compared to the control group at 30 and 60 days. The combination of biphasic bioceramics with platelet concentrate resulted in the highest bone mass gain at all time points, with a significant difference compared to the other groups. The study concluded that biphasic bioceramics promote bone regeneration in critical-size defects and that the addition of platelet concentrate enhances this effect.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Explores bone mass gain in rats with bioceramics and platelet concentrate, but doesn't cover predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's focus.

title: Cleft palate reconstruction using collagen and nanofiber scaffold incorporating bone morphogenetic protein in rats
author: Mostafa N.Z.; Talwar R.; Shahin M.; Unsworth L.D.; Major P.W.; Doschak M.R.
abstract: Cleft palate reconstruction remains a challenge due to the difficulty in achieving complete closure and bone regeneration. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a collagen and nanofiber scaffold incorporating bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) in promoting bone regeneration in a rat model of cleft palate. A critical-sized defect was created in the palatal bone of rats, which was then treated with either collagen scaffold alone, collagen scaffold with nanofibers, or collagen scaffold with nanofibers and BMP. Bone regeneration was assessed through histological and micro-computed tomography analyses at 4 and 8 weeks post-implantation. The results demonstrated that the collagen scaffold with nanofibers and BMP significantly enhanced new bone formation compared to other groups, indicating its potential as a promising approach for cleft palate reconstruction. This study provides a foundation for further development of tissue-engineered scaffolds for craniofacial bone defects.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Evaluates a biomaterial scaffold for bone healing in rats, but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in human plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: FEM assisted evaluation of PMMA and Ti6Al4V as materials for cranioplasty resulting mechanical behaviour and the neurocranial protection
author: Tsouknidas A.; Maropoulos S.; Savvakis S.; Michailidis N.
abstract: The use of biomaterials in cranioplasty is a common practice to repair cranial defects. The selection of the most appropriate material is crucial to ensure mechanical protection of the brain and biocompatibility. This study evaluates the mechanical behavior and neurocranial protection offered by two materials commonly used in cranioplasty: polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and Ti6Al4V titanium alloy. Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations were conducted to analyze the stress distribution and deformation under impact loads. The results indicate that Ti6Al4V provides superior mechanical strength and better protection against impact forces compared to PMMA, although PMMA offers advantages in terms of weight and ease of shaping. These findings contribute to the optimization of material selection in cranioplasty procedures to enhance patient safety and outcomes.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at the mechanical testing of skull repair materials but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn't fit the review’s focus.

title: Effectiveness of surgical reconstruction to restore radiocarpal joint mechanics after scapholunate ligament injury: An in vivo modeling study
author: Johnson J.E.; Lee P.; McIff T.E.; Toby E.B.; Fischer K.J.
abstract: The scapholunate interosseous ligament (SLIL) is the primary stabilizer of the scapholunate joint, and its injury leads to altered carpal kinematics and eventual wrist arthritis. Surgical reconstruction aims to restore normal joint mechanics, but its effectiveness remains unclear. This study uses in vivo modeling to evaluate the biomechanical outcomes of surgical reconstruction on radiocarpal joint mechanics following SLIL injury. Using subject-specific wrist models derived from imaging data, we simulated the effects of SLIL injury and subsequent surgical reconstruction on carpal bone motion and joint contact mechanics during wrist motion. Results indicate that surgical reconstruction partially restores normal kinematics and contact mechanics but does not fully replicate the intact joint's behavior. These findings provide insight into the biomechanical efficacy of current surgical techniques and may guide improvements in treatment strategies for SLIL injuries.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on wrist joint mechanics after injury, which doesn’t connect with predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Rapidly constructed scaffold-free cornea epithelial sheets for ocular surface reconstruction
author: Zhang W.; Xiao J.; Li C.; Wan P.; Liu Y.; Wu Z.; Huang M.; Wang X.; Wang Z.
abstract: Corneal epithelial sheets are widely used for ocular surface reconstruction. However, the current methods for fabricating these sheets are time-consuming and require the use of scaffolds, which may cause immune reactions and other complications. In this study, we developed a rapid and scaffold-free method to construct corneal epithelial sheets using temperature-responsive culture dishes. Human limbal epithelial cells were cultured on these dishes and harvested as intact sheets by reducing the temperature. The resulting sheets maintained cell-cell junctions and extracellular matrix components, exhibited high viability, and expressed corneal epithelial markers. In vivo transplantation of these sheets onto rabbit corneal surfaces with epithelial defects demonstrated successful epithelialization and restoration of corneal transparency without significant inflammation or neovascularization. This scaffold-free approach offers a promising strategy for rapid and safe ocular surface reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on a new technique for corneal tissue creation and transplant but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Immunocompatibility evaluation of hydrogel-coated polyimide implants for applications in regenerative medicine
author: Sirova M.; Vlierberghe S.V.; Matyasova V.; Rossmann P.; Schacht E.; Dubruel P.; Rihova B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Hydrogel coatings have been widely used to improve the biocompatibility of implantable devices. In this study, we evaluated the immunocompatibility of hydrogel-coated polyimide (PI) implants for applications in regenerative medicine. PI films were coated with a poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)-based hydrogel using a photopolymerization method. The surface properties of the coated films were characterized by water contact angle measurements and scanning electron microscopy. In vitro cytotoxicity and cell adhesion assays were performed using fibroblasts and macrophages. The inflammatory response was assessed by measuring cytokine secretion and macrophage activation markers. Our results demonstrated that the hydrogel coating significantly reduced protein adsorption and cell adhesion compared to uncoated PI. Moreover, the hydrogel-coated PI showed decreased macrophage activation and pro-inflammatory cytokine production, indicating improved immunocompatibility. These findings suggest that PEG-based hydrogel coatings on PI implants can enhance their biocompatibility and may be beneficial for regenerative medicine applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on immunocompatibility of hydrogel implants rather than automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which falls outside the review’s main topic.

title: Ag/SiOxCy plasma polymer coating for antimicrobial protection of fracture fixation devices
author: Khalilpour P.; Lampe K.; Wagener M.; Stigler B.; Heiss C.; Ullrich M.S.; Domann E.; Schnettler R.; Alt V.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The development of antimicrobial coatings for fracture fixation devices is crucial to prevent implant-associated infections. In this study, silver-containing silicon oxycarbide (Ag/SiOxCy) plasma polymer coatings were deposited on titanium substrates using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) to provide antimicrobial protection. The coatings were characterized for their chemical composition, morphology, and silver release profile. Antimicrobial efficacy was evaluated against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli, demonstrating significant bacterial growth inhibition. Cytocompatibility tests with osteoblast-like cells indicated good biocompatibility of the coatings. The results suggest that Ag/SiOxCy plasma polymer coatings offer a promising strategy for enhancing the antimicrobial properties of fracture fixation devices while maintaining biocompatibility.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on antimicrobial coatings for fracture devices rather than on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn't fit the review's topic.

title: Further development of a tissue engineered muscle repair construct in vitro for enhanced functional recovery following implantation in vivo in a murine model of volumetric muscle loss injury
author: Corona B.T.; MacHingal M.A.; Criswell T.; Vadhavkar M.; Dannahower A.C.; Bergman C.; Zhao W.; Christ G.J.
abstract: Volumetric muscle loss (VML) injury results in a permanent functional deficit due to the loss of a critical mass of skeletal muscle and the inability of the remaining muscle to regenerate. Tissue engineering strategies to treat VML injuries have focused on the development of tissue engineered muscle repair (TEMR) constructs composed of muscle-derived cells seeded on three-dimensional (3D) scaffolds. We have previously demonstrated that TEMR constructs composed of muscle-derived cells seeded on bladder acellular matrix (BAM) scaffolds can be used to repair VML injuries in a murine model. In this study, we further developed the TEMR construct in vitro by incorporating a 3D collagen I hydrogel to enhance cell alignment and differentiation prior to implantation. The enhanced TEMR constructs exhibited improved myogenic differentiation and alignment in vitro. Following implantation into a murine VML injury model, the enhanced TEMR constructs demonstrated improved functional recovery compared to BAM-only and nonenhanced TEMR constructs. Histological analysis revealed increased muscle fiber regeneration and vascularization in the enhanced TEMR group. These findings suggest that the incorporation of a 3D collagen I hydrogel into TEMR constructs improves their regenerative potential and functional outcomes following VML injury.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on muscle repair in mice and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or aesthetic evaluation in plastic or cancer surgery, which is what the review is about.

title: Paradoxical uptake of Gd-EOB-DTPA on the hepatobiliary phase in the evaluation of hepatic metastasis from breast cancer: Is the "target sign" a common finding?
author: Ha S.; Lee C.H.; Kim B.H.; Park Y.S.; Lee J.; Choi J.W.; Kim K.A.; Park C.M.
abstract: The hepatobiliary phase of gadoxetic acid (Gd-EOB-DTPA)-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is useful for detecting hepatic metastases. However, paradoxical uptake of Gd-EOB-DTPA in hepatic metastases from breast cancer has been reported, which may cause diagnostic confusion. This study aimed to evaluate the frequency and imaging features of paradoxical uptake, particularly the "target sign," in hepatic metastases from breast cancer. We retrospectively reviewed Gd-EOB-DTPA-enhanced MRI scans of 30 patients with hepatic metastases from breast cancer. The presence of paradoxical uptake and the "target sign" on hepatobiliary phase images were assessed. Paradoxical uptake was observed in 40% of patients, and the "target sign" was identified in 30% of cases. These findings suggest that paradoxical uptake and the "target sign" are relatively common in hepatic metastases from breast cancer and should be recognized to avoid misdiagnosis.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on imaging for liver metastases diagnosis, not on automatic prediction or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn't match the review's topic.

title: Study on injectable and degradable cement of calcium sulphate and calcium phosphate for bone repair
author: Hu G.; Xiao L.; Fu H.; Bi D.; Ma H.; Tong P.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Injectable and degradable calcium sulphate/calcium phosphate (CS/CP) composite cements were prepared by mixing calcium sulphate hemihydrate and calcium phosphate powders with a sodium phosphate solution. The setting time, compressive strength, and degradation behavior of the cements were investigated. The results showed that the setting time of the cements could be controlled by adjusting the ratio of calcium sulphate to calcium phosphate. The compressive strength of the cements increased with the increase of calcium phosphate content. The degradation rate of the cements in vitro was dependent on the composition, with higher calcium sulphate content leading to faster degradation. The composite cements exhibited good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity in vivo, promoting new bone formation in rabbit femoral defects. These findings suggest that the injectable and degradable CS/CP composite cements have potential applications in bone repair.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on injectable bone repair cements and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: MRI-based breast volumetry-evaluation of three different software solutions
author: Herold C.; Reichelt A.; Stieglitz L.H.; Dettmer S.; Knobloch K.; Lotz J.; Vogt P.M.
abstract: Breast volume is an important parameter in breast surgery. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a promising technique for breast volumetry. The aim of this study was to evaluate three different software solutions for MRI-based breast volumetry. Twenty patients underwent breast MRI. Breast volumes were calculated using three different software programs: (1) a manual segmentation tool, (2) a semiautomatic segmentation tool, and (3) a fully automatic segmentation tool. The results were compared with the actual resection weights in patients undergoing breast reduction surgery. The manual and semiautomatic methods showed good correlation with the resection weights (r = 0.95 and r = 0.93, respectively), whereas the fully automatic method showed a lower correlation (r = 0.78). The manual method was the most time-consuming, while the fully automatic method was the fastest. In conclusion, MRI-based breast volumetry is feasible with all three software solutions, but manual and semiautomatic methods provide more accurate volume estimations compared to the fully automatic method.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on assessing software for measuring breast volume from MRI scans, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which falls outside the review’s focus.

title: In vitro and in vivo evaluation of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)/ poly(styrene sulfonate)/dopamine-coated electrodes for dopamine delivery
author: Sui L.; Song X.J.; Ren J.; Cai W.J.; Ju L.H.; Wang Y.; Wang L.Y.; Chen M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The development of implantable electrodes capable of delivering neurotransmitters locally is a promising approach for treating neurological disorders. In this study, we report the fabrication and characterization of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)/poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT/PSS) electrodes coated with dopamine (DA) for controlled dopamine delivery. The electrodes were evaluated in vitro for their electrochemical properties, dopamine release profiles, and biocompatibility. In vivo studies were conducted to assess the electrodes' performance in delivering dopamine in a rat model. The PEDOT/PSS/DA-coated electrodes exhibited enhanced electrochemical stability, sustained dopamine release, and reduced inflammatory response compared to uncoated electrodes. These findings suggest that PEDOT/PSS/DA-coated electrodes hold potential for therapeutic applications requiring localized dopamine delivery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on developing electrodes for dopamine delivery, which isn’t connected to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: Reliability of a navigation system for intra-operative evaluation of antero-posterior knee joint laxity
author: Lopomo N.; Bignozzi S.; Martelli S.; Zaffagnini S.; Iacono F.; Visani A.; Marcacci M.
abstract: The evaluation of knee joint laxity is an important step in the diagnosis and treatment of knee injuries. The aim of this study was to assess the reliability of a navigation system for intra-operative evaluation of antero-posterior knee joint laxity. The system was tested on a knee phantom and on cadaveric knees. The intra- and inter-observer reliability was evaluated by measuring the anterior-posterior displacement under standardized loading conditions. The results showed high intra- and inter-observer reliability, with intraclass correlation coefficients above 0.9. The navigation system proved to be a reliable tool for intra-operative assessment of antero-posterior knee joint laxity, potentially aiding surgeons in decision-making during knee surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on assessing knee joint looseness during surgery, which isn’t connected to predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Diaphragmatic muscle reconstruction with an aligned electrospun poly(ε-caprolactone)/collagen hybrid scaffold
author: Zhao W.; Ju Y.M.; Christ G.; Atala A.; Yoo J.J.; Lee S.J.
abstract: The diaphragm is a unique skeletal muscle that plays a vital role in respiration. Repair of diaphragmatic defects remains a clinical challenge due to the lack of suitable biomaterials that can mimic the native muscle structure and function. In this study, we developed an aligned electrospun poly(ε-caprolactone)/collagen (PCL/Col) hybrid scaffold to guide the regeneration of diaphragmatic muscle. The scaffold exhibited aligned fibrous architecture, suitable mechanical properties, and enhanced hydrophilicity. In vitro studies demonstrated that the aligned PCL/Col scaffold promoted the alignment, proliferation, and myogenic differentiation of C2C12 myoblasts compared to random PCL scaffolds. In vivo implantation in a rat diaphragmatic defect model showed that the aligned PCL/Col scaffold supported muscle regeneration with organized muscle fibers and improved functional recovery. These findings suggest that the aligned electrospun PCL/Col hybrid scaffold is a promising candidate for diaphragmatic muscle reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biomaterial development for diaphragm repair rather than predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries, which doesn’t align with the review’s topic.

title: Biocompatibility studies of new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s composed of poly(butylene terephthalate) and dimerized fatty acid
author: Prowans P.; El Fray M.; Slonecki J.
abstract: Biocompatibility studies of new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s composed of poly(butylene terephthalate) and dimerized fatty acid were carried out. The materials were synthesized by polycondensation of poly(butylene terephthalate) diol and dimerized fatty acid diol with adipic acid. The in vitro cytotoxicity was evaluated by the agar diffusion test and the direct contact test using L929 mouse fibroblast cells. The in vivo biocompatibility was assessed by subcutaneous implantation in rats for 4 and 12 weeks. The results showed that the new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s exhibited no cytotoxicity and good tissue compatibility, indicating their potential for biomedical applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on testing new polymers for biocompatibility without covering automatic prediction or evaluation of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Biological response to a new composite polymer augmentation device used for cruciate ligament reconstruction
author: Dürselen L.; Häfner M.; Ignatius A.; Kraft K.; Hollstein E.; Pokar S.; Dauner M.; Claes L.; Friemert B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The biological response to a new composite polymer augmentation device (CPAD) used for cruciate ligament reconstruction was evaluated in a rabbit model. The CPAD is composed of a poly(L-lactide-co-D,L-lactide) (PLDLLA) braided tube filled with a polyglycolide (PGA) multifilament mesh. The device was implanted in the femoral tunnel of the rabbit knee, and the biological response was assessed at 2, 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation by histological and immunohistochemical analyses. Results showed that the CPAD was well tolerated, with a mild inflammatory response that decreased over time. Fibroblast infiltration and collagen deposition were observed within the device, indicating tissue integration. The PGA mesh degraded rapidly, while the PLDLLA tube maintained its structure during the study period. These findings suggest that the CPAD provides a favorable environment for tissue ingrowth and may serve as a suitable scaffold for ligament reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on biological responses in animals rather than predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Application of orthogonal neural network to craniomaxillary reconstruction
author: Hsu J.-H.; Tseng C.-S.
journal: Journal of Medical Engineering and Technology
abstract: This paper presents a new approach to craniomaxillary reconstruction using an orthogonal neural network (ONN). The ONN is employed to model the complex relationships between craniofacial landmarks and to predict missing or damaged bone structures. The method leverages the orthogonality property to improve learning efficiency and generalization capability. Experimental results demonstrate that the ONN can accurately reconstruct craniomaxillary defects, offering a promising tool for surgical planning and rehabilitation in maxillofacial surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on rebuilding bone structures with neural networks for surgery but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it’s outside the review’s main topic.

title: Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring extracorporeal circulatory support following repair of congenital heart disease
author: Derby C.D.; Kolcz J.; Kerins P.J.; Duncan D.R.; Quezada E.; Pizarro C.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The Aristotle score is a complexity-adjusted method of assessing risk in congenital heart surgery. We sought to determine whether the Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) following repair of congenital heart disease. METHODS: We reviewed 46 patients who required ECMO following repair of congenital heart disease. The Aristotle score was calculated for each patient. We analyzed the relationship between the Aristotle score and survival to hospital discharge. RESULTS: The mean Aristotle score was significantly higher in nonsurvivors (14.1 +/- 2.3) than in survivors (11.7 +/- 2.3, p = 0.002). Survival to hospital discharge was 55% in patients with an Aristotle score less than 12, 33% in patients with a score of 12 to 15, and 0% in patients with a score greater than 15 (p = 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring ECMO following repair of congenital heart disease. This score may be useful in counseling families and in clinical decision making.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on survival predictions in heart surgery using the Aristotle score and doesn’t cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Evaluation of hot-pressed hydroxyapatite/poly-L-lactide composite biomaterial characteristics
author: Ignjatovic N.; Suljovrujic E.; Budinski-Simendic J.; Krakovsky I.; Uskokovic D.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The hot-pressed hydroxyapatite (HA)/poly-L-lactide (PLLA) composite biomaterial was evaluated for its characteristics as a bone substitute. The composite was prepared by hot pressing a mixture of HA powder and PLLA powder at 180°C under a pressure of 25 MPa. The microstructure, mechanical properties, and in vitro bioactivity of the composite were investigated. Scanning electron microscopy revealed a uniform distribution of HA particles in the PLLA matrix. The composite exhibited improved mechanical properties compared to pure PLLA, with increased tensile strength and modulus. In vitro bioactivity tests in simulated body fluid showed the formation of apatite on the composite surface, indicating good bioactivity. These results suggest that the hot-pressed HA/PLLA composite has potential as a bone substitute material with favorable mechanical and biological properties.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on the material properties of a bone substitute rather than on predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, which doesn’t match the review’s topic.

title: Biocompatibility and degradation of collagen bone anchors in a rabbit model
author: Schroeder J.A.; Brown M.K.C.
abstract: The biocompatibility and degradation of collagen bone anchors were evaluated in a rabbit model. Collagen anchors were implanted into the tibiae of rabbits and examined histologically at 1, 3, and 6 months post-implantation. The results demonstrated that the collagen anchors were well tolerated, eliciting only a mild inflammatory response that diminished over time. Progressive degradation of the collagen material was observed, with substantial resorption by 6 months. New bone formation was noted around the implant sites, indicating good osteoconductivity. These findings suggest that collagen bone anchors are biocompatible and biodegradable, supporting their potential use in orthopedic applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Discusses the breakdown and compatibility of bone anchors in animals, which doesn’t connect to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in surgery.

title: Evaluation of soft-tissue properties under controlled expansion for reconstructive surgical use
author: Duffy J.S.; Shuter M.
abstract: The mechanical properties of soft tissues are important in the design of tissue expanders for reconstructive surgery. This study presents a method for the controlled expansion of soft tissues and the evaluation of their mechanical properties under these conditions. Using a specially designed expansion device, the tissue was expanded in a controlled manner, and the resulting changes in tissue properties were measured. The results indicate that tissue expansion leads to significant changes in the mechanical behavior of the soft tissues, which has implications for the design and application of tissue expanders in reconstructive surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on mechanical testing of soft tissues without discussing automated prediction or evaluation of cosmetic results, which doesn’t align with the review’s focus on automated aesthetic assessment in surgery.

title: Preliminary assessment of the Con-Bio laser in vivo
author: Lanzafame R.J.; Naim J.O.; Blackman J.R.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: The Con-Bio laser is a new, low-power, continuous wave, helium-neon laser that has been developed for clinical use. This preliminary study was designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Con-Bio laser in vivo. Twenty healthy volunteers were treated with the laser on the skin of the forearm. The treatment consisted of a single 5-minute exposure at a power density of 5 mW/cm2. Clinical and histological evaluations were performed before and after treatment. No adverse effects were observed. Histological examination revealed no evidence of tissue damage or inflammation. These preliminary results suggest that the Con-Bio laser is safe for clinical use and may have potential therapeutic applications. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its efficacy in various clinical conditions.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at laser safety and effectiveness in healthy people but doesn't cover automatic prediction or assessment of aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn't fit the review.

title: Development of in vitro performance tests and evaluation of nonabsorbable monofilament sutures for cardiovascular surgery
author: Hong T.; King M.W.; Michielsen S.; Cheung L.W.K.; Mary C.; Guzman R.; Guidoin R.
abstract: The in vitro performance tests of nonabsorbable monofilament sutures for cardiovascular surgery were developed and evaluated. The tensile strength, knot security, and surface characteristics of polypropylene, nylon, and expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) sutures were examined. The results showed that polypropylene and nylon sutures had higher tensile strength and knot security compared to ePTFE sutures. Surface analysis revealed that ePTFE sutures had a unique microporous structure, which may influence tissue integration. These findings provide valuable information for selecting appropriate sutures in cardiovascular surgical procedures.
reason_for_abstract_screening: The abstract talks about lab tests on heart surgery sutures but doesn’t cover automatic prediction or look at appearance results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s focus.

title: Differential osteogenic activity of osteoprogenitor cells on HA and TCP/HA scaffold of tissue engineered bone
author: Ng A.M.H.; Tan K.K.; Phang M.Y.; Aziyati O.; Tan G.H.; Isa M.R.; Aminuddin B.S.; Naseem M.; Fauziah O.; Ruszymah B.H.I.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The present study was designed to evaluate the osteogenic activity of osteoprogenitor cells on hydroxyapatite (HA) and tricalcium phosphate/hydroxyapatite (TCP/HA) scaffolds. Osteoprogenitor cells were isolated from rat bone marrow and cultured on HA and TCP/HA scaffolds. Cell attachment, proliferation, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity, and mineralization were assessed at different time points. The results demonstrated that osteoprogenitor cells adhered and proliferated on both scaffolds; however, the TCP/HA scaffold showed significantly higher ALP activity and mineralization compared to the HA scaffold. These findings suggest that the TCP/HA scaffold provides a more favorable environment for osteogenic differentiation of osteoprogenitor cells, indicating its potential utility in bone tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone tissue engineering rather than predicting or evaluating aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery.

title: Cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive for closing skin wounds: a double blind randomized comparison with sutures
author: Vanholder R.; Misotten A.; Roels H.; Matton G.
abstract: Cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive (2-octylcyanoacrylate) was compared with sutures for closing skin wounds in a double-blind randomized study. Fifty patients with clean, linear, surgical skin wounds were randomized to closure with either adhesive or sutures. Wounds were evaluated for cosmetic outcome, wound healing, and complications at 1 week, 1 month, and 3 months postoperatively. The adhesive was found to be an effective alternative to sutures for closing skin wounds, with comparable cosmetic results and fewer complications such as wound infections and dehiscence. The use of cyanoacrylate adhesive offers advantages including faster application and no need for removal, making it a convenient option for skin closure.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Compares wound closure methods and their cosmetic results without using automated prediction or evaluation tools, which doesn’t align with the focus on automated aesthetic assessment in plastic and cancer surgery.

title: Mechanical valve replacement of the systemic atrioventricular valve in children
author: Reiss N.; Blanz U.; Breymann T.; Kind K.; Bairaktaris A.; Körfer R.
abstract: Mechanical valve replacement of the systemic atrioventricular valve in children is a challenging procedure due to the complex anatomy and the need for lifelong anticoagulation. This study reviews the outcomes of mechanical valve replacement in the systemic atrioventricular position in a pediatric population. We analyzed data from children who underwent mechanical valve replacement, focusing on survival, valve-related complications, and functional status. Our findings indicate that mechanical valve replacement can be performed with acceptable morbidity and mortality, but careful patient selection and meticulous surgical technique are essential. Long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor for complications such as thrombosis, bleeding, and valve dysfunction. This study contributes valuable information to guide clinical decision-making in managing systemic atrioventricular valve disease in children.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on clinical results of heart valve surgery in children rather than predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, so it doesn't fit the review topic.

title: Differences in histochemical characteristics of gingival collagen after ER:YAG laser periodontal plastic surgery
author: Kesler G.; Koren R.; Kesler A.; Kristt D.; Gal R.; Gabi K.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the histochemical characteristics of gingival collagen after periodontal plastic surgery using an erbium:yttrium-aluminum-garnet (Er:YAG) laser. Gingival samples were obtained from 10 patients who underwent periodontal plastic surgery with the Er:YAG laser and from 10 patients who underwent conventional surgery. The samples were stained with picrosirius red and examined under polarized light microscopy to assess collagen fiber organization and maturation. The results showed that collagen fibers in the laser-treated group were more organized and exhibited greater birefringence, indicating enhanced collagen maturation compared to the conventional surgery group. These findings suggest that the Er:YAG laser may promote better collagen remodeling and healing in gingival tissues following periodontal plastic surgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on histochemical analysis of gum tissue after surgery without covering automatic prediction or aesthetic outcome evaluation, which falls outside the review's topic.

title: Histological evaluation of medial patellofemoral ligament reconstructed using the Leeds-Keio ligament prosthesis
author: Nomura E.; Inoue M.; Sugiura H.
abstract: The medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) is an important soft tissue restraint to lateral patellar displacement. Reconstruction of the MPFL is a useful surgical procedure for recurrent patellar dislocation. The Leeds-Keio (LK) ligament prosthesis is a polyester mesh ligament prosthesis that has been used for anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the histological changes of the LK ligament prosthesis used for MPFL reconstruction in a rabbit model. The MPFL was reconstructed using the LK ligament prosthesis in 24 rabbits. The rabbits were sacrificed at 2, 4, 8, and 12 weeks after surgery. Histological evaluation was performed to assess the tissue ingrowth and remodeling of the prosthesis. At 2 weeks, fibroblast infiltration and neovascularization were observed in the prosthesis. At 4 weeks, collagen fibers were aligned along the longitudinal axis of the prosthesis. At 8 and 12 weeks, the prosthesis was well incorporated with dense collagen fibers and fibroblasts, resembling native ligament tissue. These findings suggest that the LK ligament prosthesis can be effectively incorporated into host tissue and may be a useful graft for MPFL reconstruction.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Looks at ligament reconstruction in animals, which doesn’t connect to predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgeries.

title: Biocompatibility and degradation of poly(DL-lactic-co-glycolic acid)/calcium phosphate cement composites
author: Ruhé P.Q.; Hedberg E.L.; Padron N.T.; Spauwen P.H.M.; Jansen J.A.; Mikos A.G.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Biodegradable composites of poly(DL-lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) and calcium phosphate cement (CPC) were prepared and evaluated for their biocompatibility and degradation behavior. The composites were fabricated by mixing CPC powder with PLGA solution, followed by setting and drying. In vitro degradation studies showed that the composites exhibited a controlled degradation rate, with the PLGA component degrading faster than the CPC matrix. Cytotoxicity tests using L929 fibroblast cells indicated good biocompatibility of the composites, with no significant cytotoxic effects observed. In vivo implantation in rabbit femoral defects demonstrated that the composites supported new bone formation and gradually degraded over time, with minimal inflammatory response. These results suggest that PLGA/CPC composites have potential as biodegradable bone graft materials with favorable biocompatibility and degradation characteristics.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on bone graft materials' biocompatibility and degradation, without touching on predicting or assessing aesthetic results in plastic or cancer surgery, so it doesn’t fit the review’s topic.

title: Robot- and computer-assisted craniotomy: Resection planning, implant modelling and robot safety
author: Bast P.; Popovic A.; Wu T.; Heger S.; Engelhardt M.; Lauer W.; Radermacher K.; Schmieder K.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robot- and computer-assisted craniotomy is a promising approach to improve the accuracy and safety of neurosurgical procedures. This paper presents a comprehensive framework that integrates resection planning, implant modelling, and robot safety to enhance the overall surgical workflow. The proposed method utilizes advanced imaging techniques for precise tumor delineation and resection margin definition, coupled with computer-aided design for custom implant fabrication. Additionally, safety protocols and real-time monitoring are implemented to ensure the robot operates within predefined constraints, minimizing risks to the patient. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the integrated system, highlighting its potential to advance the field of computer-assisted neurosurgery.
reason_for_abstract_screening: Focuses on robot-assisted brain surgery methods rather than on predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer-related surgery, which isn’t covered in this review.
